column10: Red Alert 3 is a great game. It plays well, has great cameos (WhhOooooOO!), and a lot of content. Red Alert 1 & 2 are better, and had much more impact on the genre. I wish the series would continue at some point. It would be great to see how everything has progressed over the years.

[b]Overall: [/b] 7/10

Red Alert 3 continues the over-the-top acting of previous games and ramps it up to eleven. It has a fantastic cast that just make all the cheesy and hammy lines amazing. Gameplay-wise, while it is more cartoonish than previous games, it can make for surprisingly hard missions as you progress.


[b]Music: [/b] 6/10

Outside of VA, and some sound effects, there is nothing remarkable here. The intro music perhaps is really intense, but that‚Äôs about it.

[b]Visuals: [/b] 7/10

Effects look good, and that‚Äôs about it to be honest. I prefer a more washed down serious tone regarding this aspect like Red Alert 2; colors are too bright here, units are a bit too cartoonish for my taste, and the battlefield is just there.

[b]Gameplay: [/b] 7.5/10
 
At the start, I didn‚Äôt enjoy the gameplay much because of how ridiculous it was looking, but after a while, you get to embrace it. Units are varied, however, there are certain combinations (depending on the army) that are simply broken or too powerful. While every unit having a secondary mode is interesting, it was also tedious since it could lead to too much micromanaging if you really want to enjoy every aspect.

[b]Story: [/b] 6/10

A simple story that works fine for this setting. I would have enjoyed more lore (like it‚Äôs counterpart, Tiberium War), however, I guess that is asking too much.

Command and Conquer 3 is one of the best RTS games you can play today, as it has aged well with time, and the complexity and captivating game play keeps it relevant in today's market. It is an experience unlike any other as it pertains to any and everyone, as the art of war does not discriminate. Command and Conquer 3 has three different campaigns as you explore war through the eyes of the Allies, Soviets, and the Empire of the Rising Sun while dominating your foes and watching those around you become corrupt with power. Command and Conquer‚Äôs campaign has elite pacing contrary to other RTS games, as Command and Conquer 3 does not overwhelm the player with everything the game has to offer from the beginning. As the campaign develops, they slowly unravel the more advanced concepts as the player develops the skills needed to conquer their foes, making it beginner-friendly. Additionally, all the new developments do not feel out of place, as they fit well within the story, as the more advanced forms of combat only show up in the late game. Each country has unique tech and concepts tailored to its beliefs and culture, making each campaign dramatically different and forces the player to think on their feet as combat ensues. Outside the campaign, you can enjoy the skirmish mode where you can hone your skills and master the art of war, as Command and Conquer 3 gives you all the tools to make each skirmish tailored to the player's needs. This allows for an infinite amount of possibilities, making it a game you can come back to time and time again and always find something new to enjoy. I would thoroughly recommend this game to anyone who loves RTS games or is looking to get into the RTS genre, as it has something for both veterans and rookies.

Put a lot of hours into this game. I think I've learned to work around the bugs and use the exploits to my advantage. For example a proton collider on an A.I. enemy construction yard will always make it pack up and move, allowing you to chronosphere it into your base. 

The enemy macro is impossible to deal with with certain enemies, such as if you allow your opponent the time to build aircraft carriers. They use EMP missiles to shut down any of your defenses, then use hydrofoils to neutralize anything that can destroy them. Your units will also stand still while they're getting attacked if the enemy attacking them is out of their range or they are unable to fight back. This is incredibly frustrating if your jets are hovering or circling and just getting wiped out one by one from a bullfrog or hydrofoil. 

This game has a lot of problems, but I've put this many hours into it so I might as well give it a thumbs up.

Great game with balanced multiplayer and an innovative campaign where each mission is designed for 2 player co-op rather than solo play.  RTS games tend to be multiplayer focused and this takes that concept to its natural conclusion.  Sure, you can play the campaign with an AI ally to simulate co-op, but it just isn't the same.

Too bad you can't play this game multiplayer any more.

Few hours on Steam, but more on disk and on DLC, and thousands of hours in other strategy games. 

Red Alert 3 is fun gameplay, models, actors you'll say 'Hey, I recognise them!' and metal af in general. 

I'm going to start with things I didn't like so I can end the "review" on a high note, because you AND the game deserve it!!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Things I didn't like:
- It's dated: Not just technology-wise. It's 2017 now. No male models in the game (other than George Takei). Definitely a weakness here. Would have been hilarious to have some jacked, half-dressed dudes just towering over desks, giving you a briefing with their innuendo-filled dialogue. Definitely a testament to how anything catered towards us fucking nerd gamers in the early 2000s amounted to nothing more than scantily-clad women, explosions and awkward dialogue. Don't get me wrong, I think this shit is funny. The sad part is people still seriously eat this shit up. It doesn't matter if their poster girls where invented by another man, they blame whatever their definition of 'a woke' is when they don't get this elsewhere. It's a bit toxic. 

- Skirmish options: Not enough customisation of the options in skirmish. I recall only being able to change starting currency amount, starting positions and all the factions/teams/colours stuff you'd expect from an RTS game. Having played so many other strategy games, it would have been nice to have the option to customise the experience more. 

- After hours of playing, it's a little TOO simple: Like I said, very accessable to new players of the genre/series, but after a while it gets old. Build power buildings, get money, build units and attack. That's the extent of it. Whereas, popular RTS game Age of Empires 1 over here, you have to get MULTIPLE resources and you have to upgrade individual troops and climb eras/tech trees etc. 


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Things I like: 
+ Art style: The artwork for this game looks really cool. I'm a fan of the bright colours and how they instantly start defining each faction by making them visibly unique, which is also shown through in game with their units and abilities being completely diferent from each other. 

+ 'Bad' live action cutscene acting: 'bad' because it doesn't take itself seriously! One scene showed a Russian general and a Russian Intelligence officer giving you a briefing on the situation by video call. One of the lines was something like "The Imperial Japanese army will thrust themselves into the soft tender regions of the USSR" or something like that and the Intelligence officer, her eyes just widen as if to say 'Did he just actually say that?'

+ The music: Something that has been decent since the first Command and Conquer. The main theme itself over the years acts like a time capsule for that era of video games and like the games, evolves over the years getting more and more modern. Here it's more heavy metal. As a fan of Mastodon, I approve. 

+ The clear and embarrassing use of models: It's like they said 'Hey, what do gamers love?' and some other guy said 'World Wars. Heavy metal. And hot female models.' I like that this is such a clear cliche, like from a movie, because it's over the top and just hilarious. And I hope they knew that. 

+ Gameplay: The game itself is simple enough for anyone to start playing. Power runs buildings, buildings can get money and produce units. But it can get difficult pretty quickly. I play on medium difficulty and some campaign missions I just barely complete, which is quite exciting to see your last two units, low health and all, at the end of a battle when the victory theme plays. One massive exhale and your onto the next entertaining cutscene. The inclusion of skirmish is great too! Plent of maps here, and all 3 factions are playable AND they have a spectator mode where you can just watch a match between the AI play out. Useful for people wanting to record some background footage or sounds, or just take a look at what they do and what everything looks like. Lots of unique units and special abilities for each faction which is essential for a game like this. 

+ Abilities: Every unit has a special ability or unique mode which can make it even more effective in situations. Like the telsa troopers can either electrocute enemies or completly stun vehicles. There are also abilities that you can get depending on your faction, in a similar way that Company of Heroes does. Your bar fills up as you play, you get a point, you can spend that point on an ability, like the space magnet which pulls enemy vehicles into space for them never to be seen again. "Ground control to Major Tom..." 

+ It's fun!

+ Graphics aren't bad either!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Have a great day.

The Cast:

Actresses:  Gina Carano, Vanessa Branch, Jenny McCarthy, Gemma Atkinson, Kelly Hu, Lydia Look, Ivana Milicevic, Grace Asakura, Minae Noji, Kerry Finlayson

Actors:  J.K. Simmons, Tim Curry, Peter Stormare, Randy Couture, Jonathan Pryce, David Hasselhoff, Bill Blair, Paul Eiding, George (mf) Takei

What is that...? The 2024 Cast of Hollywood's 1st $1 Billion Feature Film...(?) NO! That is the cast of Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 (2008). Albeit, Kari Wuhrer was not cast in this third Command & Conquer, that cast listed above is still a AAA cast brought together not for a film, but for a video game in a popular RTS franchise...that somehow Electronic Arts managed to ruin in the years since. So, you get all of that acting goodness, PLUS! There's a classic RTS game all assembled in one package - how could I not recommend C&C:Red Alert 3?!

This game goes hard. Very good RTS with 3 playable factions, each with a considerable amount of units to use. Lots of depth to strategy, while still following a vaguely rock, paper, scissors structure between anti-armour attacks, anti-infantry, and anti-air.

The cut-scenes are very funny as well, you can tell the actors weren't taking it *too* seriously.

If you are looking for a game similar to Age of Empires or Starcraft, Command and Conquer Red Alert 3 is an excelent option. Not only is adictive, but it rocks in everything.

Same as the precursors, the story takes place in a world where WW2 did not happen like it should but rather Soviets against Allies. Seeing the country in crysis, the Soviet leaders travel back in time to kill Albert Einstein, making them more powerful but with the Imperial Japan attacking them. There are 3 stories, where you play as a faction. Just like EA thought about it, it's so nonsense and goofy that is awesome: from the Soviets using bears and electric armors, the Allies using tanks that cloak every unit near them and dolphins to the Japanese using mechas and a waifu to fight. 

If you are used to Age of Empires or Starcraft, let me say this game is kind of different to play, and more depending on which faction you play with. The Soviets can spawn buildings across an area marked by the main centers (or Sputniks), the Allies build a structure and then spawn it in an area marked by their main center (or prospector), and the Japanese can create bots that can merge into buildings wherever they want. And of course, each unit in game is different. Finally, there are commandos that help you win the battle: Natasha, Tanya and Yuriko, each one with a different gameplay. 

Despite being a game from 2008, it aged visually very well. The units, buildings and scenarios are well detailed. 

Do you know that joke of "Doom music goes with everything"? Well, Red Alert's soundtrack too. It's just powerful and motivational. The sound effects are cool too, but maybe the dialogues of the commanders and cutscenes are kind of cheesy. Still, they made a great job with it.

The full price for the game is 20‚Ç¨, which years ago I'd say it was worth it. Sadly the multiplayer mode was shut down, so after finishing the 3 campaigns there is not much to do. During sales it can cost just 5‚Ç¨, or even 2‚Ç¨ at the historical low. I'd recommend you not to pay full price for it.

If I had to add a game to the list of "games that aged like wine", Red Alert 3 takes a spot there. If you love strategy games, this might be the greatest option for you

STUB review::: I will update this review and write a proper one when I have the time, but for the time being I at least want to give a heads up on whether it's good or not, so...

It's great! I recommend it. Netcode is good. 

It's NOT a good Command & Conquer but it IS a good RTS, which is why I am rating this positively.

Whoever worked on this had good ideas in mind and made an RTS the way they think it should have been done. Resource collection has been VERY simplified and every unit having special abilities, which for the latter isn't quite what I like and NOT AT ALL what I want to see in a CnC game, but still despite my personal opinion it is well implemented and it works if you see it as its own thing. The same goes for the resource collection except that I don't mind it being less micro-y.

Pathfinding is good most of the times, then other times its complete garbage. BUT it doesn't drop the game to 1 FPS like it did in Command & Conquer Generals from 2003.

There is a chance of it crashing randomly in multiplayer (had it happen in 1 of 3 games, all of which had AI players in them).

I've owned this game since it came out on disc and have played all three factions through multiple times. It still remains my favourite ever RTS to this day, even over C&C3 and Starcraft 2. It has good graphics, fun and varied missions, a fantastic collection of different units and a sense of humour. Oh, and lots of attractive ladies. It's a crime that it isn't more highly considered than it is.

[b]Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a super fun strategy game that keeps you on your toes. It's all about building bases, making armies, and outsmarting your opponents. The game's set in an alternate reality with cool factions, like the Soviets, Allies, and the Empire of the Rising Sun.

[i]One awesome thing about Red Alert 3 is the variety in gameplay. Each faction has its unique units and strategies, which keeps things exciting. You'll find yourself using different tactics and trying out various units to see what works best.

The game's graphics are pretty cool, considering it's an older title. The design and animations are nice, making the battles look epic. The storyline has that classic cheesy charm, making it enjoyable to follow along.

Now, this game isn't all sunshine and rainbows. The learning curve might be a bit steep for new players. There's a lot going on, and it might take some time to get used to the strategies and mechanics. But once you get the hang of it, it's addictive![/i]

Overall, Red Alert 3 is a classic real-time strategy game that's great for both casual and hardcore gamers. It's got cool factions, engaging gameplay, and plenty of strategy. If you're into strategy games or want to experience some classic RTS action, this game is worth checking out.[/b]

I'd say this game is a must try for it's classic. It's not exactly easy to play multiplayer with anyone anymore, but the campaign is really enjoyable and memorable should you like or love the game.

[h1]Briefly about pros and cons:[/h1]
[b]+ gameplay with a focus on fun
+ cutscenes
+ soundtrack
+ style
+ mods

- $20 for an abandoned game is ridiculous
- AI is more annoying than dangerous
- not working multiplayer without third-party services
[/b]

[h1]Detailed overview:[/h1]

But seriously speaking, this is the essence of fun for me. This is an absolutely meme story with great cutscenes. One of the classic RTS that in my opinion is one of the worse ones and definitely overrated. The graphics style and the designs of the units, maps, the goofy story with purposefully overacted and exaggerated live-action cutscenes, the music - those are all great.

However, when it comes to actual gameplay, the game is basically killed off by an attempt to restrict base building in various ways (depending on faction) in a very bad attempt to make base building, of all things, more varied. These attempts don't land at all and make the whole game extremely tedious - you easily spend 50-75% time fiddling with clunky base mechanics. This game really is a perfect example on why you don't try to fix things that work.

The combat itself is pretty good, some of the units have pretty interesting abilities that allow for distinct strategies and while the game is pretty easy to pick up, it certainly has a pretty high skill ceiling. Which makes it even more of a shame that it got bogged down by bad base management.

And lastly, like many games of its era, its campaigns have forced stealth missions - and like most games of its era, they are fucking terrible and whomever thought them up should not only be banned from working in gaming industry, but banned from using any electronic devices in general, just to make sure they don't release any other digital abomination of any kind, ever.

So I'm going to list some pros and cons.
Pros.
*3D
*Easy for beginners yet can be tweaked to be hard for the veterans
*Decent acting
*Better controls then C&C games before
*Good mission briefing gives clear instructions on what to do for missions
*Co-op mode great fun with friends
*Has Kirov gunship
Cons
*Barely short campaign I wish it would be just a few missions longer
*To play Co-op or online you have to install a third-party server provider
*Soundtracks are not as good as RA2 they should have let Frank Klepacki work his magic
*No upgrades like command and conquer generals loved the upgrades in that game sad to see a system like that not implemented in this game
*The points and unlocking system is only a remnant of what the points system in Generals was. The new system yet new and somewhat good shows a clear sign that C&C has steered away from the generals point system. The system works basically the same as the one yk kill troops and level up to get new abilities. But the abilities are not as good as the old one where in generals the GLA can get stuff like ambush repair and vehicles. In RA3 you get stuff that should just be considered a super weapon they should just add buildings that do that or have a mix of abilities and upgrades. Like maybe some could be like the anti-missile rockets that pop out of the apocalypse tank but as an unlockable ability for RA3.
Summary Overall the game is great even though I had a lot of complaints I still love this game just a lot of missed potential. But that doesn't ruin the game nor make it bad of course if the missed potential was not missed it would have been a better game but I still think it's great. This game is also the best one in the series to play with friends once you get the third-party servers set up it can be a blast going through the campaigns and some friendly skirmishes here and there. After all this in conclusion great game I would recommend you to buy this hopefully some day a remaster of this and the rest of the series will be released maybe even a new RA would be good too.

Red Alert 3 certainly has its positives: amazing music, great visuals, and very campy and fun cinematics. Not to mention the nostalgia. However, it also has issues so fun-breaking that they make it impossible for me to recommend the game.

Every single unit here is some variation of 'it's good against this specific unit type, but practically useless against any other type.' Simple infantry can tank a dozen shots from freaking [i]rockets[/i], [i]tank shells[/i] and [i]superheated lasers[/i]. But then fortified buildings and powerful vehicles practically turn into paper when scratched by those same weapons. In addition, vehicles can one-shot infantry by running them over, and there are some specific units infamous for being too powerful (ex: terror drone, cryocopter).

Of course, meta builds also exist but here they are basically the only ways to (consistantly) win. If you don't abide by such a strategy, then at best you'll handicap yourself, and at worst be straight-up unable to win. Rushing and hyper-aggression are examples of practically being a must here. The balance, as well as superweapons and abilities, all make it feel like we're being heavily discouraged to enter the late game and build large armies. All this leaves most late game strategies underpowered and not really viable.

Then there's the AI, which just [i]blatantly[/i] cheats. They'll have more resources than you, they'll know where you are and what you're doing at all times, and they'll have no issue using all this as well as their near-instantaneous reaction speed against anything you do.

Last but not least, some rapid-fire flaws. Online play doesn't work anymore, fps is locked at 30, the game's price has doubled for no reason, and the game is also way too micro-focused. Not to mention how most effects in this game (explosions, death effects) barely sound fitting and lack any feeling of impact.

Red Alert 3 is often unfairly maligned for its place in C&C history. RA3 (2008) was developed and published by EA, who would release the historically disastrous C&C4, marking a sudden and sharp end to the franchise. While EA has never had a positive reputation among the PC gaming crowd, particularly those who enjoy RTS games, anti-EA sentiment was exceptional during this period. Two years later, the company would win Consumerist‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorst Company in America‚Äù award twice in 2012 and 2013, and bashing EA was a popular internet past-time.

In retrospect, the complaints levelled at EA for their handling of the C&C franchise are more complicated. While C&C4 was a tragic end to the franchise and deserving of intense criticism, it did reflect the shifting tastes of mainstream consumers. Its focus on micro-management predicted the rise of the MOBA genre, with titles such as League of Legends (2009) and Dota 2 2013) later coming to define the genre from 2013 onwards. Red Alert 3‚Äôs biggest failure is being situated too closely to the fall of the traditional base-building genre, and its proximity to C&C4.

Contrary to popular belief, EA‚Äôs involvement in C&C wasn‚Äôt wholly negative. In fact, production values skyrocketed and the series‚Äô low-budget FMV cutscenes now featured cutting-edge CGI and star-studded celebrity castings. C&C3: Tiberium Wars, for instance, featured actors from Star Wars and Top Gun. Red Alert 3 continued this streak, featuring Star Trek actor George Takei, Rocky Horror Picture Show‚Äôs Tim Curry (who delivers his most iconic performance in gaming), and even David Hasselhoff.

Visually, Red Alert 3 was also impressive. To this day, it features perhaps the best water effects you‚Äôll see in an RTS game, which is emphasised by the game‚Äôs focus on naval and amphibious combat. In an effort to be the most attractive game on the market, RA3 also features a heavy dosage of late 2000s glamour models, intending to reference the pin-up models of WW2 and Vietnam. Although a slightly blunt and crass approach, it did spearhead the game‚Äôs marketing efforts through posters, desktop backgrounds and additional merchandising.

Cutting through the glitz and glamour, Red Alert 3 still holds true to the C&C formula. There‚Äôs an excellent blend of rock-paper-scissors combat, and knowledge of the battlefield and units will rightfully bring the most knowledgeable player to the top of the leaderboards. There are two main changes in RA3, the first being an additional focus on units‚Äô secondary abilities. Every unit in the game has an alternative power that can completely change the unit‚Äôs tactical use; attack dogs can stun groups of infantry with an AOE bark, Tesla Troopers can create disruption fields to halt incoming units, and Japanese aircraft can transform into ground mechs to dodge anti-air fire.

While this renewed focus on micro creates significant depth, potentially even an overwhelming amount, I‚Äôm less keen on RA3‚Äôs economic changes. In previous titles (excluding Generals), resources were harvested from large, sprawling Tiberium or Ore fields. These fields were situated in hotspots in the map, and led to intense encounters as enemies would often circle your resource fields in an attempt to pick off your harvesters and disrupt your economy. These fields would often have tactical implications as Tiberium would poison infantry, or could even be detonated as part of a chain reaction in C&C3. In Red Alert 3, resources are gathered directly from small mining outposts a few tiles large, where harvesters go directly back and forth in a very short line to pick up and drop off resources.

In function, this economic system plays much more like Dawn of War 1‚Äôs strategic points rather than C&C. On the one side, it encourages players to push forward to capture key points in the map to gain resources to ultimately win the game. However, the predictive and repetitive nature of resource gathering removes much of the game‚Äôs tension. In previous C&C titles, resource fields could creep near enemy bases or transport lines, creating tension as your harvesters edged closer towards the boundaries of available resources. Now, it‚Äôs oversimplified into a back-and-forth transaction at a singular point of contact. You‚Äôre unable to practically recruit multiple resource gathers to harvest at once, and harvester harassment is much less of a threat.

Overall, Red Alert 3 is a worthy entry in the C&C franchise. While people are hot and cold towards the game‚Äôs stylistic choices, bearing a more cartoonish and goofy approach, the series‚Äô classic gameplay mostly remains. It‚Äôs inevitably drawn into the vitriol of EA‚Äôs management, for both fair and unfair reasons, but it‚Äôs worthwhile to be open-minded and give it a shot. It might not be many people‚Äôs favourite title in the franchise, but it may be a fantastic jumping off point for new players or a refreshing change of pace for veteran C&C fans.

Great game.

[h1] READ FIRST [/h1]

[b] The Negatives [/b]

Don't be fooled by the simplicity of Red Alert 3, everything about this game is just a downgrade from what Red Alert series has established before. 

1) You don't have sub-factions, which was the main reason why Red Alert series set apart from Tiberium series. 

Red Alert series had sub-factions like France, Germany and etc. with unique units. But due to engine limitations, and somewhat.. they had to make compromises. But funny thing is, the Sub-fractions are possible with mods like GenEvo.

2) Red Alert 3 doesn't have Gems. In previous Red Alert games, Ore is main resource, while Gems are the secondary resource which helps double the amount, but somehow the developer removed it for competitive play.

Doesn't matter if they have tried to explained it in the lore, story or interviews. This shouldn't be the reason why the iconic secondary resource should be removed.

3) Nerfed Economy, this is not your typical C&C game where you can just chill and build a medium to large size armies. 

The economy amount you get for harvesting in Singleplayer and Multiplayer is very small. You can only build 1 unit at a time, and 1 barracks and 1 war factory. If you try to build 2 barracks or 2 war factory.. don't be surprised if the eco you have is empty.

4) You're forced to build as quick as possible and you have to keep your remaining units alive for the entire game. 

For example, if you lose 3 tanks, it's game over for you. Unlike in C&C3 you can still recover even if you lose 3 tanks. Again, tied to the economy, but also the units deal less damage.

5) The Campaign is not worth your time, in the campaign mode your economy is shared with your ally, which means if you play solo the AI will never stop spamming armies until your eco is dried. 

Story-wise is not the great, the way they explain why they have to reboot the entire Red Alert series and deleting the Red Alert 2 universe with Yuri's timeline is ridiculous.

6) Commander abilities, in Generals, you gain point abilities for the amount of damage your units dealt, but not in Red Alert 3, In RA3, even if you do nothing, you still gain points.

7) Multiplayer is not easy to get into, if you're very new to this, make sure you understand the basic "Red Alert 3 Build Order", unit damage and abilities for each faction before jumping into Multiplayer.

Is like StarCraft 2 but harder, where on day 1 of 1v1 Multiplayer PvP, you've prepared to counter the player's attacks.

[h1] However there are some positives I can say about Red Alert 3 [/h1]

[b] The Positives [/b]

1) The simplified resource gathering is interesting.. by concept. But sadly, it fails to satisfy solo and non-competitive players. Again the amount of resource you get is very small, GenEvo on the other hand solved this issue by increasing the amount of resource you'll get.

2) I understand the game's design focus is towards competitive, but, somehow i feel like, Red Alert 3 has a bit of Real-Time Tactics elements to it, where you can't just sacrifice too many units or even a level 1 veteran unit. (Which kinda explains why they decided to go with RTT route with C&C4).

3) I kinda appreciate that they brought back the grid-like base building that was in classic C&C games, but there is however the same problem that most 3D/HD C&C have, that is the uneven terrain that you can't build.

Most maps are very small if you look at.

4) The Campaign however as stated above, is painful to play, but you'll still have to get through it in order to understand the game's mechanics.

Thank you for reading this far. If you're still looking forward to buy, or play GenEvo, just wait for a sale.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME THROUGH STEAM.  Steam is pulling support for Operating systems after they become "obsolete", regardless of whether games will only play well on the older OS's or not.  If you paid for it, you should be able to play it on the OS you bought it on.  In 7 years, you will be lucky to play this game.

This game had so much potential, but yet again EA destroyed yet another game series.  Red Alert 3 had so much potential, but they just had to bring back the stupid time machine into the series.  Seriously, it was only needed the first time in order to get the universe started.  It was not needed after that.  Seriously, I came up with a better story plot within 5 minutes, and yet it somehow took years to make this game. . . This game was a major step backwards in the realm of gaming.  Red Alert 2 had better graphics and play style.  

Game positives: 
#1. Large numbers of unique and innovative units and diverse tech trees.  

#2.  This game also added the ability to build aquatic bases, which definitely adds a whole new level of tactical options.  

#4. The opportunity to play each and every mission with a friend is also a plus.  

#5. Computer players giving you static is also a fun feature.

Game negatives: 

#1. Horrible game graphics.  To tell you how bad this game's graphics were when the game came out, games a decade older had better graphics than this game.  

#2. Boring and weird campaigns.  It looks like they put the story making team on hallucinogenic mushrooms before they started coming up with story ideas for these missions.  The poor map makers had to make the best of what they were handed.  This game's campaigns are only good playing twice, once by yourself and once with a friend, if you can even find a friend to play this game with.  Even then, it is obvious that the campaigns were designed for multiplayer.  It is not that fun playing it if you are by yourself.  

#3. The computer players also cheat like no tomorrow.  Yes, I know that a lot of poor sports say that, but in this case it is rather obvious.  The computer players are able to see and target your units and structures with super weapons and support powers with such accuracy that their human counterparts can not even come close to copying short of the fog of war not existing.  Older Command and Conquer games can at least have the computer players simulate the fact that the fog of war was there.  These ones cannot no matter the difficulty level you have the computer players set to.  Also, the computer players actively are able to toggle between attack modes/secondary powers with all of their units in a ridiculously fast fashion that human players cannot even come close to copying even with using hotkeys.  Think losing an entire air force and navy within one minute because the computer player's forces are able to toggle that fast between targeting ground based and air based assets.  It literally sucked all of the fun that was in the game out of the game. 

#4. On top of that, the skirmish maps suck.  There are also not that many of them.


It is inherently obvious that EA took a ton of short cuts in every single aspect of this game.   It does make me wonder why they even bothered releasing this pathetic excuse for a strategy game.  

I do NOT recommend getting this game unless you get it for free.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is set in an alternate history where the Soviet Union, the Allies, and the Empire of the Rising Sun engage in a fierce conflict. The game's storyline revolves around time travel and the consequences of altering history. The Soviets create a time machine, resulting in an altered timeline where the Empire of the Rising Sun becomes a major threat. The Allies and Soviets must unite against this new enemy and prevent them from conquering the world. The narrative follows various campaigns and missions as the factions clash, featuring political intrigue, humorous dialogue, and memorable characters.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a true gem in the world of strategy gaming, delivering an exhilarating and immersive experience that captures the essence of the series while introducing exciting new elements. From its engaging storyline to its polished gameplay mechanics, Red Alert 3 delivers on all fronts and proves to be a must-play for fans of the genre.

One of the standout features of Red Alert 3 is its captivating and well-crafted storyline. The game takes place in an alternate history where the Soviet Union and the Allies engage in a fierce conflict with the Empire of the Rising Sun. The narrative is rich with political intrigue, humorous dialogue, and memorable characters, creating a sense of immersion that keeps players invested throughout their journey.

The gameplay in Red Alert 3 is nothing short of fantastic. The strategic depth and variety of units and structures at your disposal provide countless tactical possibilities. Whether you prefer a stealthy approach, overwhelming force, or a combination of both, the game caters to different playstyles and rewards strategic thinking. The addition of naval warfare adds a new dimension to battles, forcing players to adapt their strategies and consider the advantages of sea-based units.

Visually, Red Alert 3 is a treat for the eyes. The game boasts stunning graphics and detailed environments that bring the battlefields to life. The attention to detail in unit designs and animations is commendable, adding to the overall immersion. The game's art style strikes a perfect balance between realism and the series' signature aesthetic, creating a visually appealing experience that stands the test of time.

The sound design in Red Alert 3 deserves special mention. The game features a stellar soundtrack that perfectly complements the on-screen action, immersing players further into the intense battles. The voice acting is top-notch, with talented actors bringing the characters to life and delivering witty one-liners that enhance the overall enjoyment of the game.

Red Alert 3 also excels in terms of replayability. The game offers a diverse range of single-player campaigns, each with unique missions and objectives. Additionally, the inclusion of co-op and multiplayer modes allows for endless hours of fun with friends or players worldwide. The online community remains active, ensuring a steady stream of opponents to test your skills against.

The developers have also shown great support for the game post-launch, releasing patches and updates that address any issues and improve the overall experience. This commitment to player satisfaction is highly commendable and further enhances the game's value.
This game's campaigns are cheesy as fuck and the actual game is a pretty good RTS. If that sounds good to you go in blind.

While this isnt Westwood Studios, Red Alert 3 is a surprising hit for EA.

With Red Alert 3 following the classic command and conquer archetype of building a base and defeating an opponent. The twist this time is that Einstein was killed and prevented the Allies/NATO from building their nuclear weapons. As a result, the Soviets are winning in the European Theatre but as a result now have to fight an  unchallenged Imperial Japan.

The story of the three campaigns are full of entertaining moments and characters with Tim Curry‚Äôs Space line being a notable example of the game‚Äôs charm and comedic effect. While improving Red Alert 2‚Äôs systems, 3 manages to actually deliver an enjoyable experience that stands on its two feet.

On a sidenote the promotional artwork for the game is certainly worth a look online.
POI

One of my favorite RTS games of all time, and it's nice, every once in a while, to dust it off and take it for a fun spin again to feel a little nostalgia at playing such a silly game.

The game has that old-school, campy, very silly vibe of a game that does not take itself very seriously. It has fleshed out campaigns for each of the factions. it has balance issues, and unfortunately a very annoying amount of micro, but it's just overall a pretty polished, well-run game. If you like RTS games it's a classic.

Really makes me wish EA hadn't thrown it all away with the gigantic pivot-failure that was C&C4. I know there isn't much appetite for RTS these days but imagine where this franchise could have gone if it wasn't league-ified. Red Alert 4 would've been something I'm sure we all loved, maybe with some sort of 4th faction---like China?

Guess we'll never get to see, though. EA, the killer of dreams. pick this one up if it's on sale though, you won't regret it.

Electronic Arts (EA) released "Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3" on October 28, 2008, but the latest version of the game is still the V1.12 version released in July 2009, since then, EA has not updated the game, but also in 2010 disbanded the game production team. Although EA gave up on the game's follow-up maintenance, it still relied on the Gamespy platform to provide official online services, until Gamespy shut down the servers that provided online services in 2014, Red Alert 3 became a niche game without official operations and jurisdiction.

If you still want to play multiplayer mode, how? May I suggest [url=ra3battle.net] ra3battle.net [/url]! RA3BattleNet not only provides multiplayer skirmish but also provides online cooperation service! It overhauls EA's native online mode and allows players to experience what it was like back in the day! Auto matching, ladder, cooperation, and even the game UI is updated! Such as the CPU and network status bar, which helps you to identify who causes the lag!

A free and advertising-free platform for players, try it today!

Red Alert 3 is a game that holds a special place in my heart, as I've played its prequel since childhood. It's a nostalgic journey that continues the legacy of the Red Alert series with its fast-paced and lighthearted gameplay. The campy storyline, colorful visuals, and energetic soundtrack bring back memories of countless hours spent strategizing and battling it out. While the AI may have its flaws and the game may not reach the complexity of its predecessors, Red Alert 3 still manages to capture the essence of fun and excitement that I remember from the earlier games.

This game is not fun to play, almost entirely because of bad unit pathing. When you select a group of units and tell them to go to point A, half of them will slowly go towards the point, while the other half will get lost and probably die because they ran into enemy static defense. That's assuming they move at all, of course. Many times I would select units, tell them to move to a place, and they would stand completely still. Other times I order a group of units to attack the turret that is slowly killing them, and they sit around for about 20 seconds, allowing the turret to kill 3 more tanks, before they actually start firing. And not all of them fire! I played a campaign game yesterday, and my ally won the game. While they were busy doing that, I was trying to figure out why my army wasn't moving.

I understand that this game is old. I understand that we didn't have the pathing technology that we do now. But this game is just really infuriating to play. There are no mods that I can find that fix this, no way to make this better. I want to enjoy the fun stuff that all the other reviews are talking about, but I can't because this game is so genuinely frustrating to play.

Don't trust the negative reviews about no Multiplayer. Yes, EA no longer supports this game. Yes, they bumped up the price of a 10+ yeah old game that they don't support. Yes, it's still fun (Dunno what these "lag issues" other people get are. I've never had issues).
HOWEVER, you do need to use 3rd party services if you want to get it fully working (but the original CD game needed that anyway) and you do need to use 3rd party programs and servers to use the multiplayer.
Just go to: https://cnc-online.net and follow the Setup guide and F.A.Q.

Although not the best C&C game and not as enjoyable as Red Alert 2, still an amazing and very underrated RTS game.

I believe it's very normal that this game not as enjoyable as Red Alert 2. In this game EA improved in-game graphics and tried different game formula/design. But it really doesn't matter because the game is still quite enjoyable.

Co-commander system is very good. If you have a friend that plays this game (probably no one) you can play together. I don't have any friend, but the co-commander's AI is suprisingly good and with my co-commander, I have never felt alone in any mission. It's really enjoyable.

Cutscenes are well done, mostly entertaining. Story didn't change so much but what have you expected it's an RTS game :D

Each of the 3 factions (Soviet, Allied, Empire) is fairly unique. Each of them has their own playstyle.

The soundtracks of Red Alert series have always been good and in this game, although I know literally nothing about music, I can say that the soundtracks are incredible! (For example, take a look at "[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iSepa672f0s]Rock and Awe[/url]" which is an in-game soundtrack for Allied faction, it is stunning!)

This game is fixed at 30 FPS. Of course if it was 60 FPS, it would be better. But the game doesn't come to eyes jaggy. Maybe it effects the VFX's, but it doesn't make sense at all.

Gameplay comes slower than Red Alert 2 but I think it's very normal. Because they improved the graphics, added special ability to every unit and made the game more tactical. These things decreased the gameplay speed. For instance, In Red Alert 2 you need to train 50 GI for a purpose, but in this game 20 Peacekeeper will enough for that. Every peackeeper have special ability (shield) and their graphics are much more detailed. For these reasons game become more tactical and slower than RA2. We have much smaller but effective, tactical armies in this game. We feel the weight of the units.
The game was designed in this way. I think if they hadn't tried new things and changed the game formula, they would still be criticized. I understand that people expected something as enjoyable as RA2, but it was clear that this was not going to happen. RA2 was a revolutionary game.

They changed the ore refinery system. RA2's ore refinery system was more enjoyable. I've watched a video on youtube and the creator said they changed them because some of the game design reasons (the video: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JQX1VOoBtDA]An Analysis of Red Alert 3's Economy System[/url]). Nevertheless, this ore refinery system feels empty. You intuitively understand something wrong if you have played RA2 before.

I feel like sometimes these games repeat themselves a lot, but I don't know how could they solve this. If I'm not restricted, almost every game I try the same unit formula. They have fairly balanced this game, but I think some of the units are clearly more powerful (I'm saying this for campaign missions). Kirovs in Soviet, Century Bombers in Allied and Rocket Angles in Empire. It is not that easy, but if you mass produce these units, most of the time you win easier.

It's a game that understands how to be fun. From its timeless and colorful art style to all of the missions being playable with a co-commander and the goofy B-movie plot and acting, Red Alert 3 holds up as a very positive experience. The game offers slightly less gameplay freedom than other entries in the C&C series, but that only paves the way for tighter balance and more variety in strategy.

If I just bought this unknowing of how the game play then I wouldn't be as optimistic.

[b][Technical Issues][/b]
1) The game won't launch unless I block the connection to EA server via firewall. RIP CO-OP players.

2) Changing resolution crash the game and I have to edit the option.ini in the Appdata/Roaming.

3) Music sometime stop entirely on loading save during gameplay, Not much is lost because they are inferior to C&C standard.

4) Obviously EA has stop caring of updating this game and fixing these issues. 

[b][GamePlay&Story][/b]
1) 3 Factions with different way of construction is not original but nice. 

2) Story is short and jumpy with not much emotional connection.
-Einstein is dead, So why are there prism tower, mirage tank, iron curtain, and ffs the chronosphere!? even before the doctor defect.
-Apparently Soviet put their entire army on cuba as the next mission is their last stand.
-Apparently Allied send their entire army to negotiation as the next missio- wait, I already made this point.
-Nonsense plot on why premier decide to murder me, Like for what benefit?
-Soviet moral is as hard as a stone....
-The whole story is basically a stereotype of america/russia/japan 
-No intrigue like yuri in RA2 or Kane in RA1. 
-Feel like it was created to fill the void with no justification for sequel.

3) Most of the mission are pretty easy with a few difficult one.
-AI partner made the game very easy.
-Soviet campaign is by far the easiest. I was able to finish them first try even when my AI partner is dead.
-Cryocopter is a hell spawn, I hate it when I play japan's campaign.
-Japan have arguably the most of the difficulty spikes.
-The Allied's final japan mission is quite confusing one.
-Japan's final took a few tries because I didn't split my base up, But can be finished with ~6 Rocket Angels and AI.
-Allied doesn't have low-tier air transport is basically the entire difficulty of the 'Kill president' mission. Thanks cryocopter, Unironically.
-I hate abilities pretty sure I didn't use 60% of them.
-I dislike the artstyle.

I think the Soviets in this game are strong, simple and fun to play, the Allies are okay too, and Japan is annoying, especially since during their campaign, with every mission they feel like they're missing key tools in their arsenal until you get to the last few.

The Soviet campaign has the strongest gameplay since the units you get each mission build nicely on one another and you don't really need all your cool units to make the dream work, you can just smash the enemy. It also has probably the weakest story.

The Allies are both a little mediocre to play, their missions frequently revolve around 'commando' work instead of RTS gameplay, and while they're not terribly boring they are a little dull. Overall, they play the most like C&C Generals and not a Red Alert faction. Their story is terribly dull.

The Japanese is at times fun to play and they have some good missions but the main issue is they aren't particularly fun to play as, and their missions can be more frustrating than anything else in the entire game, including the expansion, because there are times when it feels like you just have no idea what the game expects you to do in answer, and there's no hints forthcoming. Their story is probably the strongest however, because there are actual characters in it, George Takei in his like three minutes of screentime and assorted transmission clips puts on a sterling performance as you would expect of a career professional. It's small but the relationship he has with his son is compelling in the few brief moments you see it. In short, there was an attempt.

So disregarding online for this game in particular because it's long since dead thanks to Gamespy's demise and Uprising has no multiplayer whatsoever, I'm not going to pretend I spent a lot of time in skirmish in this game either, mostly because while all three factions are serviceable enough, they're not an incredible amount of fun to play and you never really get much joy out of any of them. The only draw is the campaign.

For new players, this is a perfectly good RTS to play through if you just want to try and play an RTS that will occupy your time well enough without any glaring flaws or problems.

For veteran C&C fans, this is not a Red Alert or Red Alert 2 sequel really because it completely resets the timeline for the sake of its own canon, sort of making the whole affair of calling it Red Alert somewhat pointless, especially because in this case the gameplay is much closer (possibly thanks to the engine) to C&C Generals, which is a perfectly good game, but I suggest you temper your expectations.

To reiterate and form a synopsis of my opinion: Red Alert 3 is perfectly fine but not exceptional. It will entertain you. Get it on the cheap maybe.

Also, it takes like 5 minutes to launch because it's trying to contact a defunct server, it still runs fine. On Linux too!
very late to the party, still a great game tho

It's cheesy and tacky and unbalanced in so many ways. Playing Allies is easy mode, the cutscenes and "stories" are cringe as hell, and overall there is a lot you have to ignore if you want to enjoy your time here. But, I recommend it regardless if you're looking for a fun and fairly casual strategy game - the graphics have aged really well and the sheer weirdness of what's available to you lends itself very nicely to experimentation and meme builds. My favorite thing to do is 3v3 skirmishes with all brutal AI, just hanging out and interfering in various ways.

Mods are really your best friend here. The base game gets kind of old kind of quickly, but given that this game is 14 years old by now (oh my god i remember buying this when it was NEW), the amount of fanmade maps and mods is nearly limitless. I recommend the 4GB patch (which can be found on ModDB) as an essential add-on because it unlocks MANY many mods.

Should it be taken seriously? lol no. Hell no. This game sucks in so many ways. But god can it be fun.

As a veteran of the original Command and Conquer Red Alert it is easy to see that this game is all of the first two...but much worse. The game-play is the same: a fast-paced RTS with base-building and lots of themed units, a single player campaign, solo skirmishes and a multiplayer function. Despite the genre, there isn't really any strategy involved here: you spam-build the best units and spam-attack them against the enemy. That's it. No pause button with which to plan your offensives, no nuanced decision-making, no utilising the different strengths and weaknesses of your arsenal.

The graphics are cartoony rather than realistic but they are okay, even today, however, what is incredibly out-dated is the depiction of women which is all rather breast-based and wrapped up in skimpy faux-military workwear. I'm a red-blooded male but even I now find it, well, embarrassing. Further, the scenes with real actors against green screens are all amatuerish without reprieve and you end up watching them with a grin and expecting to see the Brazzers logo flash up on screen. The Tanya 'performance' was the keynote speaker at this conference of cack but even the likeable Tim Curry was made to look bad.

Buy Red Alert 1 or 2 instead.

The one Mod that i absolutely love and cant stop to play it the total conversion mod named GeneralsEvo this mod turns Red Alert 3 into the beloved Command Conquer Generals with major graphical improvements and some little extras that the community wished for, if you have Red Alert 3 i recommend you to try General Evo out its really a great mod for a great game.

In the end the only negative thing is like i said in my CnC Tiberium Wars review the behavior of EA with the CnC franchise, its just sad to see that they killed it off like that.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

I wanted to revisit the C&C RA3 but the game is locked at 30fps which makes it an unplayable powerpoint presentation. 30 frames per second used to be the industry standard 15 years ago but let's be real, nowadays no one wants to play a slideshow and people that do are doing so purely because of nostalgia, otherwise no one would be playing this.

I'm sure it's a decent game but in its current state, I find it unplayable. The fps can be unlocked but it will break the game, animations are going to be be wonky and sped up because the devs built the engine of the game with 30fps in mind and the only mod that allows you to play at 60fps with no issues is locked behind a patreon subscription paywall (so thanks, but no thanks). 


Will revisit and leave positive feedback when it will be possible to play at variable refresh rates.

TL;DR Game's fps locked at 30fps, only non-game breaking mod/solution sits behind a paywall.

Loved this game on xbox but the PC version has been a plague. I'm constantly getting audio and graphical issues. Also, certain missions will get stuck during the in-mission transitions, like when the co-commander is talking.

A very nostalgic game I was looking forward to playing, however, besides the cool out of this world concepts for units and the fun - albeit cheesy - cutscenes there isn‚Äôt much else going for it.
The gameplay is not up to par with modern RTS standards and in some cases almost unplayable, You cant shift+click to add a single unit to a group, you cant multi select units holding down shift, you cant customize your keys as you want and the control is very limited, you cant number buildings or select multiples and many many many other gripes in gameplay and control.
The campaign is also extremely overtuned and in some missions even impossible to do on normal difficulty. RA2 has a special place in all old school RTS players‚Äô hearts, RA3 only satisfies 10% of the nostalgia and the love we had for the older game.
TLDR;
Pros:
- Nice graphics
- Good Music
- Funny Cutscenes with an insanely high-profile cast
Cons:
- Boring gameplay
- Extremely poor controls
Overall score 6/10

To overact while still giving maintaining your composure is something a lot of actors don't know how to do well, but by golly he does it effortlessly. What a champ. His cutscenes in Red Alert 3 are the absolute highlights of the¬†campaign and his¬†involvement is absolutely what sold the game.¬†

That being said, I don't think Red Alert 3 (RA3) is a good¬†game.¬†When I press the "don't recommend"-button it's mostly because it's a very binary choice. Usually this is because a neutral option wasn't possible, but with RA3 I have no qualms in not recommending it.

A few positive comments and asides first.

The briefing videos, as stated before, are the highlight of the game. They are brought with such panache and confidence that I couldn't help but smile all the way through. While it has a comedic tone, in its own twisted way the comedy is taken quite seriously. Every faction's (Soviets, Allies, Japanese) culture and stereotypes are taken to a ludicrous extreme and always stay that way. It's very consistent in that sense, which I really appreciated. It's taken to such a cartoony extreme that it's impossible to call it racist - how can you be racist if you laugh at everyone at¬†the same time?¬†

The cartoony look of the game has been heavily debated. I think it fits very well with the tone set by the cutscenes and the developers choosing this style isn't that much of a stretch considering Red Alert 2 was also very campy. People like to pretend RA2 isn't that campy but in that¬†game you have giant squids, time warping commando's and a man who can literally control people's minds. Everyone loved RA2, so RA3's direction is just a logical step to take. RA3 does has a brighter color scheme than RA2 and an amount of bloom that made me want to barf at times.¬†

Only the very first Red Alert was taken pretty seriously. It was World War II with mild fantasy elements. RA1's Soviet campaign literally opens with Stalin overseeing the effects of innocent civilians inhaling toxic gas.

What I'm more concerned about are the game's visuals. Video games, just like a board game (especially when we're talking about RTS games) need to be crisp, uncluttered, and visually readable. In a fraction of a second, you need to be able to tell exactly what's happening on the screen. That being said, I can conclude that RA3 is one of the least readable RTS games I've played. It's gorgeous for sure, especially for the time, but when the biggest challenge in this game is finding my mouse cursor, something has gone wrong.

Half the time I don't even know what I'm looking at, especially during combat. Everything is such a clash of colors and gunfire and particle effects that I'm not even sure what the hell I'm doing. Placing a completed structure is a puzzle all on its own, often I'll be obstructed from putting it where I want and I'll have no idea why, which wastes valuable time.¬†

Units blend in very easily with the environment, which is what the older titles avoided by virtue of having simple graphics. I've found that the only solution to this problem is to lower all of the graphics - with the exception of texture quality - to their lowest setting. But then this obviously makes it feel like you're playing an unfinished game. It's clean, but also hideous.

RA3 lacks the satisfying, ferocious combat of its predecessors. All units with the exception of end-game units feel really weak and you will spend a silly amount of time building a carefully¬†balanced army of 50 units only for them to be destroyed in half a minute when attacking a base. 

The player is much better served turtling up and building a comical amount of airbases, as air units are far more useful in nearly all situations. Trying to find your favorite units in this game is like trying to find your favorite sheet of paper in a stack of papers. This kills all creativity and makes all campaigns feel like a tedious slog of building your defenses and slowly but surely build all your units. Making money in this game is so slow you'd think your ore collectors have clinical depression. 

The pathfinding engine in this game is unfinished. Units either blatantly don't follow orders, try to move through high terrain, get stuck on terrain or form a neat little row like children getting ready for school when given a move command, providing the enemy with easy targets. This doesn't always happen but it happens way too often.

RA3 is also chock full of triggers. Not the Twitter kind, but events that happen when the player completes an objective. Sometimes stuff will happen where the player can only respond appropriately when he already knows what will happen. In other words: trial and error.¬†

The AI is a cheating SOB that can spawn reinforcements out of nowhere to completely turn the tables, and not in a clever way.¬†
- In the second mission of the game you need to kill an end-game level unit who wipes out whole armies in the blink of an eye.
- You'll need to quickly destroy a unit that can only be killed by anti-air units, and if you don't have any, you're SOL.¬†
- In some missions you need to use an unexplained ability to win. You don't know how or where to get it, and I had to look up a guide to figure out how to get it.
- Or you get a tiny portion of the field map, and suddenly it opens up to reveal more enemy bases elsewhere. RA3 does this a lot, and it annoyed me every time.¬†

You're not really encouraged to go out and have fun in this game. The difficulty of missions is like a patient's heart monitor in that it consistently flies up and down. It never feels like a fair fight: the AI always has way more money and options than you. 

And when I feel cheated, I'm not angry, I'm bored.

I wasted money so you don't have to. Don't fall for this shameless cash grab.

If you just want the single player experience, buy the C&C Ultimate Edition on EA Origin for $20. It comes with this game and about 15 others.

But if you want the multiplayer experience, forget about it. The open Multiplayer feature still complains that it can't connect to the Game Spy servers (what, 20 years later?). And the Network LAN feature only half works; my friends can join the lobby but they immediately get kicked out for "not responding".

I bought this game because I thought maybe they actually fixed the multiplayer to work through Steam's interface instead of Game Spy's non-existent servers. Nope. Just a rehash of the same old single-player game that's available on Origin for a fraction of the price, with the same frustratingly broken multiplayer. What a ripoff!

Bears, Bombs, and Big Tiddy Blyats

It's definitely worth the pickup, especially if you plan on playing it with a friend. Note: you need to down C&C Online to play the game with a friend, since the multiplayer feature has been disabled.

The tone is way lighter and more comedic than Tiberium Wars, but overall, it's the same game, just a different theme and story. As mentioned before, what makes it stand out is the co-op feature. I'm not sure why more RTS games don't provide this feature for their campaigns, but I suppose they have reason. It's what makes this experience very unique in comparison to other RTS games.

I've played and replayed this game with a buddy of mine for years now, and we'll probably be doing it again in the future.

There isn't that much going for the story. The gist of it is a time machine has altered history. Nukes were removed and Japan wasn't bombed by A-bombs, thus allowing them to thrive and become the new faction of the game called the Rising Sun. You still have your standard Allieds and Soviets and their unique styles of playing.

Like C&C3, the 30 fps can take some time getting used to, especially if you've been spoiled by higher fps like I have, but you'll get used to it. The game isn't too difficult, but there are some moments that can catch you off guard.

Overall, it's worth a try, especially if you pick it up on special.

Here's the deal, okay? This game is entertaining, addicting, and all those buzz words you hear when a game brags about it's reviews in advertisements. The story is goofy but fun, the balance is... less than perfect, but you'll still have a blast in spite of it, and the graphics are still pretty good compared to some more recent RTS games I've seen released.
However, there's a catch: you will be playing this game ALONE. there are no multiplayer servers still up, and the external tools needed to set up a match with friends is a headache at best, or non-functional at worst. That EA is featuring this is a franchise sale and aren't at least temporarily offering a means to get multiplayer working natively again baffles me.
If you play RTS games to fight AI, go for it, but if you're looking for some PVP look elsewhere.

Easily one of the most addictive games I've ever played. 

Definitely grab this game if you enjoy base building and ordering troops around. The different types of units all have their own special abilities which allow for more tactical gameplay.

There are a few things to point out however:

For some reason they decided to reverse the mouse controls where you have to left click to select something but right click to move it which can be confusing when most similar games like Red Alert 2 use the left click to do both these actions. Thankfully you can change the control scheme for the mouse in the options menu so that it works the same as in Red Alert 2. Just make sure to do this before adapting to the default scheme. 

When booting up the game for the first time the graphic settings will be set to the lowest by default. You can adjust the individual graphic settings in the options menu but you have to access the options menu from the main menu otherwise the graphic settings will be frozen out.

I can't understand all the positive reviews for this one. Red Alert and Red Alert 2 were/are great games, with interesting stories and a diverse range of units. Red Alert 3 on the other hand feels like they got a bit too loose and creative with some of the mechanics and unit types, with the result being a game that's a bit silly and hard to connect to.

Summary
A disappointingly poor instalment in the series and I'm sorry to say it (because i really like the Command and Conquer games) not worth trying. The remastered version of Red Alert and the Tiberium series are available on steam and way better, I suggest giving those a go instead.

This game is so insane, and I am here for it. The story seems like they jumped the shark, and they wore that like a badge of honor. It's so campy, all over the place, a cast of actually great actors and super models with passable to poor acting, and every faction and unit is a stereotype. But at the same time, it's so endearing and charming. There is not a single character I dislike. Heck, the units for this game have some really good voice acting, and I never get tired of hearing them. The game play is also really fun, and every unit is interesting to use. Though I prefer the macro game play of tiberium wars and kane's wrath more, I still find the micro heavy game play very fun. The game play is very unbalanced though. It's a very rush or get rushed, and several units are a lot stronger than others (looking at you cryo copters). Despite this though, I love this game. It reminded me why I loved rts games so much as a kid, and it reignited that love now. Also, the soundtrack is banging. I listen to the battle music and hell march a lot after playing this.

I can't talk about Red Alert 3 without mentioning how much I love this game. It's probably one of the best RTS games ever produced and one of the best games in history. For some strange reasons it was criticized upon release by some old fans of the series. But this was done just because those people grew up on Red Alert 2, another masterpiece which was made by old Westwood Studios, and so they wanted for Red Alert 3 to be more like the previous game. But Red Alert 3 was produced by EA Los Angeles, it was different time and not the 90s anymore, a different developer team. Because of this Red Alert 3 has its own face and I grew up on this game and really loved playing it. Besides, now in 2020s when I am writing this review, we know that RTS genre is almost dead and games of such scale like Red Alert 3, which wasn't ideal for someone back in 2000s, is something which completely impossible to be made today. EA Los Angeles had a lot of dedication to create interesting and modern RTS gameplay and they invited awesome, just amazing cast for playing all the roles. I actually think its the best cast in CnC history, just look at all these names - J. K. Simmons, Tim Curry, George Takei, Peter Stormare!.. Not to mention incredible and super hot female actresses and models - Gemma Atkinson, Gina Carano, Jenny McCarthy, Vanessa Branch, Autumn Reeser, Kelly Hu!.. Oh man, I had such incredible teen years thanks to it! So, it's just difficult to speak about this game any further without praising it so much. And with so many good words already spoken and I didn't even mention it's super amazing soundtrack! Legendary Frank Klepacki along with also some other talented artists once again wrote original tracks for the soundtrack which are so great that I listen to them for more than a decade already!.. So, I want to make it clear that this is one hell of RTS experience and one hell of a game and yes, it's sad that CnC series have gone, but I'm very thankful to EA Los Angeles for what they created. It gave me a lot of awesome memories which I'm still carrying after all these year.

I am a big fan of fast paced RTS like Starcraft BW and Starcraft 2.
RA3 is a really solid game, with lots of options including naval/land/aero combat.

Single player is fun and can become challenging even at normal difficulty because of how many things they throw at you and you always have the AI partner which may or may not respond well.
The down side is the single player campaign is simply like an introduction to the game play and units, while the AI skirmish is quite easy.

And that is made worse because in order to play the multiplayer, you need to go through many loops and I doubt many players are left in my area to have any reasonable ping.

That being said, the game has great cast, great music, fun and interesting mechanics. 
I would definitely rate this as a buy if you are looking for RTS to play. (there's just not many good games in the genre right now)

This game has aged like milk since the dawn of recent strategy games. It is so unbelievably fast paced that it is impossible to keep up with the AI without just rushing units early game and trying to win immediately. There isnt really the ability to turtle due to super powers or abilities. The campaign is full of crap behind every corner. You will be doing a mission and the enemy will just have units spawn out of nowhere in your base or somewhere randomly on the map. It's very much a constantly on your toes and rush down the enemy type of game, not at all meant to be lengthy or grand. I played it a lot when I was younger but it has not aged well or the PC version of this game is far too difficult to be at all enjoyable. I can't extract fun from this anyway I approach it.
Edit1: I forgot to mention that there is fog of war in the game, however, the AI does not even attempt to pretend it has fog of war, it will assemble a force and target your structures adequately no matter where on the map you attempt to build them. The Ai knows where everything is at all times and will counter every seperate attack as much as it can and will not hesitate in its relentless attacks.
