[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3[/b] is the first entry in the [b]Red Alert[/b] series made by a different studio. In the previous expansion for [b]Red Alert 2[/b], the series introduced a bit more over the top story and units you control. This entry continues in this legacy and presents a humorous story with real actors, as well as unique and interesting units for each faction.

[h1]Single-player[/h1]
The single-player offers three campaigns for the Soviet Union, the United States of America, and the Empire of the Rising Sun. It takes about 20 hours to complete them all on the highest difficulty setting. There is no restriction, so you can start playing as any nation you want. The great addition is that you can play all three campaigns in a co-op with a friend or random player. You receive an AI partner if you choose to play alone. Other than that, you can play Skirmish against the AI on several maps.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2155298139
[h3]Story[/h3]
The Soviet Union is almost at its downfall, and only last hope remains. The Soviet Premier manages to travel in time, kills [i]Albert Einstein[/i], and returns. Without [i]Einstein[/i], the western Allies have never gotten an advantage over the Soviets. However, the happiness of the Soviet leadership will not last long, as the new threat from the East emerges. [i]The Empire of the Rising Sun[/i] (Japan) simultaneously invades both Americans and the Soviets. Without [i]Einstein‚Äôs[/i] scientific research, Japan was never bombed with nuclear weapons, as those do not exist anymore. All three factions are now in a war with everyone, and it is up to you, which one will you lead to a victory.
[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The gameplay‚Äôs core is the same for every faction. You collect golden ore from mines which serve as money and build powerplants to keep the power going in your base. Without electricity power, most of your buildings stop working, especially the turrets for your defense. The great addition is that you can build almost every building both on the ground and on water. This allows for more diverse base-building than in previous games. You expand and build new bases anywhere you want, but the ore mines placement is always the same.

The base building is almost the same for every faction, as you always need to build powerplants, barracks, dockyards, defensive turrets, and more. They have a few noticeable gameplay differences, but you will not be completely lost when you will start playing as another nation. The main differences come with the units. There are always anti-infantry, anti-vehicle, and anti-air units. The game has four different unit branches: infantry, ground vehicles, ships, and aircraft. They all differ in each faction, and every single one has two abilities. For example, [i]Soviet Conscript[/i] has an assault rifle and an ability to throw Molotov‚Äôs cocktails. The [i]American Peacekeeper[/i] has armour, short-range shotgun, and can equip a shield. Lastly, the [i]Imperial Warrior[/i] has a rifle and sword, which increases his overall speed. The same goes for all the units in the game. Every nation has something that counters the other‚Äôs units and abilities. Nations also differ with their unique ability tree. While the Soviets can throw satellites on their foes, Americans can freeze them, and the Japanese can send their kamikaze squadrons.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2155296739
Unfortunately, the AI is not the brightest, as it is very scripted in the campaign. It does very rarely something on its own, and once you manage to damage their income or destroy their recruitment buildings, you won. In most cases, the AI will not try to repair their buildings or even build new ones. It does not even try to counter your units, so you can easily spam them with one unit type if you manage to hit them quickly and precisely. The AI is a bit better in the Skirmish, as it is trying to do something, but do not expect an enormous challenge, as you will not find it there.

Another negative is that some campaign missions, especially the ones where you mostly control just heroes, are tiresome. The strength in this game is to build what you want, and that is gone when you are restricted to play with just one or a few units.

[h1]Multi-player[/h1]
The official servers are down, but the option to play [b]Red Alert 3[/b] online, as well as other [b]Command & Conquer[/b] games is still there.

[url=https://cnc-online.net/en/][quote]All you need to do to play [b]Command & Conquer[/b] games online is to go to [b]cnc-online[/b], register yourself, download a launcher, and follow the instructions.[/quote][/url]

The multi-player offers the aforementioned Skirmish maps against real players. There are various maps from 1v1 up to 3v3. Playing against players is definitely a better option, as you have to use accordingly faction‚Äôs units and abilities. Everything else works the same as in the single-player.

[h1]Audiovisuals[/h1]
The game‚Äôs art style is something that I really adore, as it is quite unique and colourful. All three factions are very diverse with their distinctive appearance. You can easily recognize every unit by their looks and can exactly expect what they can do. Some of the visual effects look great for a game from 2008, and that especially applies to some visual effects and water.

However, [b]Command & Conquer[/b] series was always known for presenting real actors in its cutscenes. The Soviet premier is played by famous [i]Tim Curry[/i], who wants to spread Communism to the whole world and Space. Against him stands anti-communists presidents of the United States, portrayed by [i]J.K. Simmons[/i], and they are all invaded by the Japanese Emperor, played by [i]George Takei[/i]. There are, of course, way more actors and actresses, and from some from cutscenes, you can clearly see that they are trying to hold their laugh. When talking about actors, one must mention quotes of the units, as every unit has their quotes depending on the situation they are currently in. Sometimes they are really hilarious or cheesy.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2155296869
The sound effects of all the weaponry, machinery, and explosions are just great, but what really stands out is the soundtrack, which is a mix of several genres, mostly industrial metal with presented vocals. The third version of [i]Hell March[/i] is present. Every faction has their own compositions, and when you are in the middle of a chaotic battle, it all clicks together.

[h1] Performance[/h1]
The game was tested with an [b]i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM[/b] running at the highest settings at [b]30[/b] frames per second, at [b]1920x1080[/b] resolution. The game is [b]locked[/b] on [b]30 FPS[/b]. If you try to unlock the framerate to 60 or more FPS, the game‚Äôs speed will increase, and most of the animations will disappear.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you accept the game for what it is, that means a light-hearted fun with unique design rather than a competitive real-time strategy game, then it presents a fair amount of entertainment. Playing all three campaigns in co-op makes it for a better experience. However, the 30 frames per second cap and other aforementioned shortcomings can definitely be a problem for many.

There's a reason these old-fashioned RTSes disappeared from my life, and I rediscovered that reason while playing RA3: Skirmish AI. Within three or four minutes of starting a skirmish, you will be attacked from every angle by a constant stream of AI units. It has more money than it possibly could gather in any given time, it sees through the fog of war, and I'm fairly sure it builds faster than human players can. It will spam you incessantly until you're incapable of fighting it, or until you find the single trick that lets you beat that AI or that level. You can't surprise it, you can't beat it by guile or subtlety; you can only win by finding whatever very specific sequence of actions allows you to anticipate and out-spam the AI. By contrast, your own AI units are incredibly stupid; they ignore attacks on themselves or on nearby units unless set to aggressive, at which point they get kited to death. 

No amount of (admittedly hilarious) voice acting or fun individual units compensates for an AI that simply cheats, constantly, to win. Leave games like this in the past where they belong. Don't waste your time or money. If you want a good RTS series, try Total War. Even though the TW AI doubtless cheats, it's at least a little better at disguising it.

[b]Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3[/b] is a Real-Time Strategy set in alternative universe. At the beginning of the game soviet general travels back in time in order to eliminate Einstein, who‚Äôs responsible for a lot of technical advancements of the West. But in doing so, he creates a new force more powerful than the enemies he sought to destroy. The game offers three campaigns, where you can play as Soviets, Alliance or a new addition to the Red Alert series ‚Äì Empire of The Rising Sun. As far as I can tell the only canon campaign is Alliance, the rest are ‚ÄúWhat If?‚Äù scenarios. Each story is pretty much what you‚Äôd expect from a strategy game, but there‚Äôs something special in the way it is told through full-motion video cutscenes and actors are doing their best to create memorable and charismatic characters.

The gameplay differs depending on the fraction you chose. It‚Äôs not just that units have different looks and balanced a bit differently, they even change such basics as base building. For example, Empire cannot create buildings directly, it creates a vehicle that can be unpacked into a building at any place on the map. Alliance and Soviets use more traditional scheme albeit with a small difference. Each unit has a set of abilities that units in other factions don‚Äôt have. It adds a lot to the variety and it‚Äôs always fun to discover new strategies and counters. In my opinion there‚Äôs only one major drawback to the game ‚Äì bland mission design. Most of the time your objective is to destroy an enemy base with no additional conditions that will make it special. I guess the reason for it is that the game was created with a co-op in mind and the AI partner you get, when playing alone, isn‚Äôt very smart.

Moving on to the visuals, it has the same 30 FPS lock as other C&C games, you can remove it using a fan made mod. The graphics themself look pretty good even by today‚Äôs standard, most of it can be attributed to the cartoonish style, that the developers have chosen. The soundtrack is awesome as is usual for [b]Red Alert[/b] series. The acting in cutscenes is great and this time there are actors, that you can recognize from TV shows and movies.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Gameplay is unique for each of the factions
+ Funny story with charismatic characters
+ Awesome soundtrack

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Bland mission design with almost no variety
- Allies AI feels stupider than enemies'

It doesn‚Äôt matter whether you‚Äôre a fan of the series or a newcomer, you will be able to appreciate this game. Just keep in mind, that it‚Äôs probably better not to binge the entire game, because you will probably get bored soon.

Now, I got a special place in my heart for all C&C titles, even the red-headed step-child C&C4. RA3 I find myself coming back to more often than most. Let the humorous A.I co-commander take some of the heat off me. Simplified economy lets me put more focus on demolishing stuff to feel tough. The only way I could feel more zen is if I were baked while playing RA3.

I forgot just how much I disliked Red Alert 3. Which is sad as I'm a massive fan of the original. Albeit Red Alert 2 was heading in this direction this is the one where they actually "jumped the shark". Weaponized dolphins, oversimplified mechanics, and a general art style that is borderline comical. While I know the story has always been tongue-in-cheek the original was still more grounded in both visual style and gameplay. And considering it was released AFTER Command & Conquer 3 it's insanely sad how they intentionally scaled back the game design. How this is held in any high regard must be from those who where too young to have known the original when it came out.

Everything from character design to gameplay mechanics are so silly that I can't not think of this being to Red Alert 1 what Duplo is to Lego. It does have a few QoL improvements of it's time but overall wouldn't recommend to anyone who was a fan of the original. RIP in peace Westwood Studios, you are missed.

With that out of the way, let me just remind you of what you're getting into here - everything about this game is over-the-top - the story, the characters, the artstyle, the units, the actresses' cleavage. Basically, a Red Alert game like any other, maybe except for that last part.

There are three factions to choose from, the Allies, the Soviet Union, and the Empire of the Rising Sun. Don't ask. Okay, you just had to, fine. Einstein invented the time machine, erased Hitler from the timeline. Soviets got ballsy and started WWII instead of Nazi Germany which is now nonexistent. Then Allies kicked their asses twice, and at that point they invented a time machine of their own to kill Einstein. "Wait, that would mean there is Nazi Germany now and-" No, shut up and go defend your refinery from cryocopters.

Behind the nonsense of a story, there is a jewel of RTS design, hands down. Every unit has a secondary attack, meaning more micro options. There are air, land and sea units (every building except barracks and war factory can be built on water), some can freely switch between two or even all three. Every faction is unique to play down to the way they build their bases, each has something different to offer depending on your preferences and they're overall balanced relative to each other. People might tell you that Allies are the best faction which is kind of true but there was a time when they said the same about Empire so whatever. Just play Soviets, they have bears.

I allegedly spent 32 hours completing this game on hard, but the hair on my desk and lines on my face indicate that it was actually 32 years. This an atrocious game that I completed out of spite. Do not touch it. Do. Not. Touch. It.

You don‚Äôt play CnC for the plot, but it‚Äôs awful in RA3. Admittedly you‚Äôre expected to turn your brain off and enjoy big explosions, but you can‚Äôt do either of those things when you‚Äôre left to wonder just how Japan sneak deploys a floating fortress to the North Sea ‚Äì while the Allies and Soviets are fighting in Europe‚Ä¶  
There‚Äôs being camp and ridiculous, and there‚Äôs just dumb. RA3 starts off wacky, and then rapidly becomes plain stupid. 

To support the plot slobbered out by a studio of deranged man-children is an ensemble cast of talent that is brutally abused and subjected to dialogue that makes porn look artistic. Speaking of porn; each of the three campaigns features a female mission handler to provide fanservice for the intellectual adolescent. All which fall in love with your mute insert due to your masterful ability to manipulate the game‚Äôs broken level design or shift-click your faction‚Äôs broken unit until you win (more on that in a minute). If this is kind of thing that gets your rocks off, then you‚Äôre gonna have your mind blown by what you can see online ‚Äì on some sites they even take their clothes off! Imagine that! Don‚Äôt look while your parents are home though.

Aside from the women, I will admit that there a few enjoyable characters in the game. Watching Tim Curry and JK Simmons delivering their godawful lines while struggling not to laugh provides a little bit of solace in the shitfactory of the campaign. The Russian cast were particularly entertaining. That said, you can just look up these clips on YouTube and save yourself the agony of playing. 

Red Alert 3 is allegedly a Real-Time Strategy Game. It‚Äôs definitely Real Time (as is the time you waste playing it) but calling it strategy is generous at the least. Strategy generally indicates planning, concentration and tactical manoeuvring to outwit your opponent. In Red Alert 3, you simply find your faction‚Äôs broken unit and mash your mouse while the words ‚ÄúINSUFFICIENT FUNDS‚Äù scream in your ear. 

There isn‚Äôt a single memorable voice line, and old favourites like ‚ÄúKirov Reporting‚Äù and ‚Äúhigh speed, low drag‚Äù are butchered by a voice cast seemingly rounded up from the alleys behind the studio. Units are either useless (including 90% of the allied roster) or broken. Most units are destroyed seconds into combat are eye-wateringly expensive to replace. The AI knows this full well and takes savage synthetic delight deploying its limitless resources to flood you with OP units. 

Your camera is annoyingly close to the battlefield, even if you manage to amass a moderate army, you‚Äôll quickly lose control of it and be unable to locate it on the tiny tiny tiny minimap. Units have a habit of simply disappearing ‚Äì probably achieving self-awareness and killing themselves. The units that do remain behind all seem to be trained at the Cuckold‚Äôs Academy of Watching Your Wife Get Fucked as they will do nothing but watch enemy units steamroll your base unchecked (even while on aggressive mode). Speaking of the AI has full map vision where you don‚Äôt and will quickly send a surgical strike on a 45 waypoint plan that perfectly slips through your AA corridor to snipe your resource collectors. This gets old fast.

Speaking of resource collection, I have to take a minute to lambast the most pointless features which are resources and power. To get money you build expensive refineries which have to place in specific designated locations that are literally a foot away from mines, to send a resource collector to traverse the tiny distance. Amazingly, this process takes forever; The average American citizen could haul ore faster. For some reason, this was seen as a preferable option to just having a mine building that collected ore for you.  Then, power. The AI has more power than you from fewer reactors. It exists solely to trip you up when the enemy deploy a fourth-dimensional ambush force that cripples your base defences. You don‚Äôt have enough money as it is, and the game forces you to tediously waste it on useless buildings that may as well be pi√±atas for enemy planes.

There are three campaigns, which I did on the co-op mode because I don‚Äôt quite hate myself enough to do them alone. This required downloading third party content, messing with my windows cmd and sacrificing a three horned ram to appease the corpse of Gamespy. All the campaigns suck. Generally, attacking missions are better than defending missions. Most missions can be exploited ‚Äì assumedly because they couldn‚Äôt find enough the money required to keep play-testers in the room. Once you realise this, mercifully the game gets easier which speeds your passage toward playing another game. Half the difficulty comes from the game placing you in completely absurd positions. An example is an escort mission halfway through the Japanese campaign which literally ‚Äì and I am not exaggerating in the slightest - starts with your escort objective suicide running at the enemy. 

The soviet campaign is the most bearable by a slim margin. Once you unlock airpower the regular missions are a case of waiting for your airfields to churn out enough fliers and then you just cannot lose. It had good moments and some truly fucking awful ones. You do get to listen to the best part of the cast chewing the scenery around you and enjoy some good units. Bizarrely the most interesting one (the terror drone) turns up at the very end. Half the missions are write offs, the others have moments of practically Thatcherite brutality (ironic for the reds) following by whimpering as your kirovs get off the ground.

Then the allies. Fuck the allies. Their unit roster is built around synergy, which is perfect because you have the budget for 4 men and a dog because the rest of is spent building powerplants and researching upgrades. By the time you‚Äôre ready, your base is gone. Plus, you have to listen Jenny ‚ÄúVaccines bad‚Äù McCarthy masquerade as Tanya with insufferable voice acting. The difficulty curve is ridiculous. Building takes for ever. You could raise a child with the time it takes you to build a barracks. And when you‚Äôre finished, your units are still worse than both of the other factions. Special mention as well to the Cuba mission which implies that the United States air force is incapable of stopping a fucking. Blimp. Without your help. It has the worst levels alongside the worst units but it‚Äôs only difficult through sheer incompetent design of both the faction and the levels.

Japan isn‚Äôt quite so bad as the allies. It‚Äôs more memorable ‚Äì because for two levels you get a fucking Gundam, but still puts you in stupid situations. In the last level the game literally deletes your entire base and army and gives you 8 units to finish the game ‚Äúbecause reasons‚Äù. You could lose all the progress you made fighting through the level just to have it snatched away from you. Some levels took forever, whereas others were so laughably exploitable they were over before they began. You can also tell the man-children were creaming themselves when they designed a literal schoolgirl as the Japanese Commander unit. There is allegedly an expansion centred solely around her, so if you‚Äôve yet to lose your virginity that‚Äôs one for you. She also has a line on the game‚Äôs wiki about her underwear which tells you a lot about the calibre of people who enjoyed this title. 

No, I didn‚Äôt play the multiplayer. I don‚Äôt want to imagine that there other thinking, feeling, human beings that willingly spend time on this game. 

In short, Red Alert 3 is a textbook example of the unspeakable desecration wrought by a soulless corporate entity like EA. It was shat out to make money on the Command and Conquer name. I suffered this so that you didn‚Äôt have to. Please, do not make my mistake.

I love C&C, and the Red Alert 2 still ranks as one of my favorite computer games of all time.  I never got around to playing RA3 until recently.  What a step down!  Don't get me wrong, I love the campy acting that has always been a cornerstone of the series.  But the idea of a co-commander with each mission is awful.  Either the AI goes hog wild and beats the game for you, or they mess up horribly and have to be constantly saved.  In either case, I would love an option to shut it off all together so that I can enjoy the game.  Why does EA have to do this?  Dead Space 3 had the same issue, with EA shoe-horning in multiplayer to what had always been a single player experience.  At least in DS3, your partner only showed up in cut-scenes and could be ignored otherwise.  Poor execution sinks the experience here.  I wish we could resurrect Westwood Studios from the grave.

Fun game and solid entry into the C&c franchise. Some design choices for me hold this game back from complete greatness. The first being the cartoony art style compared to the rest of the 3d c&c games. Most of the units look like toys versus the more ground in reality world objects (buildings/cars/roads} so they are quite jarring. 2nd problem with the game is its economy. Resources are way too slow in generation even when you have several ore refineries going. Compared to generals and Tiberium wars/KW it takes much longer to generate quick resources. Also hate the fact that there are no resource generating buildings you can build in your base (like generals) so once you are out of ore refineries or oil refineries that's it. Also units are too pricey considering how long they take to build/slow resource generation. 3rd problem I have with the game is the unit durability. Every unit even the Kirov feels like it has the durability of a wet paper towel. Just about everything can be easily destroyed compared to the units in the earlier C&c franchises. If this was not c&c it would be a much more solid RTS comparatively. Still with all its faults Red Alert 3 is Fun and quirky just not a C&c I will go back to often like Generals or Tib wars/KW.

I've been playing the C&C franchise since Dune II, and my favorite sweet spot in the whole series was Red Alert.  This game has its own version of my favorite feature in that game. I'm a skirmish-mode junkie. Almost daily, I'll play a 6-way skirmish in easy mode, just to clear my mind.  It's like doing a crossword, or watching a short episode of your favorite show. Graphics still stand out rather well, but keep in mind it runs at 30 FPS, but I do not think that's an issue in this genre.

This feels a bit like Starcraft where they decided the three factions would operate through different rules, but all that ends up doing on my part is making me much more comfortable playing the USSR, just because they follow the more traditional building rule set. The other ones require a bit of adjustment, and I do not see any advantage to any of it, except the allies being able to spam buildings from the various centres into one location, and the Japanese having units that switch between types.

[*] The Soviet story wise campaign is alright, unfortunately none of the twists are that great, and are rather obvious. But the overall gameplay of the maps is the most fun and consistent.
[*] The Allied story is the best of them all. It‚Äôs rather fun by twisting and even replaying historical events. However, the campaign maps are the weakest, having even unclear objectives and rules at points.

[*] Finally, the Japanese is a mix of both. The story is fine, and ties rather well with the rest, and is the happy story really. The levels are fine, but sometimes you have got to deal the Giant Mech, it‚Äôs a great idea, but ends up so poorly executed that just makes it a chore to move across the map.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a game I have put a lot of hours into. It is one of the first PC games I played when I was young.

One of my uncles introduced it to me at an internet caf√© while on holiday, before lending me a CD copy to install on my own computer. I later got a copy for myself, both a PC version and later a PlayStation 3 version before finally getting it here on Steam.

I played through a bunch of the campaigns to see how it hold up to my memories, and I have to say that it holds up great. The acting is very fun and the actors really ham it up sometimes and seems to have a lot of fun filming the scenes.
The three different factions play quite differently, and require different strategies to complete their objectives. Personally, I am a big fan of the Empire of the Rising Sun faction for their ability to place their structures wherever they want to.

The story, as far as I understand it, continues from the second game where the Allied story seems to be the canonical ending. The Russians, in a desperate bid, uses a time machine, travels back in time, and kills Albert Einstein, changing the future. This allows the Japanese Empire of the Rising Sun to take power for themselves in Asia, making a third faction. You play through three different campaigns, controlling the different factions while trying to take over the world.

I remember playing this with my cousins and having a great time with it. Because of these memories, it makes it really sad that you are unable to play online, since the servers are down.

I would still recommend trying this game, and get it on sale if possible.

STEAM thinks I've played this game for around 17 hours, but oh maaaaannnn if only you knew, STEAM, if only you knew.

I love the C&C franchise and wish more titles were available on STEAM.

I do really like the campaign for this game and would recommend it to anyone that has time to play an rts. The camp live action videos are what really sell the game for me. All the voice actors suit the role of making you feel like a commander; accomplishing objectives for the glory of your faction. 

Where the game falls flat for me is the controls.  

I don't know, maybe I need to watch a tutorial on how to play, but the units were a pain to control. The units  always want to scatter after a move command, rather than clump up. This feels unnatural considering other rts games I played, where units like to gather close as they move forward. Micromanaging these scattered units to consolidate gets tedious and annoying. Control groups aren't really going to help; you are going to have to manage the pathfinding of the units to stick together. The hard rock metal and encouragement from my allies are generally the only things that keep me sane during this painful experience. And it also helps to hear a funny comment from one of my units. 

The other issue is that because certain units are unique, its not always easy to know what the counters are for all the enemy units. You kind of have to experiment in some campaign missions, or look it up on the internet. 

I feel like there should be a tutorial section that lets you learn the hard counters for all the enemy units.
I didn't notice any help menu that would give you quick access to that information either. I've played many rts/tbs games with this kind of help menu feature, when units in a game are unfamiliar and don't have recognizable counters. 

(Yes a flack trooper/javlineer is a hard counter against air, but when you're on a water map where you can't build ground forces, and you load up the ally campaign before the soviets, its not going to be intuitive that you can build static anti-air defenses over water...-_-

Yeah technically its my fault for not completing the Soviet campaign first, but maybe some of us are partial to Ally forces, and others to the Imperial Army. We shouldn't be punished for wanting to play one faction over another. )

Anyway...

If you're looking for a camp ww2 military fantasy game where you beat back time travelling Russians, or a hyper advanced Japanese army controlled by George Takei, then this is an amazing time. Honestly, the cinematics are worth all the pain.

But I'm sorry, I wouldn't be able to tolerate multiplayer for this game. This could just be a result of my lack on knowledge on how to keep units grouped together, but it just seems like a hassle. There are better multiplayer rts games out there. Starcraft and Age of Empires being at the top of the list. Hell, idk if its nostalgia, but I think you would be better of playing RA2 or 1 for multiplayer. 

Controls just feel much better overall in those games.

Still, for the single player experience, I encourage everyone to give this game a chance. Don't get it at full price though, buy it on discount during a steam sale. EA doesn't need your money.

This series has really gone downhill in terms of plot / story. I always thought that the Red Alert spinoff had lots of potential for great story-telling but this game has brought it down to a new low of self-parody. The majority of the budget was spent on hiring "hot scifi women" to do the briefings which outright disgusted me.

Worth $5, if only to try out co-op campaign gameplay.

2021 Edit: My original review was overly harsh and neglected to mention the multiple innovations that this game either introduced or was an early-adopter of. This was one of the first command and conquers with top bar abilities and they're quite fun to learn how to use and master. Every unit also has its own innate activateable ability which adds tons of opportunity for micro. Each faction also has a very unique style of building (For example, I really like Japan's mobile construction cores).

Finally, I will say that this game is worth playing solely to see Tim Curry's performance. You can tell that Tim Curry really had fun while filming for this: "SPAAAAACE!".

Red alert 3 in my opinion is 8.5 game.Worth is on a slight sale if you like the RTS genre or the c&c series.I bought it for 10 euro(50%off) it was well worth it.

The bad: 30fps(SAGE engine) cap!!!fps tied to gamespeed,no "official" multiplayer alive,slight balance issues,obviously no more balance patches(the game got abandoned pretty quickly, it failed at becoming an esport game).Few animations such as trees falling down seem to be sub 30fps.I miss the unit upgrades which tib wars had.I find certain 1 click"free"long coldoown ablities too powerfull such as aoe frezee at lvl 3.

Neutral:
Some ppl can find it TOO cartoony, TOO silly,some ppl might find the women clothing in mission briefing cutsenses as"hot"or "too revealing" depending on personal values/tastes.The game is even LESS serious than previous red alert.Economy is simplified compared to last c&c.
The game wanted to be more "esporty".Pathfinding is okayish,better than last game but much worse compared to starcraft 2.I think economy and unit count tend to be smaller than in tib wars,and each unit has a "special" ability.It is also seem to slightly slower paced than previous c&c,but still kinda fast.

The good:
Graphics still hold up pretty well on max+8xaa,no unit cap,I like the traditional c&c quality cutsenes, intros.The game has npc coop commanders in the campaign,it has "non official" BUT active community on cncnet,ypu can play the campaigns with your friend there.Each unit has 1 ability eg.attack air mode or jam enemy weapon mode,and each of them has use,the default controls are Imo much easier compared to last c&c.

The 3 campaigns are kinda good I've completed them in about 20 hours on hard with npc coop commander.The campaings are MUCH more balanced than tib wars as the balance pathces did not screw up the single player.The naval combat is the best in the series,naval base building is viable too.

Overall,in the end I had many good laughs thanks to the campaigns corny cutsenes and I enjoyed the gameplay,wish the game got more support from EA.

Can't recommend this game enough, I love Command and Conquer, got into the series as a kid with the first one been playing it since and this is by far my favorite. 

Pros - 

Base Building (More like Dawn of War or Starcraft as opposed to Company of Heroes)

CO OP CAMPAIGN - This is by far my favorite part, playing through the story with a friend is great, don't have any? That's fine too, honestly the AI is competent enough to beat medium campaign for you. 

Huge Story mode - Each side has their story told through their own campaign, its either 8-9 missions per team and with 3 each its a nice chunk of play time. 

Dual Unit mode - Each unit has a dual function, for example the terror drones can not only freeze a unit but there main weapon allows them to attack the unit. Allowing you to use one to freeze them while the other kills it unharmed. EVERY unit has  dual mode so you have a lot to work with in your unit composition. 

Cinematic - One thing i felt they always did well on was there live action cinematics, they even have a few big name actors such as George Takei and Tim Curry. The actors really did well making you feel they actually believed in there cause and the outfits were fantastic, really great over all on this part. 

Mixed - 
Cartoony units - If you enjoy the likes of Generals and its more modern appeal this might not be for you, while i personally think its great that i have bears on my team it might not be for every Command & Conquer player. 

Cons - 

Online - While it is realtivly easy to get into the online mode, if you're not very tech savy there may be some hiccups preventing online play at all. While its not needed to play the community is still pretty active so playing with others can be more enjoyable for some but this game is over ten years old. 

Unit Overlap - While the 3 sides do have a wide variety of units to work with some function all to similar or have a secondary that can feel a little lame. Example Migs just head back faster.
I know this is a classic game, but man this franchise probably has the worst RTS mechanics.

I had to pick this up to play it again despite the warnings that it wouldn't work. It seems to work fine! 
It only crashed once while resetting the resolution in the options menu. Just downplay some settings if things get sluggish and restart if it crashes. Seems to work for me anyway.

As for the game itself: pure charm. The actors in the cutscenes, the voices, the designs are just marvelous. On the strategy side it's a little light (although there is a definite tit-for-tat unit balance) but the major focus is satisfying action. Big meaty vehicles, thundering gunfire, scads of troops and tons of explosions. It's just good clean fun all around and challenging if you up the difficulty. The story is great, the soundtrack is one of the best, and the graphics are bright and full of personality.
I liked C&C 4 too but that felt more like an endless war of attrition. This feels more like you can focus on base building and defense in addition to short, sharp incursions into enemy territory with balanced unit variation to take on different tasks and threats.

I am going to start with this because I know it will be a deciding factor for many: the game is capped at 30 FPS. I will give my opinion on it as someone who is used to playing games with triple digit FPS, as it is definitely noticeable, but not to the point that the game is unplayable. With a still camera, the low FPS is not very obvious and only becomes apparent with fast moving units and the shadows they cast. However, when moving the camera, it becomes very obvious and the visuals become quite difficult to focus on. In addition, moving the mouse feels slow and inaccurate relative to other games, and the trails left behind are quite visible. While it is strange for a PC game (even an older one) to be capped at such a low framerate, I do not think it solely should drive away anyone who is otherwise interested.

Red Alert 3 is as classic as an RTS can get, from a seemingly lost era where the only way to victory was by destroying your opponent's forces. With three differing factions, hectic gameplay, base building, and a plethora of units, structures, and abilities, it checks all the boxes of defining characteristics from the golden age of RTS. A full campaign for each faction provides a variety of challenges and a skirmish mode with numerous maps offers unlimited replayability. Both feature selectable AI difficulty, with that of the former being selected on a per mission basis, allowing the player to take on a more challenging version of a mission without having to play the entire campaign at that difficulty.

Visually, the game holds up very well. Despite being an older title, it still rivals to be one of the most graphically impressive games of the genre. It supports 2560x1440 with no problems and a distinct art style makes running the game at this resolution very satisfying. The cut scenes also look fine at this resolution and it is evident that they were filmed with quality hardware. Yes, filmed, as they are live action cut scenes, something quite unique to the genre.

I will admit that I expected the live action cut scenes to be somewhat cheesy, but I was very wrong. All of the actors and actresses put on a stellar performance and the various sets are well-designed and believable. This extends to the unit voice acting as well, which is very well performed. Even after failing a mission multiple times, I would never skip a cut scene, as I enjoyed re-watching them.

While the FPS cap hinders a game that could otherwise be a flagship of the genre, it is not enough to hold back an otherwise amazing game. I will be honest, if I was aware of the FPS cap before playing this game, I would not have bothered installing it. However, that would have resulted in me missing out on a very enjoyable experience. Would the game be better without the cap? Yes. Would I have rather not played the game at all? Absolutely not.

Amazing game! While the economy breaks away from it's predecessors and other games in the C&C franchise it does do a good job with it in a different way. It is quite fast pace and your units will die pretty fast compared to other RTS games so there is less camping which can be hard for new players even against AI. Although once you learn how to be aggressive and how the gameplay works it becomes a lot easier to play and not having to worry about your economy lets you focus more on your units. Speaking of every unit has it's own unique ability that lets it have more options than just to attack your opponent, this makes the game more micro heavy which is good for some people but bad for others. If you don't like the fast pace gameplay I highly recommend that you play Tiberium Wars / Kane's Wrath instead as that is a lot more of a campy game that can ease you into playing this one.

I‚Äôve played hundreds of hours of Red Alert 3 outside of Steam. While I consider Red Alert 2: Yuri‚Äôs Revenge to be the best Red Alert game. Red Alert 3 is a very good sequel and the Uprising expansion was a very fun campaign. The game‚Äôs scale is much smaller than RA2‚Äôs, but it introduces significant, new mechanics that leads to interesting strategies and tactics. The game introduces something like hero abilities from games like League of Legends or Warcraft 3. The game greatly improved naval combat, which I considered a bit lackluster in the predecessors. The co-op design in the game‚Äôs campaign is awesome and something I wish other RTS games implement. The AI is very competent and the game‚Äôs content is vast. The campaigns are well done and there‚Äôs diversity in the factions. Like most of the C&C games, Red Alert 3 has a healthy modding community that provides further content and fun. You‚Äôll find them at ModDB.

RA3 Review, game that did kill C&C Series

After over 10 years, I did decide to write a review, for in my opinion the worst ever created RTS.
Well while its most commonly known C&C was killed with C&C4TT, the mortal wound was RA3.

RA3 is the equivalent to combine Terminator: Dark Fate, ThunderCats Roar and Star Wars: The Last Jedi
A franchise with quite a serious tone and lore, was turned into something cartoony and silly. 

The game itself starts with basically erasing the C&C timeline entirely, presents grafics/units that look like toys/cartoon instead of grim/dark realistic as it was by game just 1 year earlier. With completely broken balance as new introduced Japan faction simply can build anywhere refineries and wins by simply outnumbering its opponents. 

The game is very generic and does miss quite a lot of C&C features like gamespeed controls, shroud, select music tracks, select how many starting units, technology levels and so on. Very bad camera to zoom out to oversee the battlefield, while units are outlined with a very ugly yellow bright borders if you select them. 

The AI is very bad, while they tried to give it some personality, problem is, it did make AI very predictable as it does use same approach and tactics each match. Unlike AI in the game made just 1 year earlier Tiberium Wars, where it did mix differently units and they did attack from different directions,   RA3 AI is going to attack with exactly same units at same locations.


The only redeeming quality it has, are quite a lot of interesting mods on moddb to check out for the game.
But the base game itself, wasnt a speed bump, but a gravestone for the franchise.

It's not nostalgia that bring me back to this game over and over again. The balanced competitive gameplay, great visuals, unique concepts and wonderful game design that made this one of the top tier RTS games really have me chained to it. Hours of hours of single player and mutiplayer never were a waste of time. From a noob to a pro this game never felt less challenging. The strategies you discover can never be the ultimate method of defeating all enemies. You constantly discover new ways of winning while refreshing the old strategies, and those strategies never grow old even to AI enemies. To compliment the gameplay. A well made and immersive soundtrack was implemented differently to all three factions which dynamically changes through the course of a skirmish.

The tone (style) of this game is often criticized upon for being not serious or "true to C&C and Red Alert". In my humble opinion C&C: RA3 was never meant to be a realistic military strategy game. The colorful tone works well with the not so serious story (of Red Alert in general). Due to the tone being more causal compared to other RTSs, the units' and structures' designs are fitting, hilariously charming, and non-generic. All three factions share similarities but one faction never feels the same like the others (due to core gameplay being different). Thus for every factions there are very unique play styles and gameplay experiences. 

I'm writing too much then I ever intended to... If you want an RTS that's fun and challenging then get this game. It's one of the best.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is an ok game. While it's competently put together, and has all the hallmarks you'd expect from a game in the franchise, I think the development team of this game learned all the wrong things from it's predecessors. While the absurd unit designs, goofy voice acting, and live action cutscenes are back in force, they seem cater more to fanservice. The bad kind of fanservice. Softcore porn aside, the game feels very slow, and due to the reimplementation of a map grid system unit movement looks and feels a bit clunky.  Individual unit abilities have been added to the game as well, aping Starcraft in a way that feels slightly off due to the aformentioned slow units. While Red Alert 3 isn't bad per say, it feels like a bad parody of the previous games in its line. My advice: Go back to Red Alert 2.

[h1] The Best of C&C [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

I played this game long ago when games were still coming out on CDs!  While I don't have a lot of time on it here on Steam, I did play it a lot.  It's an over the top RTS with a great, hilarious plot and solid gameplay.  It's good for those old school RTS players.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Not much that I can remember.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I played it more than enough when I had it on CD, so I didn't really have a need to play it anymore.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

Superbly fun game of a stellar RTS franchise. Red Alert 3 has it all.

Pros:
- Clean, crisp visuals that look great even today (2021). Units and buildings are extremely readable, which is a must and very hard to execute properly in an RTS game.
- Unique factions with unique and varied play styles and themes.
- Solid game mechanics and somewhat balanced gameplay.
- The unit quotes and quips give personality to each unit and add an extra layer of readability to them.
- Absolutely bombastic soundtrack.
- Level design is unique and fun in each campaign mission, plus the multiplayer maps are very well thought out.
- Amphibious units and structures add an extra layer of gameplay and make sea-based warfare far less of an afterthought than in Red Alert 2.

Cons:
- Campaign/Story is short and the cinematics are way too cheesy, the oversexualization of certain female characters stood out a little too much for my taste and kind of turned me off on the story. Most of the characters are also a bit too stereotypical and one-dimensional.
- You need a third party app to play multiplayer and I ran into some issues trying to set it up and getting it to properly launch the game.
- Once you get a hang of it, the AI gets very predictable and easy to defeat.

If you're an RTS player, I highly recommend this game!

Best Real Time Strategy Series EVER!!!!

It's weird. When RA3 came out in 2008, I ignored it, but I'm not sure why. The singleplayer campaign is solid, even offering co-op. The moment to moment combat is exciting and creative, with all factions having their own twists on familiar gameplay tropes. It's weird to think that RA3 was panned by fans when it came out, considering it does so much well. It keeps base building, but streamlines it. There is ore collecting, but less micro intensive. Superpowers. Navel combat. It's all there!

Ten years later, I'm glad to have played the game and I would recommend it to others who like Real Time Strategy games.

Red Alert 3 is arguably the most divisive game in the Command & Conquer franchise. One of the main reasons for that is a different (and inferior as many of the game critics claim) system of gathering money (ore in this case) from a stationary ore mine, compared to the traditional way of building as many harvesters as possible and sending them away to increasingly dangerous ore fields. Another issue for some is the focus on unit abilities and micromanaging that can make the game much harder to play.

However, it can be argued that the changes and the experiments that the developers went for in Red Alert 3 make this game stand out not only among other C&C games, but also have a special place among all RTS in general.
While these changes are not all for the best and the game does have some issues (some abilities are way stronger than what they should be), the gameplay feels very dynamic and skill is often the deciding factor on who comes out on top in the multiplayer games. You can really get a lot from your units and the money gathering system actually makes expansions and harassment a very important and rewarding part of the gameplay, giving more options to all kind of players.

Also, the campaigns (that can all be played in Co-op) are a lot of fun and continue the traditional Red Alert theme of being slightly over the top, but being very funny at times. The game is worth buying for those alone (check out the Uprising expansion for more campaigns/challenges).

The biggest issue is that the multiplayer is no longer supported by GameSpy and you need to connect via C&C net, which is run by the very passionate community. But it is not a difficult process and there are multiple guides to help you out.

Overall, I'd say that this game is an easy recommend for me. Having played this when it came out and recently playing it on Steam, Red Alert 3 is still a lot of fun to play even 12 years after its release. The graphics hold up incredibly well and the gameplay is a ton of fun. There is only a handful of other RTS games that hold up better than this one. Stay open-minded, give it a go and you will enjoy this game quite a bit!

I think RA3 is a good and fun game, I would recommend it if you like the C&C/RA series. It slightly changes things in that you have three factions and you also have a "co-commander" you're supposed to work w/. You can do this solo w/ the AI or w/ a friend. Refining ore is simpler in that there are ore mine structures you simple build a refinery in front of and your collectors will collect it, however ore can become "depleted." There are also usually a number of oil refineries you can capture with an engineer.  There are also some well known actors.

However, the game isn‚Äôt always without it‚Äôs issues. There are two guides here on Steam that can help you troubleshoot issues you may come across. One problem I had was getting the game to accept my resolution of 1920x1200. I read online that you can add the numbers in the launch options to force the resolution. So, in my case I had to use the launch option of ‚Äú-1920 -1200.‚Äù Then I was able to go into the game, change whatever settings I wanted and the game would accept them. Then I was able to remove the launch option, because it was no longer necessary to force the resolution. However, I think another solution I read involved editing the resolution in an .ini file for the game. If you have problems with the resolution, you should be able to find the solution with a simple web search. In my experience the game will not run in ‚Äúcompatibility mode‚Äù or as ‚Äúan administrator.‚Äù You may notice that the game takes a bit of time to load, because it is searching for servers that are no longer online. You can resolve this and make the game load quicker, by downloading the ‚ÄúRA3 Quick Loader,‚Äù which you can find simply by searching the web with that phrase. There‚Äôs even a link within the Steam community forum for it. It also gives you options, such as the ability to load mods. However, if you are using mods or Cheat Engine, you may have a problem with the game crashing after about 10 minutes of play. However, there is patch that will increase the game‚Äôs available amount of memory to 4GB. This can be found by searching the web with the term ‚ÄúRA3 4GB patch.‚Äù You want to run the executable and it will open a screen for you to select the file you wish to patch. Navigate to the game‚Äôs Data directory and select the file titled ‚Äúra3_1.12.game‚Äù and that‚Äôs it, it‚Äôs pretty simple and solved the problem for me. You may want to do the same for Uprising, the file is titled ‚Äúra3ep1_1.0.game.‚Äù

You can use a program called Cheat Engine to activate cheats in the game. Upon launching for the first time, it will ask you if you want to do the tutorial, which isn‚Äôt necessary if you‚Äôve already obtained cheat tables someone else created. Opening a table you‚Äôve downloaded and selecting what cheats you want to use is quite simple. The tutorial may help you discover cheats for your games, but I found it to be complicated and it‚Äôs just easier to look for a cheat table someone else has already created. To get cheat tables for RA3 and Uprising, you can do web search for ‚ÄúRA3 cheat engine‚Äù and you‚Äôll find (probably the second link on the list) the table in the link that says ‚ÄúRed Alert 3 ‚Äì Fearless Cheat Engine.‚Äù When you open the link, you may need to scroll down, but the fourth post has links to two files, one for RA3 titled ‚Äúra3_1.12.game.CT‚Äù and another for Uprising titled ‚Äúra3ep1_1.0.game.CT.‚Äù You may want to download these into your ‚ÄúMy Cheat Tables‚Äù directory under your ‚ÄúDocuments‚Äù folder that was created by Cheat Engine. The program may look there for tables and be able to recognize the correct one for the game without you having to open the file manually. Simply open the game, get to the main menu, then Alt-Tab to the desktop, run the Cheat Engine program, click the first icon on the top left directly under ‚ÄúFile‚Äù and it will open a list of processes running on your computer. You‚Äôll want to look for the one (probably near the bottom) that looks like C&C RA3, select it then click ‚ÄúOpen.‚Äù After that click on the second icon in Cheat Engine that looks like a folder, it‚Äôs to the left of the ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù icon and under ‚ÄúEdit.‚Äù You‚Äôll then need to navigate to where you stored the cheat table you downloaded and open that. However, with these tables, I found that the game would automatically detect the right tables and ask if you want to use them, so clicking on the second icon isn‚Äôt necessary if this happens. The big white box at the bottom of the program will be populated with text. Click on the box (to put a red ‚ÄúX‚Äù in it) directly under ‚ÄúActive‚Äù and it will open a list of the available cheats. Then click on the box next to whichever cheat you want to use and that‚Äôs it. Go back to the game and enjoy your cheats! I went through a lot of trouble with this game and what I was trying to do. Since I was able to resolve my issues, I thought I‚Äôd share this info so that someone else won‚Äôt have to go through the trouble of figuring out how to do all of this and make the game stable and waste time like I did.

Welcome to the Micro Management hell!

I have to admit, I was tempted to buy from good looks, marketing and videos.
This game is polished, good looking and cartoonish, but somehow feels awkwardly off. It's the first time i actually requested a refund for a game and deinstalled it right away after 8 hours.

All the Command & Conquer feeling that i had from previous versions: fighting for and maintaining resources, carefully trying out different strategies, thinking ahead and executing quick attacks or crushing your enemy with a huge army etc. is simply wiped away by the urge to quick-rush your enemy - otherwise they'll crush you, your "paper" army and your base defenses like nothing.

Remember that satisfying feeling having secured enough resources, base defenses and units and then slowly running over the enemy?
Well, too bad. This game is pure stress + i had to turn off voice because of the constant blablabla and notifications ALL THE TIME.

Also, i don't care about micro managing that stupid co-op AI or each of my units every second just to have a chance.

No, thank you.

I'll move on to try out C&C Generals now, which looks definitely more like a strategic war game compared to this cartoon-blast of a game.

Compared to earlier releases this is a decidedly mediocre game with lots of unskippable mid-level video cut scenes that really interrupt gameplay. Was enjoyable enough, I guess, but not sure I'll bother to play through again.

Do you like RTS games? Do you like alternate history games? Do you like games that recognize how absurd their story is and run with it?  if your answer to those questions is yes then this is the game for you. The story is good but the main reason to play this game is the skirmish mode. The different difficulties are actually challenging or if you just want to dominate your opponent then easy is great. The three factions have enough differences that one play style for all three wont work. The soviets have great land power. The allies have great Air power. The empire has great sea power. Their building methods are all different so you will need to try them all out and practice to find how to work best with each one. 

On a note completely unrelated to my review itself the Modding community is still alive for this game so if you are wanting more than what the base game provides then the modding community will have plenty of mods for you to try out.

This game is narrowly adequate. 

Pros

1. Exquisite production art. Excellent style. The posters and load screens are the best in the series so far. Similarly the game was not infected by the "current year" disease. All the actors/actresses are aesthetically pleasing and worthy of their own merchandise. (Id buy some of these posters)

2. The games graphics for the time were okay. It kind of hits a sweet spot between Dawn of War 1 and Starcraft II. That‚Äôs what you should expect and that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre going to get. The color coding is good, you‚Äôll never confuse the types, or ownership of the units you see.

3. It'll be very easy for you to raise your army of 100+ units without any lag.

4. It feels like a Red Alert title. Wackey and zaney. It‚Äôs akin in attitude and spirit to an early James Bond film, Lupin the Third or an old Emma Peel Avengers episode.

5. Most of your favorite units are back. A lot of them have little caveats added to them but they are all recognizable and used in the same way. Believe it or not it‚Äôs the Ore miners that are the most changed. Your resource collectors now work in a Blizzard goldmine/mineral style. I appreciate that the mines that are harvested can be depleted, but never truly run dry and you can play as late into a game as you‚Äôd like.

6. The co Commander ai/co op with a friend gimmick is very interesting, playing this campaign in tag team mode is a unique experience in Red Alert. It makes battles a little more improvisional. This mode may very well be the future of the Red Alert franchise.

7. Tim Curry and Oh Mai Takei are awesome.

Cons
1. Virtually Every Single Level is Amphibious! Every Single One! Remember the bridges from Red Alert 2 that would give you a little leverage, give you a few opportunities to play a few levels the way you wanted to? Not here. Similarly a lot of your unit‚Äôs aren‚Äôt the swimming kind! So you'll have to painstakingly transport them from one island to another when it‚Äôs probably just more time efficient to forget them and rebuild your army via new MCV/Expansion. 

2. The Rock Paper scissors balancing feels a little off. If you play as Soviets you have such a crippling absence of Anti Air that I can‚Äôt imagine there'd be a single competitive game against them that doesn't turn into Tanks trying to outrun aircraft in 100 games out of 100 games. In RA2 anti air was their weak spot, not an Achilles heel. Similarly In an effort to speed up game play nothing is quite as tanky as it used to be and garrisoned buildings are not the strategic hard points that they used to be. 

3. Apart from the update to Hell march the soundtrack is entirely forgettable. You will never notice it. 

4. This could just be me. Unit pathing, the way units move, the way they form this weird ultra spaced out non clump, the way selections of multiple units never seem to go to the exact point where you want them to, despite individual units behaving perfectly fine, is super weird. I want to say that something feels borked about attack move. From start to finish the controls always felt like something was just a hair off.

5. The Campaigns feel monstrously short. Level Redundancy in incorporating an amphibious landing into every single map pairs harshly with the fact that you are now fighting two factions rather than just one. As soviets again, as a point of reference, you will counting the tutorial engage the Japanese Empire in four levels? Three and a half?

RA2 only had 12 level campaigns, but what a difference 3 extra levels and some more qualified map makers can make. You‚Äôre going to blaze through the campaign in a day.

 6. The Coop mode that was intended to be played with friends does not appear to function on steam. (This could definitely be a fun rumble game to play with a friend if they fixed it)

7. Epic actors aside, they don‚Äôt have interactions that are quite as clever as the ones in RA1,2 or Yuris Revenge. This is again due almost entirely to the tiny campaigns. Curry and Takei aside you just don‚Äôt spend enough time with the other characters to get a feel for them.


Verdict

This game has virtually all of the things that Red Alert needs. It just needs more girth, more volume and map makers who put more than a few weeks into the job. It only takes one branch of the development team to torpedo the entire effort and it really feels like everyone else did 99 percent of their jobs. I won‚Äôt scuttle the whole game on account of a few slackers but unfortunately the level design does bump the game from an A- to a solid C.

If they wanted to cut corners and have such tiny campaigns but made each of the campaigns interlocking. AE each campaign builds up to a bigger overall story, then at the last level let you decide which of the three factions you wanted to roll with for a unique ending, the biggest of these problems would be solved. It wouldn‚Äôt be in keeping with Red Alert /C&C Tradition but it‚Äôs certainly more desirable than having campaigns the length of a mid 90s shareware.

All things aside, if you are a Red Alert fan this game is worth 5 dollars (That‚Äôs what I paid and I don‚Äôt feel ripped off!) but when it‚Äôs all said and done you‚Äôre going to want to replay Red Alert 2 and/or Yuri‚Äôs Revenge when you‚Äôre done.

Id play a Red Alert 4 if they made one but right now I‚Äôm much more interested on the whereabouts of a Red Alert 2 Remaster!

It's really fun! A worthy successor to Red Alert 2 and maybe my new favorite CNC game.

The Good:
+ An awesome cast that is clearly having fun! (Tim Curry, George Takei, JK Simmons, Kelly Hu, etc.)
+ The game is now based on hard counters, with the exception of maybe three units there aren't any that can shoot at both land and air at the same time. This forces you to make a mixed army instead of just rushing tanks.
+ The campaign missions are mostly really good, with a lot of expanding maps, creative objectives and the occasional backstab.
+ The water looks amazing! Even 12 years later this is the best water I've seen in an RTS and modern hardware can handle it on high without any problems.
+ The music rocks and has a fun surf rock vibe to it.
+ The addition of amphibious and transforming units gives you a lot of ways to move around and a lot of variety in how you attack.
+ Being able to build most base structures on water allows for new ways to make expansions and backup bases. You can still win even without any bases on land.
+ Each unit has a special ability or a transforming ability and they are all handled with the same hotkey. No having to memorize a ton of hotkeys for caster units. It's a near perfect amount of micro.
+ The resources are simplified and very similar to C&C Generals. It forces you to expand but still keeps your focus on the fighting.
+ You can fire bears out of a cannon, which will cause them to parachute down on to enemies! You can then order those bears into water to fight dolphins!

The Bad:
- The campaigns are pretty short at 9 missions each. I wish they were longer since the story feels pretty rushed at the end for all of them.
- No Steam Multiplayer/Co-Op Support, you have to use CNCnet
- The "Right Click" mode is a little weird. It has you confirm with a right click for things like attack move instead of a left click like every other RTS out there.

I need to talk more abstractly and contextually about this game, because there's too much surrounding the game to merely break it down and say "yeah it's okay."

The *other* black sheep of C&C. This one is actually acknowledged to exist, but it's still... weird. The other games might have had a cheesey undertone and RA2 sort of snorted that first line, but everything outside of Yuri's Revenge and RA3 is mostly freaking dark, bordering on political horror in setting, tone and plot.

I think people forget that the first Soviet mission in RA1 literally has a conversation about nerve gas tests and has you wipe out a civilian town with efficiency that would make the Nazis blush, on the orders of Stalin himself. Even the "good guys" were given to war crimes here and there, right up to before this game. And that's without getting into the sheer horror and societal breakdown caused by Tiberium and what it does to wherever it grows and whoever comes into contact with it, along with the religious imagery and ideas that made it into that sub-series.

This game, however, makes you chuckle. It does not take itself seriously at all. This is C&C on drugs, for better or worse, and some of it isn't intentional: EALA was in perpetual crunch mode for 10 years, and this was their last game that was reviewed positively. The edges are a lot rougher than the *excellent* C&C3 that they made *somehow* in 9 months. The rush to get RA3 done and on shelves within a year shows, which gives it a lower budget feeling than even the developers intended, amongst the flashy graphics that still kinda hold up. You can tell that this is a development team that is tired and hate their bosses, despite still having the passion. 

They tried to make naval units more relevant, with many units being able to travel on both land and sea. You can even build most of a base on water if you want. They were trying so hard to innovate, bless them. The thing is, trying to innovate in the late 00s within the gameplay structure of Command & Conquer is never going to work right, and that's ultimately why the series... went to sleep for a bit. They couldn't turn C&C into Starcraft or Dawn of War. It was never the right series to compete with those.

*I* never completed this and I never will, but there is something about it and RA3 deserves attention from any C&C fan, because you might like it, or at least appreciate Tim Curry and George Takei enough to last a few missions like I've done three times over the last 10 years. The gameplay is good (if slightly convoluted) but it just strays too far thematically from what I personally like about C&C games. If you've just come into the series via the Remastered Collection (welcome!) you may enjoy it as well, but don't expect the dark semi-serious tone of those games.

For me, this is where the dream died. RA2 was THE game of my tweens but I could not get into this even back in 2008/9, and it wasn't even a priority launch-day play for me unlike every other game in the franchise apart from the original and C&C4. The day that I got RA2 is an incredibly happy memory for me... but they failed to hype even me, their target audience, up for this game. I was 18 and male. I should have loved this stuff, but the tone was way off. Following, there was a bit of hype for C&C4 after the teaser trailer dropped and then... well... I point you to my C&C4 "review". I don't think this was a case of simply growing up.

PS: The music is good because it mostly consists of RA2 remixes. Everything else has been forgotten.

Red Alert 3 was one of the last good C&C games, aside from Tiberium Wars.

The main attraction is the campaign, which gradually increases in difficulty across 3 campaigns. My main issue with the game is that it was meant to be played online. Every single campaign mission is built around being co-op, which to me is actually downright infuriating because your co-op partner takes half your income. And because the multiplayer servers are down you have no option but to have an AI controlled partner

The problem is that the co-op AI will get steamrolled, and have next to none or even no buildings or units at all. But they still take half of all your income. So your constantly starved for income and can't mount a proper counter-offensive against the super built up enemy bases, so if the enemy AI has 2 mines that's the same income you get if you had 4 mines! This means that even if you have 4 mines you can't beat the AI economy wise, it will build more units than you and be constantly spamming against you.

Aside from that, the game itself is fine. I just wish the campaign got rid of these junk co-op commanders and let me control everything with a full income.

This is a really strong RTS game and a great entry into the series. The controls work well and give a satisfying feeling of being deftly in control of your units. Also the range of units between factions are well varied so successfully make you try a variety of playstyles. The units are generally highly specialised which is very effective at allowing opponents good counter-strategies should a player rely too much on any one unit type. (I've found this to be a real perk as it means a good strategy is rarely to make huge armies of a single unit). The story is simple but engaging enough and the acting within cutscenes is generally excellent for a video game.

Probalby the best RTS game I ever played, played thousands of online games before I got this precious game on steam. Matches are intense from the first second into the game. Great faction difersity, good voice over and smooth gameplay. The rock paper, scissors counter system works well and every unit gots a usefull and unique second ability. You can start out the game with so many different builds and conventual of creative crazy strategies. Gameplay on water is well intergrated and basebuilding and combat on water are as vauluable as on land. The campaign is soldid with fun cutscenes with famous actors. Multiplayer is really where this game shines. you can have an intense 8 minute game or a long fought out battle that can take an hour or more. There are always great stories to be told!

Beware if you want to play this game online (which you should check out!) you need to connect to the fan made servers: https://cnc-online.net/en/
Hopefully in the future CNC will again support this game with their own servers as they are rebooting the series. 

If you want to buy the game, then buy the base game Red Alert 3 and NOT the stand alone expansion Uprising. The expansion is not multiplayer compatible and only adds some unbalanced units and a ton of commander chanllenges and some campaign. Its fun, but not as great as the base game. 

Now go and play this amazing game. See you on the battlefield Commander!

Nostalgia-blinders off:
Neh, don't go into it. MAYBE if you are an old-skool RTS nerd, but the way they 'STREAMLINED' the experience will make you burn out fast. I tend to play one or two matches and bail for a few months at least. 
It didn't age too well on the UI and the shortcuts, but you can adjust them.
Then the major thing in RTS is pathing. It's as terrible as any game from this era. So you will find yourself adjusting pathing for units depending on the terrain. 

So all and all;
If you are nostalgic or want to revisit a classic because you LOVE RTS. go for it, don't pay too much tho! (I got it at like ‚Ç¨5,-)

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#417 out of 612)... it's time for Command and Conquer: Red Alert 3.

I'll be honest: I absolutely adore Red Alert 2, but I was never quite able to get into Red Alert, and I find myself equally unable to get into Red Alert 3. It's a problem of fidelity, I think, as all three games are well-crafted real-time strategy titles with a special affection for cheesy Cold War parody. Where Red Alert was too crude to really spark my imagination, and Red Alert 2 was just right, the heightened "high definition" detail of Red Alert 3 is just too much‚Äîit's makes it too obvious that the FMVs are filmed on very cheap sets with very basic props and costumes.

Which is all a roundabout way of saying Red Alert 3 doesn't quite click with me for reasons I have difficulty articulating. I think a decent analogy might be video, as a large part of Red Alert's appeal is the over-the-top, exaggerated C-movie antics of the live-action FMV cut-scenes. In this framing, the difference between Red Alert 2 and Red Alert 3 is the same as the difference between VHS and Blu-Ray. Some movies look better when you can't see the details‚Äîthe lower fidelity masks the imperfections that would otherwise be laid bare in HD. And in Red Alert 3, all of those imperfections are rendered in perfect clarity.

Of course, it's also entirely possible that the game didn't click with me because of imperceptible differences in tone and style‚ÄîRed Alert 3 being developed by a different studio than the prior games. This is not a Westwood RTS!

Even so, I think Red Alert 3 is a solid game. It doesn't quite draw me in the same say its predecessor did, but I can still appreciate the absurdity of its premise and the competence of its mechanics. What can I say? It's a decent, utterly satisfactory game whose greatest flaw is that it's not the classic its predecessor was. A lesser son of a greater sire and all that.

Here's to Red Alert 4 in some faraway future!

I got this game as part of the decade collection. It is by far one of the worse C&C games. The only one that might be worse is C&C 4 and you can see the C&C 4 elements present in this games development. EA sucked the life out of most of the Red Alert Series. The game play is lack luster and does little to different its self from other strategy games on the market, even is 2008 it was uninspired and bland. The single player story is a let down. While the cut scene's are decent they cross over from B-Movie to terrible SyFy Channel  movie and not in the Sharknado good way but in The Room bad way. The missions are lack luster and way too focused on small team unit constrained missions versus the base building. This eliminates and feeling of scale or grandness that was present in the previous games. The Skirmish maps are based around PVP and fail miserably when you play against AI. This makes re-playability very limited. Also since the support is long gone there are no new maps coming. Overall you are far better off going back to RA2 or other RTS games. This game is the consequence of trying to make a competitive  league driven RTS game while trying to rope in casual fans. As such it doesn't really do either well.

While it's probably not as universally loved as Red Alert 2, its more famous forebear, RA3's pretty good. Personally I think this game's pretty underrated, and might just have the best core gameplay out of any Command and Conquer game. The three factions are each really distinct from each other with a lot of strategies to try, with a lot of hidden depth coming from the ways the various units interact with each other. In addition despite its age and the fact that it's running on an engine that was outdated even back when it came out, the game's visuals have held up well, with some really nice visual effects and terrain, especially on maps with water. It also has a great soundtrack with music by revered C&C veteran Frank Klepacki. 

The campaigns are  very short by series standards, and the story's average at best despite the C&C trademark FMV cutscenes featuring several fairly big name actors, but the missions are fun and fast paced enough to keep you on your toes, with varied maps and objectives. The campaigns were designed to be played in co-op and as such you'll always be partnered with an AI co-commander, which can be offputting as it can sometimes feel like the AI is playing the mission for you. You get used to it though and it's not a huge problem overall, and it has the upside of allowing for some pretty massive battles across the course of the campaign. Unfortunately this was a game that used Gamespy meaning that the official servers for online multiplayer are long dead, although thanks to various third party tools it's still technically possible to play it and this game's online community isn't entirely dead. Even if you don't feel like that you can still play skirmish battles with AI bots, which can be fun enough in its own right even if it's clearly no substitute for a human player. 

Overall it has its problems but it's worth playing on the whole. For its current normal price I'd probably say its worth it, although I can definitely see why people would prefer something a bit lower. Just bear in mind that it doesn't seem to go on sale all that often.
