A quickly paced RTS game. If you enjoy previous C&C titles you'll probably like this.

The game has a lot of charm just like the previous entries. Live action cut-scenes are great. Music is amazing. All around an enjoyable experience. 

I would not consider the game to be well balanced though. Empire is just a little bit too mobile compared to the other factions. Though this game has an unusual skill ceiling. It is definitely more than possible to outplay an evenly matched empire player. The unfairness mostly comes from the transforming units. To get kills on a single type of empire units you often need to make sure you have 2 other unit types to counter them. Empire just doesn't have to worry about that. 

Basically the empire player has a free retreat if the enemy does not have  the right units to counter the transforms. Empire gets free repairs at the mecha bay so this can really add up over a game. It's just a huge advantage to have in an RTS game. In situations where a soviet or allied army would be wiped, often an empire player just transforms. 

Since all of the units have unique abilities that can be activated you get a more dynamic feeling game. Compared to other RTS games, a single unit generally feels like it has more potential if used correctly. 

Now I don't mind a challenge so the balance issues are not that big of a deal for me. Any faction can devastate in the hands of a good player. I enjoy the differences in the factions enough to still recommend this game 100%. I would rather have unique and interesting factions than copy-cats to make the game appear bigger and more complex.

The 3 factions for me:
Soviets: straightforward, easy to play, all around just good
Allies: most potential out of their units, harder to use, turrets
Empire: Most maneuverable units, hit-run tactics, kind of predictable but still annoying
It's just a fun distraction when your bored.

Red Alert 3 feels like a bubblegum version of real-time strategy. It's silly and campy, yes, and it's also fun. The most striking feature of this game is the comical concept it has. I enjoy that the game doesn't try hard to make the whole experience realistic. Rather, it has its perk of being very playful and strategic in the same time. The characters' acting also add on to the comical vibe of the play. 

What I disliked though, is that I couldn't check how many units there were when I selected a group. Having a small indicator would be significantly useful. 

Other than that, I highly recommend this game to those who want to play strategic games that are not too intense. Great job!
I love the campaign mode. Helps you to strategies by yourself or have team effort to beat the enemy.

I remember playing this on the (I think 360) back when it first came out and thought it was a pretty solid game, but having played it again recently... all I can say is "meh". 

It would be an incredibly fun game to play if it wasn't for the *CONSTANT* spamming of super-weapons/abilities by the AI which means you're just being endlessly hounded by annoyances that you can't possibly keep on top of... the trouble is: the AI is able to simultaneously move and adapt it's whole army to your use of special abilities though. This ends up forcing a very tedious and boring playstyle of having to rush the enemy every single game; sometimes without even having to utilise many (if any) special abilities. Frankly... it's boring to play. 

Shame, it could have been pretty fun (the unit special abilities, for example, add a nice dynamic to the game; being able to switch from anti-air to anti-surface units on the fly is kinda cool) but it's all ruined by very boring and unimaginative AI patterns that just spam you endlessly unless you rush them, usually ending every skirmish within 5-10 minutes.

Red Alert 2 is my all time favourite game. The third installment in the series has a lot to live up to, but it was an acceptable attempt. Fun in it's own right. Fast forward 12 years to today and you'll notice the 30 FPS lock which can not be fixed with modding. It gives me an immediate headache while trying to play. As EA used GameSpy servers (that shutdown in 2014) the in-game multiplayer matchmaking no longer works and you'll have to use third party software. These game breaking issues could be fixed with a small update and would cost EA very little. It would fix the game and make them even more money. But this is EA, they didn't care about it in 2014 - why would they care about it now? Westwood - we miss you. <3

I love the "Red Alert" series in general, RA2 was my first C&C game. What I like about RA3 is how we have an ally in every mission during the campaign, something I always wanted to see in C&C, making me feel like I'm not alone and the other Commander are with me doing missions. That "Co-Commander" mode in both singleplayer and Skirmish play is amazing, well at least for me, sad it never returned in "Uprising". What I also like in the story about being time-travel, I love these kind of stories in video games. The "Red Alert" series as whole is based on time-travel, so nothing new for RA3. Playing with those 9 Commanders making the game alive. It's a shame that it's only 6 players max in multiplayer while it used to be 8. Well, personally I still love RA3, I don't know about others.

I remember this being the first C&C game I skipped out on when it came out in 2008. Finally bought it on sale for 5 bucks to try it and it's no surprise that this was the last Red Alert game made. 

The cutscenes do justice to the original campy Red Alert style and the cover art is cool, but the game itself is pretty weak and feels cheap all around. Every unit looks like a McDonald's happy meal toy. EA drove this series into the ground when they took over Westwood, hopefully they do a better job with the remasters of the original C&C games to help breathe some life into an RTS genre that feels like it's dying.

High budget AAA RTS games are very rare at the moment. Red Alert 3 was one of the last ones to get made, and the quality shows in the cinematics and presentation.

RA3 is not the best Command & Conquer game. The harvesters were controversially replaced with resource nodes, which detracts from hit-and-run economy strategies and favours unit spam instead. Otherwise, battles are quick, economies are low effort, and unit relationships are pretty typical post-cold war air, land and navy fare.

Most modern RTS games are made on smaller budgets and often don't include single player content. The single player campaign in RA3 is decent though, and worth it for the price alone.

A fan of the series or not, you owe it to yourself to at least try the game.

I felt like a serious review was needed for this game, since most are either "I hate this, Red Alert 2 is better" or "LoL Tim Curry meme!!!"
This game is likely the best thing EA has made, or is part of an elite group. What's not to love? Graphically, it looks great for 2008, especially the HD cutscenes. The three factions are wacky and rediculous, each made to go with a specific wacky strategy. Each campaign, one for each faction, has an introduction to each faction's units and a funny yet well thought-out story. 
Yes, there is a coop feature, but I never used it. Once, when the service was still up under EA, I tried the coop, and both sides had a unique but well-balanced start.
Back to the cutscenes, they are God's gift to video games. The three faction leaders are well-renowned actors who, luckily, are known for being able to do a not-serious role. George Takei, Tim Curry, and J.K. Simmons all make masterful performances, especially Tim Curry, who is essentially the main character of each story.
Overall, a fantastic game and one worth playing. What are you spending $20 on, Starbucks? Spend it on this.

While not so awfully bad that it's unplayable, the game does have a couple of issues that people used to classic C&C titles or even Red Alert 2 will most likely find to be a deal-breaker. 

The biggest problem this game has - just like Command & Conquer 3 - is that the gameplay is way too hectic, and because of that, even the very first missions have pacing issues. 

In the previous titles, building an army took some time, but you had fewer units able to withstand more punishment and capable of delivering quite a punch. The game had a more "meditative" feel thanks to that peculiarity. 

Here you have the opposite trend: lots of units that don't do much on their own, and have a lacklustre personality partially because of that. You can spend some time building up your forces - which is still considerably less than what you'd have normally spent in the previous chapters - and when you're done, you'll often have a big army and will feel pretty sure it's enough to take on an enemy base, to only see it completely wiped out after just a couple of minutes. What a joke. 

Another strictly related issue is that I am not even at my fourth or fifth mission, and I am already assaulting naval yards, destroying tech centers, and stuff like that. Where is the more linear and slow-paced tech progression we used to have in RA2 or other C&C games? 

The addition of the possibility of playing in co-op mode is interesting, but when not playing with a human ally, you have to play alongside the CPU-controlled AI, whose performance is abysmal to say the least. I think in some missions you share resources, and that only makes it worse. The real problem here is that I just want to be left alone, goddamnit, I don't want any ally, human or not, whom I will have to even minimally assist; why shove this shit down our throats? 
And I still have difficulty understanding what the hell are the harvesters supposed to be mining; in RA2 you had very visible, yellow ore and here...I'm not even sure. 

As of this writing, I have spent around 2 hours playing the game, but I just don't feel like continuing...I probably will, but nothing about it feels particularly compelling. Sure the graphics look good even today, but its overall graphical style is different from what Red Alert 2 had to offer, and I cannot help but vastly prefer the latter. Cannot recommend (to the fans of the classic 2D games).

Yet I can't say I overly love this one but I also don't hate it. OK I'm going to break it into the LIKE and DISLIKE files.

DISLIKES: 
- Unit designs 
'Ok so I know that when it comes to CNC the unit designs are a mix of goofy but also epic and a sprinkle of reality. Yet it just seems the units can be TOO GOOFY. Especially when it came to the Japanese units, the Bullfrog and the Apocalypse Tank. I mainly HATE the bullfrog just for it's goofy launch cannon, somehow just launching War Bears from a cannon isn't as entertaining as playing as the Soviets invading Washington D.C. and destroying the Pentagon with JUST conscripts. Also EA WHAT DID YOU DO THE THE APOCALYPSE TANK' 

-Lost Potential 
'In Command and Conquer RED ALERT 2 you could fight in Washington, New York, Paris, Moscow, London and THOUSANDS OF FUN AND WELL BUILT LOCATIONS. IN CAMPAIGN AND MULTIPLAYER THEY DIDN'T TAKE ANY OF THAT! For instance instead of the South of France for the Second Allies mission why not launch a Operation Overlord styled invasion or fight the Soviets in Paris, a Soviet mission in London or Berlin. SO MUCH POTENTIAL YET AIN'T TAKEN' 

-EMPIRE OF THE RISING...WHY? 
'How does getting rid of Albert Einstein make Japan a technological empire? I forgot that bit in human history when the Japanese Empire DIDN'T rise because of Einstein. Don't try to back this timeline up it's just dumb. Theres NO reason for this WHAT SO EVER it's JUST A WAIST! A COMPLETE AN UTTER WASTE!' 

-New York City's gotten smaller lately? 
'What! ONCE AGAIN SO MUCH POTENTIAL LOST! AND THE LAST MISSION FOR THE SOVIET CAMPAIGN IS AS ENJOYABLE AS A FART IN THE MOUTH!' 

-The paratroopers
'Why is it only the Allies can deploy paratroopers (only in the campaign) and the Soviets (despite the first mission for the Allies where it shows that the Soviets DO clearly have paratrooper potential) and the Japanese (despite the Japanese having advanced technology) don't take advantage of para's' 

-No more snipers

-No more prism tank

And so the Soviet Union's leaders, on the brink of defeat from the oppression of the military might of the Allies, cower behind the walls of the Kremlin in a state where one could assume for them to be in complete disarray. From there, Colonel Cherdenko reveals to General Krukov of a top secret military project that he been put in charge of, introducing (him to) Dr. Zelinsky who was the mind behind the creation of said military project, it being a time-control machine. They get in and strap themselves into the machine against Zelinsky's wishes, directly having been sent to Brussels, 1927 from the coordinates that Cherdenko had given to Zelinsky, a physics conference that Einstein had attended. He'd only recently finish his speech, walking unaware to the backstage only to be met with the unlikely Colonel Cherdenko, having to shake hands which would lead to Einstein becoming disintegrated, ultimately having been removed from the space-time continuum, the reason for the world's atomic bombs to have never been created, and the technological advancement of the Allies practically lagging behind the Soviet Union if it weren't for an external company.

Yes, that is how this game's intro is, much like the first Red Alert game's intro where an influential member of our history would shake hands with one of our cast only to be removed from the timeline, erasing their mark on the world as we know that had lead to an extensive change of history. Red Alert 3 in itself is a game that I believe to be all but bountiful than its predecessor game, Red Alert 2 (Yuri's Revenge, if you'd call an expansion a predecessor game), lacking quite a lot of units that its previous iterations had, an even less serious plot and storyline, and.. well, that's about all that I can complain about. It's somewhat lackluster in content, I believe, but nonetheless, I would still deem this game as one of my favourite Real-Time Strategy games just for the sole reasons such as the game's style of art and design, dialogue, obscure jokes, moddability, and let's not forget the cast of actors like, David Hasselholf becoming the president, [i]then[/i] there's Tim Curry with wanting to go to the moon, quite a lot of questionable, yet enjoyable stuff nonetheless. The gameplay is quite simple and fun, having the majority of functions that any other standard RTS game would have, boasting a special ability system with all of its units which I believe is sort of one of its highlights along with unit pathfinding AI comparable to CoD Ghosts' Fish AI. Red Alert 3, in my opinion, excels at emphasizing on whatever humour it can dish out, most notably the Conscripts of the Soviet Union and a few other units I could care less about, then there's the cutscenes. It's the trademark for every other Command & Conquer game, but I think that Red Alert 3 does it quite well, having the best set of actors, scripts that felt like fanfictions written by cocaine addicts, and the Soviet March or OST in general. There isn't much to say about Red Alert 3 for me, atleast. It isn't all too special by itself.
It's just a cool and good game, an essential RTS, but it isn't worth its price on Steam. Better off getting it on Origin if you don't mind using a different launcher or spending a bit more.

No negatives.

TLDR: I'll recommend, with certain reservations and qualifiers, however... 

Might touch some hardliners' nerves, but I'm just giving my honest take on it:
I'll start off by saying that this is my first C&C:RA title (And the only C&C I've bought since C&C:G/ZH); so, I don't have background on how RA is "supposed" to be (as in how the older games played compared to RA3). I dare say, after 5+ years since Generals, I'd expect graphics that weren't so marred looking that they give you a migraine - on every setting from min-max, on a modern display, BTW-. Generals' polygons and landscapes were crisper and less blurred looking. The water effects, however are MIND-BLOWING by 2008 standards; they nailed that, I usually don't care about how in-game water looks, but dang, it's gorgeous.

Game play-wise, the units are clunky as frig. Who was in charge of the unit mechanics; and how did that not get fixed prior to launch? (Because, you see kids, there was a time when games were actually FINISHED before they were sold to us. Ah, the long lost days of old...) You order a Dreadnought to a location, it tries its dangdest to go THROUGH land. And don't get me started on the gaggle that more than four or five tanks become when you try to mass any force. Next, units won't attack enemies in their LOS, even on aggressive, until they are within "defensive" range anyway. So what's the point? 

Power-wise, virtually every unit (except those blasted Mirage's and their god-like OP-as-all-crap Spectrum cannons) feels nerf'd with even specialized units barely able to destroy their respective specialty targets. In my opinion, after playing all three campaigns and several dozen skirmishes, I rank each factions' usefulness and effectiveness (overall) as follows: 

I. Soviets. They're the only one with truly-useful helicopters and have the most versatile artillery and navy; and an easy-to-expand building construction system.

II. Allies. Their leader powers are the most devastating and they do have the best heavy bombers IMO. Aircraft carriers (which are irritating to be on the receiving end of) are also useful when properly deployed. If you use them, (see below...) they do have the toughest rifle (technically, shotgun in their case) infantry.

III. Empire. Most of their units are jack-of-all-trade transforming machines. They do each job to a mediocre degree at best. The VX is the most effective IMO; the King Oni may as well not exist, most useless "heavy" unit" in the game. I do like the Shogun battleships but the rest of their navy is so-so. Their saving graces are: Good blend of leader powers, most destructive hero (OP, really, but in a way that is fun to play with, or against) and a good heavy turret. The only thing that makes them worthwhile in a match is, of course, the cores' ability to build far outside the range of the con-yard without an expansion unit/building.

Pros:
*Excellent blend of selectable powers AND you can earn ALL of them if you happen to play a match long enough.
*Great water graphics and weapon/explosion effects.
*Good number of skirmish maps.
*Generally good unit active powers/abilities.

Mids:
*Building system is a gift and a curse. While you don't have to wrangle builders, being stuck waiting for one building at a time to crap its way out of the yard is downright frustrating at times. At least your opponent is stuck doing the same. (Crusher Cranes FTW)
*Simple gathering system makes it easy to set up resource collection, however,... (See Cons)
*Semi-decent campaign (with OK cutscenes, with actors you've actually heard of [How did they afford Takei?...]), though some missions are quite a grind; and not much replay value.

Cons:
* Graphics are good in the effects department, but the units and land terrain are not pleasing to the eye and look almost childish, along with being marred-looking as stated above.

* The #1, 100%, undeniable, undisputed world champion of CLUNKY unit controls. Units just bounce and bob and cluster-stuck their way to a given point, even with waypoints to guide them around terrain they should not even travel towards to being with!!!

* The screen is filled with so many "convenient" button clusters that it's well, VERY INCONVENIENT! Plus, you can only drag select a small group units since the cursor stops at each group of buttons! Convenient? Fuzzy Wuzzy wasn't very fuzzy was he?

* No viable source of infinite resources. Oil derricks certainly don't cut it. I know, I know, you should be done before mines run out. But some of us old timers don't always do a balls out rush and actually try to enjoy a match with maxed out civs once in a while.

* Related to the above, resources come in excrutiatingly slowly with no way to speed them up. NONE! (Save the selectable one for Allies, which comes far too late in a match to be useful.) Why no tech to upgrade it? 

* Did I mention the CLUUUUUUUNNNNKKKKYY FREAKING UNIT MECHANICS!?!?!?!?

* Infantry, as always in C&C games, is largely useless (not all Barracks units, mind you, but the standard infantry themselves are a waste of time and resources). Why bother having rifle infantry at all? They can't kill a bloody dolphin! Scummy poachers kill them IRL with .22 rifles......

* Units reaction time and range needs fixing. They just sit there and die even though what's killing them is well within their LOS. 
Ensemble Studios (R.I.P. BEST RTS devs of all time) could have taught EA & Co some valuable lessons in that area.

*Standard infantry should be able to cap Gaia buildings (Nit-picky, perhaps, but $500 engineers should not be required for that.)

* And one last thing: CLUNKY UNIT MOVEMENT MECHANICS WITH SUCH AS DREADNOUGHT SHIPS TRYING TO GO THROUGH LAND AND ALWAYS GETTING STUCK IF NOT BABYSAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Overall I rate it 6/10. I'll still recommend it though, if you catch it on a good sale. It does have its good points and can be fairly fun. The campaign is a one-off, although I'll be playing it through several more times, just for gits and shiggles. I know I'm probably just stuck in the past and am also well aware that it's a different branch of the franchise, but RA3 really doesn't hold a candle to Generals/Zero Hour. I wish they'd get it on Steam, coded for modern OS's of course.

C&C Red Alert 3.

1: Red Alert 3 is the direct sequel to Red Alert 2 however In typical red alert fashion time has once again been altered. this time in such a way that imperial japan never really stopped being imperial after whatever WW2 was in the red alert universe. as such you'll be fighting two different enemy's this time around commander if you chose to fight for the allies RA's equivalent to NATO you'll be fighting the empire of the rising sun and the Soviet union. if you decided to go with the soviet union you'll be battling the Allies and the Empire with but only the most durable of armor comrade, etc.

2: Story wise it's isolated even for being a sequel and some people don't like it. personally i don't mind it i'm not a fan of it however it isn't terrible ether.

3: Gameplay wise it's C&C with a few twists. base building is different compared to RA2 with each faction having there own building style. the allies are confined to the perimeter around there construction yard without the use of prospectors or without moving the MCV, 
the soviets can expand there build radius with there structures similar to RA2 but similar to the allies although the build radius can be expanded with the use of structures or the sputnik unit it can't be altered otherwise without moving the MCV.
Japan is special when it comes to building... the japanese MCV builds "nanocores" a unit that unpacks into a structure on clear land or sea. nanocores aren't constricted to build areas unlike the other two factions but are vastly more vulnerable until deployed.

3.1: Unit's and faction specifics
Each unit has a special ability with the exception of transports which have the "Special ability" of unloading the passengers within them however simply because transports special ability's aren't unique it doesn't mean they aren't special. let's talk about the allied riptide IFV a Infantry Fighting hovercraft armed with just a light machinegun... until it's on water that is. when on water the riptide opens up a set of torpedo tubes allowing it to use explosive and higher damage weapons when traversing any body of water. the soviet bullfrog transport when unloading it's passengers does so by shooting them out of the rear mounted mancannon and para-dropping them allowing infantry to potentially bypass walls or static base defenses. lastly the empire's sudden transport although unarmed can disguise it's self as an enemy vehicle. be careful of scout unit's and the enemy players micro-ing capability's.
3.2: Now onto actual special ability's each unit as stated earlier has a special ability that can hamper enemy forces in some form or another and punish them in some form or another. the allied spy for an example can punish a player's lack of micro capability's by ether A: bribing an entire set of enemy forces and having them convert to your team at the cost of 5000 resources or B: by shutting down some form of structure in the enemy's base temporarily granting you a temporary or in some instances a permanent advantage. however on the opposite end of the spectrum there are some unit's with special ability's that encourage micro-ing like the soviet hammer tank with it's special ability being the ability to tear enemy armor and if said tank gets the kill a weapon right off of an enemy vehicle. if someone micro's said tank well enough you can potentially get a early or possibly mid game advantage.

4: Conclusion
For 20 USD i have to say that unless your a die hard C&C fan who's willing to try something a bit different but still similar to the older C&C games it's not worth it however if you can find it at 15USD or less. go for it. if not for the game it's self but the fun you can get out of it both in vanilla and modded.

The Red Alert series has always managed to mix solid RTS elements with a funny, over-the-top live action story and Red Alert 3 only improved on the previous games. Red Alert 3 also continues to have some surprisingly well known actors in its story line with amusing acting performances, which is the just the icing on the cake. 

Just don't try to take it seriously and enjoy the silliness of giant samurai mechs with laser beam eyes fighting war bears while weaponized dolphins duel tesla coil-armed attack boats. And who could forget the (actually) iconic Kirov Airships or Apocalypse tanks with their meme-worthy voice lines.

The game also still looks good, due to somewhat unique, vibrant graphics that didn't even try to go for realism when the game was new. The game also has a pretty long campaign that's not just a string of tutorials for multiplayer. It also controls just as well as any modern RTS, including convenient commands such as the ever-important attack move.

Of course, don't expect any wild innovative mechanics, as you've probably seen them all already in newer games.

Anyway, if you are bored of the more "mainstream" serious RTS games and don't already own the game, give this classic a try.

A classic game. The C&C: Red Alert series has by far the most unique campaign cinematics and quirky story of any game I've ever played. 

It all starts out with the Soviets on the brink of defeat before one of their scientists goes back in time and alters history, resulting in the new Japanese Empire of the Rising Sun who are keen on world domination. And in this new history, where every female in the military is not only gorgeous but also required to wear skimpy uniforms, you act as the commander who must lead each alliance to victory.

The story itself is not aiming to be well told or particularly memorable, but rather turning up the absurdist humour and sexiness to 11. It peaks in the mission where you must help the Japanese defend Pearl Harbour from an Allied attack because it contains Japan's largest Naval force and cultural history. 

And it would be remiss of me to not to mention the acting cast that have been pulled together contains about 7-8 very well known actors. The game is worth it for this cast alone.

The gameplay itself is decent enough, just typical C&C RTS. Each race has their own unique qualities and each unit also has a single special ability which gives you a bit more to micro. The new race, the Japanese I found to be quite annoying as they are extremely micro intensive. They have a few units which can transform into flying mode or land mode, and you need to constantly switch back and forth during the missions. 

The pathing and attack-move command is what you would expect from a game from this era. Not particularly great. You will need to micro to win battles, even with overwhelming forces. And units will never attack buildings unless specifically told. 

Another annoying aspect to the campaign is that each mission has "bonus objectives". Usually, completing these will give the player some benefit. For example, extra units or resources or technology. However, most of the bonus objectives are unnecessary as they have provide no benefit to the player. This is particularly disappointing in a game like Red Alert because you would expect these bonus objectives to unlock quirky cutscenes and extra humour that the franchise is known for. But really, these bonus objectives are just time wasters.

I only ran into 1-2 serious bugs, which just required reloading the last autosave.

The game has depth, probably more than you can show in a quick 3-4 hour campaign for each race. But well worth it just for the absurdist story, acting, and nostalgia of a gaming classic

Amazing game, has great story and even greater gameplay. I absolutely love this game. 

I love how this game doesn't just focus on land, but you must focus on navy too, and if you don't, then you're screwed. I also like how every troop has its own unique ability, which can either be used to make your unit stronger, making it vonerable for a shorter period of time, or just as a last chance for your unit to survive/defend your base. I love how mcv can go into water, which gives you a chance to actually survive if the enemy dominates the land. The plot is nice, and just like in ra it shows the corruption among the soviets. I recommend this game to everyone who loves strategy games, because it just offers so much. I also like the "research tree" and how it works. I love how I can get some special ability without building anything, and how I gain experiance over time.

Now the part which I don't like. To me, naval gameplay feels forced, because it is in every mission, and good amount of missions you can't actually make vehnicles made for land only because at the start you are on the island. Exept that I don't have any other problems, and I know that this problem may be contradictory because I said how I love that you must build navy, which is true, but I don't like being forced to build my navy absolutely every mission I play.

COMPLETED GAME - Wow!  Awesome game!  It is definitely meant to be played in the order of Soviets first, Allies second and Japan last.  I played on Hard myself and even though some Soviet missions were quite tough, the game seems to get progressively harder in that order. I think C&C Red Alert 3 is a pretty well done game.

+ The factions are quite good balanced (unlike in C&C Generals: ZH whereas the USA had a lot advantages over the other two factions). Firstly I actually thought that Japan is pretty much the strongest of the three factions due to their strong navy and land units. Not to mention their commando Yuriko Omega which is by far the best of the three commandos and is just ridiculously OP. But then I actually noticed that the Japanese are extremely vunerable to aircraft. Their aircraft isn¬¥t that bad but their counter measures against enemy aircraft are kinda...bad. With that fact I think the three factions are all in good balanced.

+ You can choose your own strategy in skirmish mode. You don¬¥t like massive tank battles? No problem! We¬¥re taking them out with our gunships and bombers. What? They¬¥re easy to destroy? Then let¬¥s attack the enemy base with our navy over the sea! You get my point. Since every map has a large sea either in the middle or around the battlefield you can play every strategy you want to. 

+ The actors are very well choosen. They all really fit into their roles considering the optical appearance. I can¬¥t say anything about their acting qualities since I¬¥m playing the German version BUT the voice acting is really great there though. Probably not very helpful for you but I still think it should be mentioned.

+ Great campaign. Sure, it is over the top and sometimes it really gets ridiculous. But I still think it¬¥s very entertaining. No matter how dark the story of a C&C game actually is there always has been a funny extent.

+ I like the skirmish messages of the commanders. This mechanic is also used in games like the Stronghold series and I already liked it there. I like this mechanic becasue it  makes you feel like you¬¥re actually playing against a person and not just an AI. E.g. in C&C Generals ZH you didn¬¥t have this mechanic. You didn¬¥t even see the general¬¥s name in skirmish mode (e.g. Not "Dr. Thrax has been defeated." but "Hard has been defeated.")

+ It is not Command and Conquer 4.

+/- The micromanagement is imo actually entertaining and sometimes challenges the player as the special abilities of your units can sometimes really save your life. But it¬¥s also at some points too much to handle. Players who can¬¥t handle this very well are likely not going to like this mechanic. I mean it already starts with the building system of the Allies or the more confusing building system of the ERS.

+/- You can only get money from the mines. There are no other ways to gain money (unlike in Generals with the chinese hackers e.g.). Due to fast pacing of the game I really don¬¥t know whether do dislike or to simply ignore that fact.

- Infantry is pretty much useless. Seriously, infantry in C&C Generals was more effective against the toxin general than it is here in the entire game. They do way too little damage, are slow, can be easily crushed by tanks and can¬¥t take much damage. At least their damage they¬¥re dealing out should be higher. If you¬¥re not e.g. charging with 271 Imperial Warriors at the enemy base (like I did) then infantry actually never is a real threat. There are only a few good infantry units which include the tesla trooper (this one is actually pretty good), all tier 3 infantry and the commandos.

- I know it is meant to be a joke but at some points the sexualization of the female commanders is just ludicrous. I mean you just have to type "C&C Red Alert 3 chicks" at Google and you get the idea I¬¥m trying to convey. I actually have mainly a problem with the ending cutscene of the Allies and with Natasha. Who in the world would go out in hot pants and a short top at the battlefield? I mean, Tanya e.g. is at least *somewhat* dressed suitable for battlefield and the anime schoolgirl look of Yuriko is just a funny clich√©. All in all that ain¬¥t that much of a problem since it does not damage the gameplay.

- I would have liked to have better counter measures against super weapons. A well defended base can avoid every attempt to destroy the super weapon so in that case you have to build up a huge army to attack the whole base...and this takes time. Maybe too much time. Mostly your doctrine feature + your own super weapon are not enough to destroy an enemy super weapon. 

- Your army is sometimes really strange positioning. Instead of being closer to each other your units are spreading out. Not actually a good plan...usually.

_____
All in all
8/10.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is simply a spectacular game. I grew up with the game on the Xbox 360, and I have many more hours on the console version than I do have on the PC. Nonetheless, it is an amazing game, and one I enjoyed immensely at that. It has 3 factions: The Soviets, the Allies, and the Empire of the Rising Sun. Each of these factions excel at a certain battlefield: The Soviets have the best armor, the Allies have the best air force, and the Empire has the best navy. There are 27 missions, divided up into 3 campaigns. The campaign has a wide variety of characters with their own unique quirks, and they make the campaign extremely enjoyable to play through, and it makes the cutscenes worth watching. The skirmish has a wide diversity of maps, and definitely makes sure you have a new experience of every map, and the co-commanders are unique, allowing you to give specific(albeit not extremely detailed) commands to your AI ally, which can definitely either serve as support for your army, or just as a meat shield to buy time. The game has an extremely great soundtrack to top it off, and the music changes depending on how good or bad you're doing in combat against your foes, and makes it so much more satisfying from coming back from the brink of defeat to complete victory. Definitely one of my favorite RTS games of all time.

My complaint is that it has a lot of bizarre limitations on the units, and it screws up the gameplay. For example, soviet attack helicopters can only attack ground units. They cannot attack other air units. Conversely, soviet fighter jets can attack air units but cannot attack ground units. Why? It seems like shoehorned complexity into the game. I also don't like how apocalypse tanks no longer have AA missiles, so they can't be put into a single attack group. We're forced to have mixed groups of helicopters with migs, apocalypse tanks with AA vehicles, etc. It feels like a micromanagement simulator.

A disappointment for Command & Conquer fans, as EA steers the CnC franchise into the mainstream arcade area. The game looks pretty, the cutscenes are true to the series, but for gameplay I'll stick with older titles.

‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ

The miriad of little abilities, be it a small superweapon you cannot defend against or just that every unit has some micro intensive sh*t to it really shoots this baby in the knee. 

The moment EA took over the cnc games started a decline - this is what happens when you make games for the money and not because you want to play them. They tried to suit newer trends, trends that didn't stay, trends that were popular in OTHER genres. It was already pretty obvious with RA3 but they kept walking, made CnC4 and now even a mobile game. 

Okay, aside from the decline and obvious negative changes from previous titles, this game is still one of the better strategies out there. Which is sad. You do need 3rd party software, cnc online for example (or only that :) to play multiplayer but if you have it, even coop is available for the entire campaign. Which is sort of okay but mostly because it can be so frustrating sometimes that seeing your friend suffer the same way might bring some ease to your pain.
A neutral vote would be nice for this... but I guess downvote would be too much. Ah hell...

TLDR: game is okay, enjoyable, but worse than previous cnc titles. Give it a try when it's free or close :)

A moderately fun game marketed for teenage boys judging by the garmets most females are wearing.

The GUI  is moderately intuitive and easy to learn. Tutorials are to the point and will teach you everything you want to know.
The campaign is reasonably diverse in their openings but ultimately there are only so many roads you can go down of course.

The play styles for each faction are very diverse but this causes a slight disadvantage in many scenarios and some advantages in other situations. Quick paced gameplay that delivers what it promises. Hotbabes in campaign mode, and a Westwood-esc RTS from the remnants of the westwood carcass of EA los angeles.

Alright here we go. To start things nice I will write things that I personally like about this game. Those things are for example great voice lines that I personally enjoy the most, water just looks awesome and units design is quite interesting. 

But for me personally that is about it. I couldn't come with anything nice to say about this game. To be exact whenever someone mention this game, I start to think really negatively. The game is not entertaining at all.

As far as the story goes, It is by the worst I saw a professional company came up with. It takes a lot of stuff from previous 2 games and by far the most original is the Japanese campaign, which makes sense because this nation was never really playable in RA2 or RA1. Whole scenario don't make any sense, only enterteinment is in Soviet campaign and that's the best it will really get.

The A.I. is so unbelievably dumb that I thought of smashing my computer with hammer. The A.I. has 3 "characters" or 3 types of attacks they will use. That means they will go for navy, airforce or ground army. Every nation have it like this and  while it does sound good on paper, It's really dumb idea. Just get scouted, get skype call from your enemy beacuse He must tell you how superior he is and then just build Anti-Air or Anti-ground. You don't really need to care about Navy Generals because the water does not give you any signifacnt advantage over your enemy.

What can I say about balance? It is just so bad that I would cry blood. Look, I get it, Japanese are super-techy with big Laser Tanks and Samurai Robots but this is just horrific. It seems like Japanese for their mobility don't need to sacrifice anything. The counters are just so amazingly bad made, that it is unbelievable. Now you can say that anti-tank troops or cannons should have advantage over their counters (Which I definitely agree), this game takes it to a whole new level.
Anti-Infantry vehicles are getting bonus in damage and protection. It is almost impossible to takeout Javelin trooper with Hammer tank. The damage those tanks do to him is just laughable to say at least.

To end this, I don't really think you should get this game for It's full price. It's boring and badly balanced  something that games should not really be. But that is just my personal opinion you can go play whatever you want, but for me it's no.

I'm an RTS gamer, as many are, and I'm no stranger to the C&C franchise, having grown up with the old titles. However, by some bizarre happenstance, I never had this game until it came up for sale recently, and didn't sit down to really play it until this blizzard snowed me in.

At it's heart, it's got the C&C mechanics from RA2, and some novel ideas and expansions on the original ideas... but the good ends there.

Graphically, the game has aged poorly- it's not unplayably bad, but it definitely looks more like a fan game than an actual C&C installment. Units have these strange, almost jerky idle animations while other graphical effects like particle effects and smoke will appear and dissapear. Not a deal-breaker, but it's a far cry from Generals or some other 3D RTS games released before and since then.

Unit variety is lacking, and has some very serious ballance issues. While the units themselves are creative in their design and function (fighter jets that turn into submarines, for example), the game lacks some good bread and butter fighting units like previous titles have had to fight battles. It feels like an entire army is composed solely of "special" weapons, which wouldn't be too bad if some of them didn't have some rather serious shortcomings. The Japanese are at a serious disadvantage to the Soviets and Allies, and the Allies are generally outclassed by the Soviets. Once you've figured out which spam methods work best, there's no challenge.

Speaking of which, the AI is really clunky. While there are certainly worse AI's out there for a single player skirmish, the RA3 AI is hellbent on taking you out no matter the battle conditions, and it's not afraid to straight up spam you in order to win. This becomes a battle of attrition- the games I played all boiled down to setting up defenses between waves, ultimately boiling down to which faction would run out of resources first- it's not terribly exciting, despite the unit types available.

Finally, there's a lot of specialized controls from previous games that are missing from this game. Perhaps they're under different keys or something, but all the keyboard shortcuts I was hoping to use (the most useful being attack ground) were curiously absent.

All in all, RA3 isn't a bad game. I think the story campaign (or what I've played of it so far) has some merit. That they got Tim Curry and George Takei to play some of the characters is rather impressive, so it may be worth it to some of you for the cutscenes alone. However, RA3 pales in comparison to it's predecessors, and indeed to other RTS games that have come after it. On those grounds, I'd advise you to save your money, and play something more deserving of your time.
has so much potential, good RTS, well design unit mechanic. yet wasted on a EA Games

If you love Command & Conquer, then you should probably go no further than this game.  It's the last in all the series of games that has the heart and soul of the originals.  Great variety from the different factions, fun gameplay, looks great (even as I play in 2018), and the campy over the top video cutscenes are classics.

I've not played a whole lot of C&C but playing what I have did make me feel happy to review this for many reasons.

This game plays like a less serious, slightly more sci fi version of Company of Hereos 2, it shows it's age in terms of how "basic" it can feel in comparison and how fairly simple the mechanics can be, along with how gameplay flows, but this is in no way a bad thing, infact it makes the game an ideal introduction to that genre of RTS gaming as it allows one to pick up the basics without too much hassle or harm. The graphics are fairly dated, but even so, quite nice to appreciate as they have a rough cartoon-aspect which means it's not exactly an eyesore like some games can be. 

The thing which sets this up as a game I will no doubt remember and (I have to admit, I already love it for this despite a few hours in) is the effort they put into the movies. The game uses realworld acting which is fairly typical of something you'd expect out of a B-Class war film, so generals with 200 medals, steorotypical characters (Americans are commie hatin' and usually using witty remarks, brits are brits, Russians speak with all the "Comrade" stuff and Japanese do the whole "Honor" / "Bushido" thing) and of course, whenever women are shown they're babes wearing outfits just showing their frame/boobs (Soviets having the most obvious one, Allies having women usually buttons undone on suits/shirts to show ETC). 

The actors they used aren't exactly lame either, we're talking George Takei and the likes, so pretty well known faces in this which usually get placed into these kind of steorotypical roles, so you can clearly see they're enjoying it and quite immersive in that sense. This is also something which is seen in game when they communicate with you, you'll be greeted with actual recorded footage in your minimap which shows some effort to use the fact they had the actors on hand. The greatest thing about this game is it shows how EA used to be before they got greedy, how they're games were built with love, care, attention and a modicum of silliness which is in your face, but also subtle. 

It's a shame this game no longer has officially supported multiplayer and given how EA is now I can imagine if they decided to remake this game it'd be a bastardised version of Company of Heroes 2 with a ridiculous amount of micro-transactions to ruin this wonderful idea they have. Suffice to say. This game is awesome and I'd be honestly happy to pay triple A prices for.

It's really a mixture, to say the least. I have high standards since I grew up playing C&C Generals/Generals ZH, which was extremely clean-cut, had plenty of options for warfare, and usually ran quite well. From the perspective of skirmishes (custom games against NPC armies with or without teams), it's not too replayable in my opinion. C&C Generals/ZH had such large maps where you could practically create cities upon cities of new bases as long as you could afford to defend them. Apart from naval units, which Generals didn't have, it just can't compete. The queueing for units and buildings with the Allies and the Japanese is just so slow once you've played Generals. Many would disagree, since similar to Soviet construction, you place buildings down and have to wait a few seconds- sure, but at least you could plan more at the same time, which is exactly what you need and can't have in this game. The AI either does poorly or completely dominates due to CPUs outperforming the player based on timing alone. On Generals, the units would gather and pace themselves just as a player would, but with RA3, you have an environment that is overtly obvious in terms of NPC strategy.
Perhaps if Generals were available on Steam, esepcially Zero Hour, people could relate- but I doubt very many people will.
I guess it's a decent game if you don't have any context of C&C Generals, but it simply cannot compete in the slightest.

PLEASE READ THE WHOLE REVIEW. If you really want RA3, consider the following:

As an RTS, it's not a bad game. However, this is primarily NOT the classic Command & Conquer experience, as many fans/purists will tell you. Red Alert 3 came out after EA bought out Westwood Studios, the original masterminds behind C&C, and destroyed them with executive meddling. Also, RA3 came out during that awkward period of time when EA was transitioning their games from Steam over to Origin, so because of that, this is one of the games that exists on both platforms.

I would implore you to check out Red Alert 2 instead, since it's a much better game, although it can only be found on Origin. If you want both RA2 AND RA3, you can buy the C&C Ultimate Collection on Origin for less than the price of RA2/Yuri's Revenge and RA3/Uprising. This will get you both of those plus all of the other C&C games, which is a much better deal. Also keep in mind that since the GameSpy severs shut down RA3 no longer has online multiplayer (though you can still play on LAN).

Red Alert 3  is by far one of the strangest most unique games I've ever played and yet the most confusing. Not confusing in a gameplay or story perspective but from the stance that I enjoyed Red Alert 2 and still sometimes play it but this is so inferior yet oddly enough I enjoy it equally if not more. The plot is odd as it involves the Soviet commanders travelling back in time and stopping Albert Enstein develop tech for the allies that lead them to crush the Soviets and basically treat them how the Soviets treated the Germans in 1945. This creates a plot hole though as in the first Red Alert, Albert Enstein travels back in time to kill Hitler in Vienna to prevent him ever coming to power which allows the Soviets to reach the penultimate position of power against the allies, this ruins time lines as it means that Hitler should now come to power but whatever, apparently not and in this world the Soviets are winning instead of losing, but with the loss of Einstein the allies lose their nuclear tech, losing their advantage in the war, but now a third faction has emerged in the form of the Empire of the Rising Sun which threatens both factions.  I enjoy this campaign incredibly so because it takes logic and reason and throws them out the window and just lets you enjoy the game. There are 3 campaigns depending on who you chose either Allied, Soviet and EotRS. All three campaigns are unique in their own respect and actually differenciate immensely and are not just reskins per mission. In terms of gameplay, the Allies are very contemporary and have tech that's more geared towards pacification and having prototype super weapons, the Soviets are more gritty and industrial and are more aggressive than the allies defensive and the EotRS is clean and futuristic but their units can be ground anti-air one second and bombers the next being very anime inspired (probably why they're my least favourite faction). This game is immensely fun and can as far as I can tell compared to the console version has no unit cap although the amount of ore you get per game is finite, so once you run out, you've got to ensure that army you've built can survive the onslaught of enemies, although you never seem to run out of resources, I've only played one game where it got to that stage, My main complaint with this game is the weird sexualization of it, like don't get me wrong, I like girls and their physical characteristics without getting too overt, but for some reason, they took a camp and vaguely parody like game series and decided to cast ex playboy models as lead actresses which goes as well as you can imagine. Still it's a very well made game, just inferior slightly to previous games and so I give it a 7/10, due to being not as complex or as deep as RA2, and the weird sexualization in the game but other than that it's absolutely fine.

Full review:

Take this with a pinch of salt as I havent actually played red alert 2.

Broadly speaking, the game runs very well. It's smooth, easy to learn, and the factions are very different in both playstyle and asthetic. The soundtrack is simply fantastic and find myself listening to it even while not playing the game(something worth mentioning is the fact that each of the factions has a different style of music, which I will generally go over later). The fact that the developers purposefully avoid a german 'Nazi' faction has put the game in an interesting place where the Japanese faction has arose from all other imperial nations to become a rising power, and it was probably a good choice as I personally feel that a german faction would feel too much like the others in most aspects.The maps are fantastic with a good average mix, some destoyable environments and differing amounts of cover for infantry.

Onto faction specifics:

Soviets:
Construction style - Continuous, in field
Strongest unit types - Ground vehicles
Weakest unit types - Cnfantry
Music - Orchestral/vocal choir
General playstyle - Slow but hard hitting
The sovient campaign is wacky to say the least, with the final level being semi-stealth based. While not the most fun of all the campaigns, it was certainly interesting with some good level design.
Noticable actors:
-Tim Curry (The Clown from Stephen King's it! (1990))
-Ivana Miliƒçeviƒá (Valenka from Casino Royale (2006))
-Peter Stomare (Czernobog from American Gods (2017))

NATO:
Construction style - Built in base then you choose where to place afterwards
Strongest unit types - Naval units
Weakest unit types - Infantry
Music - Rock
general playstyle - Medium speed with a good, well-rounded feel
The aliies/NATO campaign is the weakest of the bunch, but that doesnt mean it isn't good. There is a clear feeling of melancholy in the first mission and it ends on a high note, but generally the other campaigns are better.
Noticable actors:
-JK Simmons (Fletcher from Whiplash(2014))
-Jonathan Pryce (High Sparrow from Game of Thrones (2015-2016))

The Empire of the Rising Sun:
Construction style - Build units that can move and set up anywhere as buildings
Strongest unit types - Infantry
Weakest unit types - Air units
Music - Oriental dubstep-electro
General playstyle - Faster but slightly flimsier
The empire's campaign is by far the most enjoyable and well-designed with a mixture of low-unit-count stealth missions to rampaging through a city as a huge ronin samurai mech, I loved every second.
Noticable actors:
-George Takei (Sulu from the original Star Trek (1966))
-Ron Yuan (Nayan from Marco Polo (2016))

RA3 in a nutshell (from my experience):
- They made an interesting choice to incorporate air-to-air combat and a lot of naval, which really changes the gameplay.
- The Alied and Soviet campaigns are entertaining. I do strongly encourage you to play them with a friend; the coop AI sometimes seems to lack common sense.
- The graphics are not bad, but I don't like the fact that you can't zoom out further. Sometimes I really had problems finding my units.
- I've only played this for the campaign.

I wouldn't bother. this game's from the era where 'everything has to be co-op!' which wouldn't be a problem in itself, but the implimentation isn't the best. Instead of a buddy joining in and controlling half your force, rather, half the army is already divided between you and an AI partner which gets in the way or bugs out on you. If for example, the game has a mission where you get a super unit, there's a good chance the AI will control it and you have to sit on your hands while it follows you around behind your force. I know there's an option to give four basic commands to the AI like 'attack here, hold this position', but the AI might wander off and draw aggro from a mob of dudes you didn't intend to pull.

Cute game, decent polish, campy as the CnC:RA usually is, but the forced 'solo AI co-op' play really hamstrings any fun you could try to have with it. Dawn of War 2 handled co-op play better where a player buddy would just take command of  pre-chosen squads, this game however, doesn't really feel right, no surprise it's at bargain bin prices wherever I look on steam and gray market sites. Shame, could have been a decent popcorn game.

Ah Red Alert 3, while not as goodas RA2 or Yuri's Revenge it seems to still periodicly pull me back in. The campaign is cheesy like the other C&C games just with a lot more Hollywood actors. The three factions here each have their own unique style of tier advancement. Support powers add a bit interesting gameplay, along with the Threat-level bar (the higher it is, the faster your units in combat gain veterency,e.i more damage and self heal). Each unit has a special ability (some are really annoying) and switching between abilities in a timely manner is something that can mean the difference between life and death for your units. One big change from other C&C games (and one I definitely hate) is that the resource element of the game has been dum-downed to a mostly finite system, where as in other C&C games, the resources usually regrow (granted at a slow pace). Despite my main issue with the game, it has mods, which is definitly worth checking out. Overall a still a solid RTS game.

Not recommended as an RA game; but I do recommend it, with reservations, for less diehard RA fans, and for those looking for a more casual RTS experience. RA3 is a huge departure from RA2/RA2MD for both good and bad.

Don't be fooled by my playtime on Steam; I played the retail disc over and over.

Pro:
- Three distinct factions with distinct playstyles. Each faction receives their own campaign, which are satisfying enough.
- Naval combat is greatly expanded compared to the older RA games. Most buildings are amphibious.
- Gorgeous visual effects, especially for anything that happens over water. Modern hardware handles all the realtime lighting and reflections with aplomb and the result is a feast for the eyes.
- Very, very beautiful water indeed. 
- Co-op campaign gameplay. Sometimes the players fight side-by-side while other times they perform completely different duties.
- Each and every unit now comes with a secondary function. These functions either give the units another attack or trasnforms them into something else entirely.
- Unit countering is heavily based on the use of secondary functions, for better or for worse.
- Blatantly overpowered RA2 units return with heavy, if sometimes too heavy, nerfs. 

Con:
- Absolutely HUGE amounts of campiness. I've always thought that the campiness in RA was a side effect of its political satire (President "Dugan" = President Reagan); EA has proven me so, so wrong. 
- Very, VERY overly and unnecessarily sexualized women. Blatant sexual innuendo all over the place. Tanya in RA2 was hot, but a badass kind of hot. Not so in RA3. They're pin-up models. They practically squeeze their cleavage in your face.
- Factions are characters are heavily stereotypical and borderline offensive. The Soviets are pictures as inept baffoons drunk on "World Communism", the Allied are muscleheads screaming "freedom", "justice" and "MURICA", while the Empire of the Rising Sun (Japanese) are a collage of how Anime and other Japanese/Asian culture are perceived by the mainstream West, with giant walking mechas, transforming machines and soldiers wearing cone hats.
- Generally poor unit balancing. The Soviets dominate the ground, the Allies dominate the skies while the Empire dominates the sea. This does force players to use combined arms and those secondary functions more often.
- Cartoonish colour theme. All colours are bright and highly saturated. Unit and structure design is again cartoonish and stereotypical.
- VERY bad AI pathing. See my review of Tiberium Wars.

There are many good things about this in comparison to sc2:

-The base building aspect feels a lot more like a base ,you can only build near you con yard 
so no cannon rush bs. You can add walls to your base even at an early game that also adds to the base concept.

-Factions have unique playstyle and with good scouting you can counter most cheese tactics.

-Feels more micro intensive with things like reverse movement for some of the units
but also because the ai is older much like sc1.

-No building upgrades.

-Units upgrade the more they fight.

-There are structures across the map where you can capture and get bonuses like
self repairing vehicles, health for troopers  etc.

-Default shortcut keys are much more meaninglefull and easy to memorize
for new players though you can customize.

-In sc2 there are ground units and air units , in ra3 there are also water units and you can even 
build structures on it.

I got a great deal on Red Alert 3 along with all the other C&C titles for $17. After playing through a few missions, I feel like it was a total waste of even this small amount of money.

The game doesn't offer anything new beyond what we already saw in RA2 - but somehow, it's not as fun. From the very beginning the missions were uninspired, the only challange apparently being moving units from A to B and then clicking on enemy units to destroy them.

The story is a joke with no attempts to even pretend that it's serious, almost as if it came from a completely different franchise than RA1. Remember playing that first mission in RA1 where Stalin orders you to take out resistance in a village? The entire presentation of the game was so authentic, brutal, and instantly captivating. Instead, RA3 offers us something more akin to a Z-rated flik on the sci-fi channel.

I wish I had read the player reviews before purchasing this game (as well as the entire C&C bundle). I read critic reviews, which of course (mostly) gave glowing reviews. With their propensity to give every random trash game 4/5 stars, the critics have failed the gaming public again.

Avoid this game - if you want to try one of the newer C&C games, try Red Alert 2.

RA3 is graphically a great improvement over RA2 but has limited range of units.
It has a decent singleplayer and skrimish mode too.

EDIT: EA being the greedy pigs they are have shut down the online servers. So no more online multiplayer. You can still play on community servers but it requires additional software. And that program doesn't always work well.

The music is epic. It really makes you feel that you are fighting a war. The music also adatps to your current situation. When you are in middle of fight a rock plays, when you do nothing major it's pop-song and when you are loosing the fight, a sad song plays.

It has a 3 factions, Allies (Americans), Soviets (Russians), Empire of the Rising Sun (Japan). Although they all have their powerfull cards, I would say that it's easiest to win with Soviets. Japs have amazing ships and strong infantry, but they require so much electricity. The amount of reactors you need to build is stupid. And once your power is down the defence turrets switch off and things get very ugly.

Allies have really good variety of airplanes and good laser based defence. The chronoshephe is also useful tech.
Although the tanks are rather weak and infantry is pathetic.

On the other hand Soviets have all around good tanks, strong defence, decent ships and planes. And those ridiculous Air-ships. (Forgot thier name) They are slow but overpowered as fuck. Once the enemy builds a handful of them (8, 16) and you don't have an uber air defence then it's GAME OVER.

This game could be even better then C&C Generals Zero:Hour because of the naval units however it has two mayor flaws.
1st: Is the grid. The grid is just a nuisance. It does nothing but takes away the fun and freedom to build the way you want. Some people say that grid helps them to place their buildings properly. Well if you can't place your buildings without a help then you must have a serious handicap.
2nd: Is the fact that you are reliant on exhaustible resources. Mining is the only way to make money in this game. And once the ore mines run out you can't build/train anymore. You can still mine but only tiny amouts which is enough just to keep yourself alive but not for fighting. Whereas in Generals you can build Black Markets or train hackers to accumulate cash. In addition it proves to be lot more effective than mining.

In the end I would recommend playing but not buying it.

I have way more hours on this game than it shows on my Steam Library. I probably have played about 25 hours on the demo by itself. A good 150 on the PS3 version. Probably about 50 hours on the pc version, and counting. I love this game to bits, partially because it's light-hearted yet serious when necessary. I would recommend to those who would like to get into the RTS genre, as it doesn't require too much micromanagement nor too much thought. Jump into a quick game of skirmish and have a blast for half an hour. The story is okay, as it was interesting enough for me to play through all three campaigns in two days. The soundtrack is one of the biggest selling points, as it cues in music that makes you feel like a badass when you destroy an army of mechas or tanks. The characters are people that you will recognize sometimes, and tend to make you chuckle a bit here and there. The graphics still hold up today, and the attention to the simple idle animations for the troops amazes me to this day.

TL/DR:

Since grade school I have been playing RA2 and Yuri's Revenge. Now RA3 is a full pack action of total war. It gives you the challenge to think what type of attack you will use and what how you will outsmart your oponent. Plus points for allowing mods to be used for custom units and maps.

Get this instead of the Origin version because the latter sucks. Why? MAPS. The Origin version does not support custom maps and WILL NOT recognize if you have one.

The game is great and has the best skirmish AI among the CNC Games. Music is upbeat and great.

Some units may be cartoony especially the Empire or some Soviet units but the gameplay is great enough to detract from the design. Also, this is one of the greater strategy games out there that flawlessly integrate naval, air and land combat.

Last but not the least is balance. The factions are well balanced against each other, -- rock, paper and scissors style.


Really hope EA revives the franchise or pass the torch to other studios.

Oh Westwood Studios, how I miss you... I was a huge fan of the Red Alert series growing up. My father and I would LAN up against bots in the first game, and I spent so many bloody hours on Red Alert 2. I bought Red Alert 3, excited at the possibilities that awaited me on that shiny new disc. And then I started playing... I didn't know why it was 3D, didn't know why it was so damn cartoony - I didn't even know Westwood had been bought out by EA, I thought Westwood had just changed. Even the soundtrack was over the top, to the point of being goofy. The entire game feels more like a straight-to-DVD movie, or more like a mobile game instead being a part of the Red Alert franchise that it's supposedly attached to.

After half a decade had passed, I saw it was on sale on Steam, and decided to give it another chance. As you can see, I'd only gotten about an hour in before I had to turn it off again. It hasn't changed from what I had remembered. Rather, I wasn't misremembering this game. I'd be extremely hard-pressed to recommend this game, even for $20. I'm not quite sure who the intended audiences for. The art direction is childlike and very cartoon-esque, but as far as I can tell, people who enjoy childlike and cartoony things don't seem to like RTS war games. Nor can I see RTS fans going for a game this slow and exaggerated. I believe there are better games out there for both sets of individuals.

Note: My playtime is a result of playing hours of multiplayer when the servers were online, and speedrunning the campaign.

I've seen many a review comparing this game to its predecessor, so take them for what they're worth. I haven't played RA2, so this review is purely on the merits of this game alone. 

So you like RTS games? Well, you will probably like this game.

You like being entertained? This game is probably for you too.

As a gamers game, this is not the most in depth RTS you'll ever play. 

However, as a peice of digital entertainment that you can storm through in a few days then not play again, at the price it is now, I think you'll be pleasantly surprised. 

If you really end up liking the game and want to try your hand at multiplayer, then don't fear, because the community ressurected it with a new tool called CnCOnline that behaves in the same way at the old Gamespy servers. Sure, it's not perfect, but it does the job. Be warned though, due the amount of time that many of the remaining PvP-ers have been playing you might find yourself getting beaten into the ground for a while. They're all pretty good people though, and you'll find them at the gamereplays website organising a tournament (for cash, sometimes) and discussing strategies.

*I am a big fan of Red Alert games ever since I would binge-play Red Alert 1 as a kid, which was on two separate floppy disks for Allied and Soviet campaigns respectively.
*I also really liked Red Alert 2 & Yuri's Revenge, and played them for years and years, offline and online.

*Moving on to Red Alert 3. This game is no where near as nice as the previous game, it has had much less effort put into it, which shows on every aspect, I will highlight a few negatives comapred to the previous games:
-The Campaign is very superficial, always the same scenario, no exiting plot-twists etc - basically the story is lame.
-The game is very simplified. For example, wtf is with the specially allocated slots for the ore-mines, and the fact that ore-mines themselves have been 'simplified'. 
-Unit diversity has also decreased, oh what fun units Yuri's Revenge had. Those Scorched Earth Iraq soldiers, and all of Yuri's mindcontrolling units.
-The comedy aspect of the game is overdone fueling the superficial feeling. The video acting is retarded. Okay, there are some big names such as J.K.Simmons and the High Sparrow from Game of Thrones, but it really is one big joke for them, you can tell.
-There is no feeling of battle, the game is like a comedy legoland game played with toys. (Previous games were much better).
-In battle, depending on difficulty, AI is either literally retarded and does nothing, or is tremendously overpowered and just steamrolls you.

*Anyway I would've wanted to have liked this game after all these years, but I don't. I think its an insult to the Red Alert name.

Ever since this game came out, I've been a huge fan. It's the last command and conquer game that was actually good (because command and conquer 4 was a dissaster and I'm sure we can all agree on that). Gameplay is fun easy to learn and can get really in depth. If you like to micro manage things on an rts this is the game for you, every unit has its own ability, some of them really cool and some of them basic. The campaign is long and will take you a while to beat, they really put a lot of effort into it and the skirmishes against the AI are fun.

Multipalyer - If you want to get into this game for the multiplayer I'm not to sure about that. The servers have been shut down, but I do beleive ther is a mod out the that makes it so you can play against other people. LAN games are also a thing.

Modding - This game has mod support and there are a lot of mods out there for it.

In the end, if you're looking for multiplayer, don't buy this game (unless you dedicate yourself to LAN battles) but if you're looking for a good rts with a lot of in depth strategy, fun challenging AI, and a good campaign, this game is for you.

This game also has some pretty good music, you can tell where they put a lot of effort into the game because it always shows.

Great Game. I am big fan of Command and Conquer games and I have been playing those games for years and I loved them. Even this game is a great.

A decent C&C, not as good as RA2 though there maybe some nostalgia speaking. Personally I mostly preferred RA over Tiberium, but that is mostly a personal choice as there are dedicated fanbases for all three universes (Tiberium/Red Alert/Generals).
But even though I like RA2 better, I cannot deny that there are things RA3 did better, but mostly you can describe it as a number of changes, some good (special abilities for units), some bad (plastic toys and making the japanese commando wear a sailor. goddamn) and that horrible decision considering ressource gathering (changing from open ore fields to ore depots, took a lot of strategy considering harassing and economy out of the game.)
Since Steam doesn't have RA2 you probably won't get it unless you buy it on Origin (recommending the C&C complete collection, ranging from the original C&C to Red Alert 3. There is also THAT GAME WE DO NOT TALK ABOUT on it, so beware as it will be forever a part of your origin account)
This game is great BUT it wont work to play online at all.  There is a workaround for this but its going to be a hassle.  Thumbs DOWN steam.  You sold this game promising online playability.  Lies.

What I liked:
+The three factions are quite different in both their units, and even base building nuances. For example, the Soviet buildings are present on the field while they're under construction, the Allies only place their buildings on the field when they're done, and the Rising Sun build cores that unfold into buildings, allowing multiple buildings to be constructed simultaneously with one construction yard.
+Most buildings can be constructed on water and a lot of units are amphibious.
+Nice cutscenes


What I disliked:
-Changes to resource gathering. Instead of gathering resources from the fields, the ore miners now just drive to a nearby container filled with a limited supply of ore. Aside from the fact that I find this kind of resource gathering to be boring, I also found it more annoying to manage resources. Especially when most ore containers in the single player missions are usually already occupied and/or far away.
-Poor pathfinding at times. For example, in one Allies mission, my units kept getting stuck midway because they decided that they could reach their destination through a cliff, instead of by going through the beach right next to it.
-My units frequently ignored anything that didn't pose an immediate threat (basically, enemy units and defensive structures), unless I specifically ordered them to attack something. So, they could stand in the middle of an enemy base, but won't attack structures like power plants unless I specifically tell them to do so.
-Commander abilities are mostly ineffective

What I'm neutral on:
*Co-comanders sounds like a nice idea, but AI-controlled co-commanders weren't all that helpful in some missions, while official co-op/multiplayer support has been dropped.
*Each unit having special abilities. I never really made much use of them because for some units, they wouldn't always work (especially for dogs and bears), for some units, the special ability is basically just gain a buff or something at the cost of self-inflicting damage over time, and in other cases, it was just too much trouble to micro manage them with not enough benefit to bother.

I'm honestly neutral on this game. It's a nice game on its own, but I didn't enjoy it as much as RA2. Since I'm only given a binary yes/no choice on recommendation, I have to pick that I wouldn't recommend it. The overall feeling of the game just wasn't that impressive.
Tim Curry.

Greetings Everyone!   Today we go back to a classic of the RTS Genre, Command & Conquer:  Red Alert 3; a game that some call the best of the series and for the most part I agree.  However, the real question is:  Does it stand the test of time?  The short answer is, aside from a few small areas, it does!  Even today the mechanics and design holds up for the most part.  I didn‚Äôt find myself massively missing some kind of function or ability, though some of the keybindings are odd (queue commands I‚Äôm looking at you).

Commanding Satire:  The game‚Äôs story revolves around its trademark style; live action characters with silly or somewhat poorly done CG.  This is all kind of tongue in cheek with a hint of taking itself too serious in the name of satire; there are absolutely parts of cringe and I still found myself amused.  There are some scenes and some underlying ‚Äòconcerns‚Äô for some people.  Notably the endings which have the commander being invited by the female characters in some fashion; I don‚Äôt have issue with this but some with more modern issues might have.

Lost in Time:  So there are some issues with the mechanics, many of which are very much hindsight type of problems but there are the typical pathing issues that many old games have but overall not terrible.  In addition; you get some quality of life areas that could be improved upon; namely queuing up things (looking at you Rising Sun Nano-Cores) or abilities (fly here, transform, attack, transform, come back).  For the most part I‚Äôm probably just spoiled by modern games but it does need mentioning.  Another thing that annoys me is the campaigns over abundance of naval missions‚Ä¶except for the Rising Sun ones which I feel I needed more (spoiler they like their boats) but I was a big fan of the unit descriptions and the overall tutorial missions; more games need this.

Glorious History:  I feel this is a game that most people need to play if they are new to the RTS scene and want to know about where the modern games come from.  However, this being a old game there is one serious annoyance and that is co-op.  To begin with co-op doesn‚Äôt exist; even if you had a friend who wanted to play you can‚Äôt the game uses the now gone Gamespy servers and not the steam one.  To make matters worse your AI commander is daft beyond recognition; so many times he was wiped out or down to just a few small buildings and I‚Äôm still sharing resources; or even worse, he‚Äôs just building infantry for what is supposed to be a naval encounter.

Overall:  I like this game; I recommend it to anyone wanting to walk down memory lane or to show a younger player the old days.  If it is on sale; grab it but I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôd recommend paying full price unless you absolutely must have.  But, I waited for a sale, and I encourage you do to the same.  Enjoy!

But how would I recommend this? I will try separating both opinions based on

1) General point of view 

2) Long time fan point of view

For general point of view:
- Worth for co-op play with friends
- 3 faction singleplayer campaigns that‚Äôs worth your time

- Sub-factions that was the staple part of Red Alert series, was completely removed
- ‚ÄúGems‚Äù that was a second resource of Red Alert series, was completely removed
- Some infantry in Red Alert 3 are now less effective against vehicles, not like they used to in RA 2 & 1.
