[h1]8/10[/h1]
[h1]Recommended Purchase[/h1]

[b]If you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up![/b]

[h1]Pros[/h1]

[b]Variety[/b]
In RA:3 there's 3 playable factions,the Allies,The Empire of the Rising Sun,and the Soviets. Each faction has it's own powerful commander-like unit. The allies have Tanya,a demolitions specialist that can one shot most ground infantry and can sneak inside vehicles or buildings to one shot them from the inside with C4.Tanya can also use her special belt to warp back in time to regain lost health.The Reds have Natasha,the greatest sniper in the Soviet Army,and she uses her sniper rifle to line enemies up and shoot through them all at the same time.She can also paint vehicles or buildings with a laser and have a bomber come by and one-shot them. The Empire of the Rising Sun has Yuriko Omega,a badass psychic in a schoolgirl outfit who can use her powers to instantly take a unit out of the fight permanently.She can also use her AoE attack and instantly kill units around her. Every faction has their own unique units and almost all of them are super fun to play around with. The allies have these helicopters that can each freeze one enemy unit and keep them there indefinitly stuck in cryostasis until the helicopter is destroyed.Each faction feels unique and varied and this makes the game incredibly more interesting and fun to play.

[b]FMV[/b]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=521464266
In case you didn't know,before games used incredible CGI cutscences they used FMV (Full Motion Video). These were played with real actors and personally I think they look way better than the cutscenes of today but that's besides the point. The FMV scenes in RA:3 are superbly done and add so much to the atmosphere of the game,making it feel significantly more real. These scenes actually make you understand the characters and the situations better and that helps out the gameplay and the story both.

[b]General Powers[/b]
Each faction has a singleplayer-only set of general powers. These powers can sometimeseffect battles greatly. These powers include things like setting up small bombs as the allies,to calling in drone kamikaze squads as the japanese, or even making it rain satellite debris as the reds. These powers can seriously give you an advantage by ambushing units when they're least expecting it or unveiling a secret group of cloaked units.

[h1]Cons[/h1]

[b]Story[/b]
The story in this game is weird as can be. It involves Russia losing a war with the allies and then going back in time,killing Albert Einstein, and then coming back to a world where the allies are in a stalemate and a new faction of Japanese fanatics has emerged. Seems interesting but it's executed very poorly as the game could have made this work and turned it into something great but instead decided that they would make the game less serious and more funny and silly. The dialogue is so predictable sometimes and at other times the accents of some of the characters begin to fall apart and as you would expect,the game suffers greatly from it.

[b]Missions[/b]
Most of the missions in this game are actually pretty alright but there are a few,about halfway through each campaign where the game shoots up in difficulty. For example,one of the american missions puts you against the army of a rogue president whos incredibly well dug in and you're timed to break right into the middle of it to try and race him to a launch facility.Missions like this are never a good idea to put into and RTS game and much less to have both terrible missions and an insane difficulty spike.

The story:
After the defeat of the Soviet Union Alliance, the desperate leaders of the Soviet Union decided to try out his trump card ‚Äî the time machine. In the end, they fall in the past and successfully eliminate such a person as albert Einstein, thus, not allowing the Alliance to develop technically, but all of a sudden, there is another strong point ‚Äî the Empire of the Rising Sun, which is not going to take any more totalitarian barbarians side, and the democratic capitalists of the West.
Graphics:
Then a lot at a pretty decent level! Sorry, there are no weather effects (rain, snow, fog, etc.) at all locations is always the same‚Äî Sunny weather, there's no such thing as day/night, and where all of this could be used for tactical purposes. It would be much more fun.
The sounds and music:
The sounds and music of a military March with a touch of metal to the mighty anthem of the Soviet Union and the shiny pop singers. There are even a few tracks famous Frank klepacki, who has previously worked on the soundtrack of the old games of the series and showed himself only the good side. Always cheerful, uplifting spirit of the music the game has.
Monologues:
If you long click on units they give an interesting and even amusing phrase: "Should have seen us Vladimir Ilyich!", "Here is the account for electricity!", "In turn, you sons of bitches!", "I'm clean I swear!", etc. With the humor in the game no problem, everything is all comrades, Americans want power, and the Japanese are very spiritual nation. The stereotype of the absurd, and just makes you smile.

Red Alert 3, for the first time in C&C history, featured a full coop campaign for all three factions. The Red Alert Spin-Off of C&C always was my favourite setting and Red Alert 3 didn't receive the critical acclaim and fanbase it actually deserved. The FMV scenes were cheezy as always and George Takeii did a brilliant job just playing himself in a samurai robe.

I have many fond memores for Red Alert and it still plays marvellous today.

Pro-Tip: There is an alternate multiplayer community still very active with the game, even without gamespy it is possible to play online to this day, and although it'll require a little bit of tweaking, the end product runs flawlessly.

Good game from the stand point of an RTS, not as good as the previous C&C games but not terrible. If you play C&C you are already use to the cheesy cutscenes and the cheesy in-game dialog, if not well you will be seeing a lot of it. The Campaign is pretty good, story is alright and makes sense if you have played the previous RA games. The main issue from me is that the game is very unbalanced. The Empire of the Rising Sun is a lot more powerful than the other factions, you just need a little skill. That being said Campaign is short (About 9 hours if you skip the cutscenes and such for all 3 campaigns) and the community is dead as of right now for multiplayer(Well more dead you can find the odd match but your better off playing with friends). Its a great game for its time its just that it has now aged and thus is a little more obsolete then the other RTS' on the market. Buy it but makes sure you have buddies to play it with as Multiplayer is very fun and with a bunch of friends it can get crazy and super fun.

I would give it a solid 6.5/10 and here is why it looses points.

0.5 off for the cheesy in game dialog, which is often misleading and can lead inexperienced players to ruin a campaign game
3 off for the game inbalance as The Empire is just rediculously powerful with all of its multi-units(Good against two types of units just by clicking a button) and their build and weapon power.
1 off for the lack of a strong multiplayer base and reliance on playing with friends(Not always bad but not everyone has friends who want to buy a game to only play it a few hours a week or less)

The campaign missions can be a little annoying, with your only mobile AA either flimsy as hell (infantry or light vehicle) or needing to reload (jets).  This can (and sometimes must) be exploited in taking out your enemy.  But they give you all these fantastic tanks to use, and any time you bring them to bear, your force gets swarmed by anti-surface air units who target your anti-air first, then just take a big dump on your tanks.  

That being said - as long as you don't have a deep longing to use big-ass tanks most of the time, the gameplay is solid and many approaches are available to assault your objectives.  Surprisingly effective and pretty fun: Javelin swarm as allies.  Just an army of brothas with rocket launchers calling your "coach".

A good RTS in all regards, in my opinion, but lets go over it step by step.

There are three factions available, all with their own unique play style, and sets of weaknesses and strengths. Compared to Red Alert 2, the differences are more stark, and it goes from units to base-building styles. In addition to that, every faction has 3 different AI's, with their own play-styles.

If you're looking for a "serious" RTS, I'd suggest looking elsewhere, but RA3 is quite light hearted and cheesy(in an appealing kind of way), especially when it comes to acting and outfits in the campaign videos. Overall, it creates a feeling of a B grade movie from the mid 2000's, again, in a good way.

As for issues, I would say that the balance is a little off, and the Empire gets slightly preferntial treatment, compared to the classic Soviets and Allies, but it's quite easily circumvented, as the effectiveness of your chosen faction is dictated by your own skill, and knowledge of each unit's strengths and weaknesses.

If you're looking for a fun, light-hearted RTS that doesn't take itself all to seriously, flavor-wise, but at it's core, is a well made game with different levels of depth, go right ahead, buy it, you won't regret it.

It's a good game, but has it's flaws. There's practically no defense against special abilities and they can destroy your entire base in one good knock out blow. Some of the mechanics are a little irritating. Overall it's pretty good though, and satisfying to play.

[h1]C&C: Red Alert 3[/h1]

- Solid gameplay

- Live action sutscenes can be cheesey, with hints of casual racism and sexism, but honestly one of the reasons C&C is a nostalgic and well remembered title.

- Although there is an unified arc to each scenario each ending is unique  meaning you dont have to complete campaigns in any order, However I would recommend starting at the Soviets if you are new to the game and its mechanics.

[h1]In conclusion,[/h1]

It's one of the games you wish you could have a "Meh" button to click in order to express how you feel about the game.

Don't be mistaken, it is a solid game. When you carry the Command & Conquer franchise, however,  the expectations are different.

This franchise was one of the leading names in real-time strategy and held strong for a few years despite having major opponents on the market such as Total Annihilation, Age of Empires and, last but certainly not least, Starcraft. Then came Electronic Arts and their desire to expand. They wanted quality brand names quick and easy to augment their grasp on the video game world and it turned out whoever was in charge of Virgin Interactive at the time thought it would be a good idea to help them in their quest by selling them Westwood Studios, the guys who made the Command & Conquer franchise famous worldwide. Now, I wasn't part of Westwood and the same probably goes for whoever reads this, but it does seem Westwood wasn't the same as soon as it became part of EA. This would be one of the many examples of how big video game corporation somehow often find a way to destroy a great studio and/or franchise. When EA decided to effectively terminate Westwood, it had nothing to do with the Westwood of the old days. As a matter of fact, apparently, not even a single pre-EA Westwood employee was remaining.

But enough for the history lesson, let's talk about the game.

In the previous Red Alert games, the game would have you focus on collecting ressources. In this one, it rather emphasizes on unit control and practically abandons the mining dynamic. In the older games, your collectors would travel across the map in order to get the minerals. In RA3, the mines are inside your base area. That means you'll probably always collect your minerals no matter what happens on the battlefield. This downgrades the game right from the start. Because of this, there is a profound strategic element that is taken away from the game. In most RTS game, ressource collecting is crucial and therefore you have to act quickly in order to collect as much as possible. Now, you barely have to think about ressources. Even worse: collectors don't bring as much ressources as they used to. You will more than often find yourself lacking the sufficient funds needed to actually do something on the battlefield. It's obvious that this was done because the team behind RA3 thought it would be a good idea to slow down the game a little so that it would be easier for newcomers. Big mistake.

Red Alert 3 wouldn't be part of the series if not for the over-the-top units. They are relatively well-balanced in most cases. Unfortunately, since the game is built on slower ore mining, you won't be able to produce many units and send an entire platoon towards the battle unless you camp for an extended period of time. You'll often find yourself rolling your thumbs, waiting for that soldier, tank, ship or plane to come out of the building.

There are many units taken from the previous Red Alerts and you sometimes feel like the creative minds behind this third opus got lazy. If you were familiar with the franchise, you quickly notice that the whole game is even more colorful and wacky than before. Clearly, they also were told to reduce violence and to appeal to a younger audience. Turns out the game ends up being extremely cartoony even for a Red Alert game.

There's also, like all the other Command & Conquer games, a huge amount of cinematics with real actors. And there are a lot of well-known names there. You wonder how much money was spent on the game versus the casting for the cinematics!

Solo campaigns are relatively entertaining. There are scripted events which can be frustrating. For example, you will build a base according to the current enemy's location. Some time later, the map expands and another enemy pops out from an area you weren't expecting to exist. I mean, you're a commander and the fate of the world is in your hands. Can't you get your intel team to give you the bigger map right away?

The AI is not very smart. In campaigns, it will participate in scripted events by doing scripted unit movements. Other times, it will just send predictable "squad" attacks that you will, the vast majority of times, crush easily. Sometimes I wonder if the "hard" difficulty simply means that the AI gets more minerals than usual and thus can produce more units. Personally, I never saw a "change of behavior" from the AI besides seeing it sending more units faster. For example, they don't seem to target specific buildings in your base like a normal human player would do. If I saw a player with a lot of turrets, I'd target the power plants and so on... But the AI doesn't do that. So, yeah, the AI is dumb. Of course, the same can be said for the skirmish game mode with one or multiple AIs, but then again, the computer has never been very good at Command & Conquer and the same can be said for other RTS games anyway. It's no big deal although you'd expect that - when it was released - they would've found a way to make it more challenging and less mechanical. Too bad that the online multiplayer part of the game - where you could get real challenge - is dead, but I guess that, somewhere out there, there's a community of Red Alert fans who managed to solve that problem.

Overall, even though I've been mostly negative, the game is good. Not great. Good. It's not as satisfying as Red Alert 1 and 2, but it still, somehow, holds the flag despite being the worst of the franchise. There are worst RTS games out there, trust me.

On a side note, I've always prefered the Soviets ( I always enjoyed their dirty, in-your-face attitude, weaponry and buildings ) but I must admit that the Allies have the best girls once again... Why, God, why? Maybe I should use a time machine too to fix this issue... Or maybe I could go and shake hands with the EA CEO. ;)

I've been playing the Red Alert Franchise ever since I was in my adolescent years. RA2 was immense fun, and after buying this game, it was disappointing at first. As a long time red alert fan i was expecting more from this title, as it had big boots to fill following red alert 2.
Its a solid enough game in its own right, albeit it feels stripped down and more simplistic lacking depth of the previous games. That said ive enjoyed playing through the campaign and having skirmishes.
The lack of online since its services were shut down is a minus, and the ai of both enemy and friendly commanders is pretty much useless. if you can look past these negatives though you will find a decent if flawed experience that has enough of the old games to reignite nostalgia of your childhood games and  be worthy of a purchase.

Red Alert 3 is a decent, yet confused real time strategy game.  

Good:  
1. I love that you have proper movies in between missions, even though the acting is over the top.  It fits fantastically with the less than realistic game.  The game is worth playing just for the videos. 
2. Interesting units. Land, air and sea.
3. Good balance between factions. 

Bad: 
4. Every unit has one, and only one, special ability. It works better if some units have no special abilities and others are spell casters with lots of abilities. 
5. The game is confused.  Red Alert and Red Alert 2 were amazing old style slow strategy games.  Those games were all about careful resource management - not unit management. RA3 tries to find a middle ground to a faster pace and more focus on unit management.  As result it falls in between, succeeding at neither style. 

Ugly:
6. the psychic Japanese girl never features in any video. 

O how I which Steam would give as Red Alert and Red Alert 2.

I remember my first game of Red Alert. It was in RA2 and I was the South Koreans. I got completely crushed by the Soviets. Something about how diverse all the troops were made me want to keep going and unlock their true potential. I practiced RA2 and the Yuri's Revenge expansion pack until I became a master, able to take on 2 brutals at once.

One day, EA published RA3. I was so excited when I saw what it had to offer. I got the disk version and started right away. I was overwhelmed by all the new changes, like amphibious buildings and secondary abilities. It felt like I was that complete noob again.

A couple years later, I retook my master's status here and mained Empire of the Rising Sun. I then bought the Steam version recently during a sale so my Steam friends can see that I play games other than TF2. This game is so visually and auditorily amazing, and it is probably one of the most balanced RTS's I've ever played. I enjoyed the campaign thoroughly and find that all of the maps are very balanced. 

TL,DR: 10/10 would get rekt by army of century bombers again.

Isn't as addictively fun as Red Alert 2 and Yuri's Revenge, but, you know what? It's still fun, and it's different enough from other CnC games (in a good way, unlike CnC 4) to stand out on it's own. Like, there's a pretty interesting balance between naval and ground combat that doesn't make either feel like an afterthought, and the campaigns, while campy with pointless fanservice and mindnumbing writing, offer diverse scenarios.

Now, one thing I really hate, it has lots of unnecesseary micro. Not only is the game full of hard counters so you have to order around units so they wouldn't get owned by their counters while concentrating their fire onto weakest targets, pretty much every unit has it's own gimmick special, be it a special attack or alternative fire mode, so the amount of unnecesseary micro is unberable. Red Alert 2 kept it way more simple, and if unit had several firing modes you wouldn't need to switch between them, meanwhile here it's not even Starcraft or CoH levels of micro. Worst offender is the new third faction, Empire of the Rising Sun. They have probably the most of alternative modes due to sizeable chunk of their force being transformers like a machinegun mecha that switches into a fighter and such, and you can't switch back for some time like you get with, say, Starcraft 2 vikings, so it's rather annoying.

Westwood's legendary C&C franchise hit it's high point with this one, beginning just before the climax of Red Alert 2 the Soviets rewrite history by going back in time and eliminating Einstein (oh the anvil of irony) in order to remove the Allies' technological advantage but, in the process, birth a new superpower, the Empire of the Rising Sun, and thu the War of the Three Powers begins with a japanese invasion of the USSR.

Gampelay wise this is pretty much the same Red Alert goodness but with the extra unit/superweapon powers added to C&C3. The Red Alert series has always added more emphasis on Air/Naval power so they took the next logical step and added seaborne bases as well was making a number of units amphibious (Empire probably wins on that score with the amphibious tank though) but C&C is one of the few game series that believed in "If it ain't broke..." (at least until they did break everything in C&C4...) and Red Alert 3, for my money is the best in the franchise. However Gameplay is largely irrelevant here, the true value in this game lies in it's story and cast. It's as cheesy and stupid as hell as the previous C&C games but that is what makes this series so damn good, especially since Red Alert's lighter tone compared to the gloomy post-apocalyptic Tiberum series allows for what can only be described as bacon-ribs levels of ham acting and it is glorious and what better way to highlight the magnificence of this than getting Tim Curry to be your villain for the evening, this man and J.K. Simmons actively compete to see who can devour the most scenery as the Soviet Premier and U.S. President respectively whilst George Takei provides a subtle but still pretty cheesy performace as the Emperor of Japan. Add to this Johnathan Pryce's slightly bewildered Supreme Allied Commander and Randy Coture and you've got yourself the best cast in C&C history. 

If you want a game thats just sheer pleasure and over-the-top fun but still retains a tried-and-true formula that worked right up until EA screwed it up to bury the franchise to concentrate on ten thousand unecessary sports titles then this is the game for you. 

Oh, and one thing... Man-Cannons... that is all.

Since EA took over westwood the quaility of the C&C series has been on a decline and this is another example of a game made bad. it feels like EA is milking the money cow, starting the game with a time travelling story copied from RA1 with a slight twist where there is a new enemy in the form of the japanese. This combined with over the top cheesy dialogue and bad acting makes almost every moment of RA3 cringeworthy. while cheesy and bad acting is staple of the C&C series its used sparingly, the developers decided to take it a notch up and put it everywhere. pair this with bad taste (the japanese defending pearl harbour from the allies) one just cant help but question the idea behind the game.

Gameplay mechanics have been changed a bit, now instead of having harvesters going for ore, we have deposits where we can build refineries right beside it. our harvesters need only move a very short distance, which totally eliminates the old strategy of economic harassing. the game economics has moved towards something like dawn of war where its critinal to capture "strategic points" to ensure a large economy. 

the factions are now full of "over the top units", allies have helis that shrink vehicles, soviets have cannons that shoot "cannonball men" (paratroopers) and the japs are full of stuff copied from animes (mechas and teenage girls). to some it might feel cartoonish but it can be a matter of tastes.

the biggest drawback to the game play i guess it the "forced" co-op and the wildly spiking difficulty levels of the single player campaign. you must play with a computer beside you, which sometimes the ally computer player totally decimates everything on the map leaving you to attack the enemy base with 5 tanks and win. other times it cant hold its own leaving you to baby it, which spoils the game.

the spiking difficulty is also another that spoils the whole experience, while i do understand that games use cheats to provide some degree of difficulty to the player. i found this to be used too often, even in medium the AI has almost unlimited resources and almost instant production capabilities. pair this with the uneven difficulty across the campaign, you'd quickly have certain missions where its near impossible to pass and those that are almost not impossibel to lose, right after each other.

all in all, i felt that RA3 was cheap idea of generating some revenue. it has nothing about "gaming" to it and more on selling the brand which is RA. some might like the over the top stuff or the new revamped economics system, but i dont i heard that multiplayer is good but i have not tried it yet. for now considering what i have been through i give it a 4/10

I played RA3 for about 4 years on and off, Its a solid and well polished RTS, by biggests cristisms are that the online servers got killed off when Gamespy went under and EA did nothing to replace them,
Another minor issue, this game has a problem when running duel or mutiple monitors, your mouse cursor wonders off on to the inactive display, so you have to unplug your second or addtional monitors which is a pain in the rear.

Common invalid complaints about this game are: 
a) 'its too 'cartoony' but that trend was really started by RA2.

b) 'RA2 YR was better ' No it wasn't it was a laugh, but the balance in the RA2 YR was freaking awful,  it became a one faction joke of an RTS in multiplayer, Everyone just played as Allies, because Soviets were usless if you didnt rush in the first 5 mins, and playing as Yuri was just 'cheap' no strategy needed, just steal all the enermy units or boomer rush. In RA3 all 3 factions are very well balanced indeed. And you cannot spam your way to victory with only one unit type.

c) 'too much micro managment' - Basically translates as 'the game is too hard for me.'

RA3 was the last good C&C game to come out of EA LA, highly recomended if you can live without multiplayer out of the box.

This game is known moreso for its soundtrack than its gameplay, but that said it isn't a bad game in the slightest, taking key elements from its predecessors; certain rich plot points, and the top-down realtime strategy aspects. But none of that interested me.

What interested me most was Tim Curry as the big bad Russian Premier Cherdenko... It's Tim fucking Curry!

Gameplay:
Red alert 3 oversees an interesing  transition from RA2, incorporating numerous alternations to the gameplay that allows the game to be more tense as the designs shift more to what you will see in a serios RTS-- most prominently, ore becomes a confined resource which cannot be harvested exponentially by cramming your build order with harvesters. Units can be categorized into anti-infantry and anti-armor. Main battle tanks may be terrifyingly effective against armor yet at the same time they require five to six shots to kill some of the most cheapest infanty, which indeed is hard to grasp at first. As such, attacks emphasize on the cooperation of different units spamming only one type of unit would not bring you anywere. Micromanaging becomes vital through the concept of 'crushing levels' where infantry are subject to be crushed by incoming tanks while tanks are subject to be flattened by even bigger vehicles. Several secondary abilities and attack formations of the different factions also heavily rely on micromanaging.

The single player campaign is also incredibly entertaining. I loved the cutscenes shot in real person. The humorous plot is mildly funny and worth a laugh.

Graphics:
Absolutely brilliant special effects with breathtakingly beautiful water. Personally I prefer the rather vibrant hue in RA3 instead of  other CNC games or Starcraft. Antialiasing options lags the computer more than smoothing out the edges, however the game does not suffer from antialiasing issues much even without AA turned on.

Annoying bugs:
The pathfinding system is a total mess.
Sometimes units would take a full round trip around the building it just came out of before heading anywhere else.
Units getting stuck on the road for no reason.
Highly expensive naval fleet would randomly be stuck on the shoreline, becoming virtually worthless.
Units would line up and move single-filed, slowing each other down.
Nanocores of the Empire unable to deploy and stop en-route for no reason on certain maps

EA:
The experience for the game would be much smoother if it wasn't published by EA. RA3 had great multiplayer potential as with the introduction of the competitive aspects to the game. However, the servers in charge of hosting RA3 online closed down and there has only been a community supported server ever since, and the popularty of the RA3 community has been ever plummeting since. You won't find as much players nowadays as compared to when the gamespy servers were still online, and as a result matchmaking is almost impossible due to the tiny amount of players still playing the game.

Overall, the Red Alert 3 is a great game that could be great fun to play no matter by yourself or with others. However I certainly don't think that it is worth this price due to EA's unresponsible attitude towards this game. Buy it if you have some spare money to have fun with, but it is not on the must-have list.

I've been a fan for the Command and Conquer series ever since Generals, and this game lived up to it's name (Unlike 4, which completely abolished one of the main cores of the game; Base Building)

From raging sea battles to earth-shattering land conquest, to air superiority; this game holds an incredible amount of replay value.

The epic score will kick in when your base suddenly screams for help as your foes try to take you down, or when you build a sizeable army to take the fight straight into the heart of your enemy's fortress.

Even if you haven't played any C&C games before, as long as you have a depriving thirst for an RTS game, then this is definietely for you.

(There are a few mods for this game, and many downloadable maps, some even with custom scripts to amplify the gameplay and to suit your tastes of war)

This is my own opinion; I might sound biased, but I just can't get enough of RTS.

THE BEST real time strategy war game ever. Period. Even after all these years this is stll a benchmak. Controls are flowless, the IA is great (and may be too smart sometimes especaly on skirmish mode). Sound is great and graphics even for todays (2016) have nothing to be ashamed on. Red alert 3 is by far the game I played probably the most along the years. 
There nothing like the original , and this is the original. 
If you like strategy war game you must own it.

+ uses the updated version of the Sage engine, the one that debuted in Generals: the effects (especially the water effects) look stunning
+ has a similar script that Red Alert 2 had: they toned down the seriousness of the very first game and instead included some funny dialogues to help with the cheesy storyline
+ ambitious casting, perhaps the best in the entire series with Tim Curry, Peter Stormare, Jonathan Pryce and J.K. Simmons just to name a few
+ inclusion of offshore battlegrounds: almost every building can be built on water; this gives way to newer tactics
+ finally, a 3rd faction we can choose from: the Empire of the Rising Sun is an instant favourite thanks to the unit variation (plus George Takei!)

- ore fields were removed: we now have stationery ore mines that are nice but cutting of the enemy's' resources now is not as important or effective as it used to be
- campaign could have been a little longer: while there are 9 missions with each side completing the first 4-5 does not take very long
- the game desperately tries to show something new with the inclusion of the naval warfare: this is not necessarily a problem but throughout the campaign there's too much emphasis on it 
- mediocre coop integration: while playing all 27 levels with a friend is pretty cool, playing solo is pretty difficult at times due to the dumbed-down A.I. that is not always helpful

To summarise: for me the number 2 will be the essential Red Alert title but this one was also pretty neat back in 2008. Running it on modern PCs can be a tad bit difficult - thanks to the uploaded guide available you can find some fixes for the game.

I have a really mixed feelings about this game. I remember that I loved it when I played it back in 2009. But now, 7 years later, I find the controls quite annoying. There is too much micro management and units are quite dump and hence difficult to control.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] works ok with multiple screens - non-primary screens are not blacked out, game minimizes well
[*] 3 factions with a variety of units
[*] every unit has a special action
[*] every faction has some secret projects such as powerful satellite attacks or passive buffs
[*] coop mode in campaign, possible to play with AI that can be issued orders
[*] ok movie-like cut scenes with real actors
[/list]

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
[list]
[*] cartoonish graphics
[*] some stupid units such as dog, bear or dolphin (or spy that can pretend to be a bear)
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] game requires admin permissions on every startup (however it seems to work without it)
[*] long starting time with non-skip-able logos (which pause if you minimize the game)
[*] units' AI and path finding is rather poor
[list]
[*] units sometimes are unable to get to destination
[*] units sometimes get stuck around the buildings
[*] when large group is issued an attack order they attack in row rather than in group
[*] when you send a group of 30 units (mixed infantry and vehicles) they will create a rectangular formation at their destination - which is extremely spread due to vehicles' presence
[/list]
[*] multiplayer has been switched off
[/list]

Awesome! Great addition to a great franchise. One of the games that pioneered high production value cutscenes and live action performances that elevate the experience to a new level.

I found myself laughing at the enemy taunts (which of course were presented by seasoned actors and performers giving the game that often missing "social feel"). Classic RTS game play with three completely different play styles for each give it a high replay value. Add skirmishes and it will keep you playing long after the campaigns are done.

Recommended for fans of the franchise or lovers of RTS and strategy genre. Great graphics, great performances all around and an engaging if not over the top plot with the feel of a big budget hollywood production. I only ever write a review if I feel strongly enough to do so and this is one of them for certain. 

Looking forward to future titles carrying or expanding upon the tradition that Westwood studios so boldly started when it had the Dune franchise. Command and Conquer rocks! I can't say enough about the use of live action performers and great voice talent as well. It just gives so much life to the whole experience.

Highly recommended.

I'll start with this, I prefer Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2 to this one but it's still a really great game that everyone should give a try.
The soundtrack is awesome, for once, the allies aren't the primary faction or at least In my opinion, the Russians are.
The Japanese are really nice to use but I'd like if there could be at least 2 more factions.
The game can be pretty challenging against hardest AI though, unlike Generals Zero Hour which is easy In my opinion, but it's not as a challenging as Command & Conquer 3 which In my opinion is the hardest, of course, I'm talking of the hardest difficulty in game.

1. Command & Conquer: Generals Zero Hour
2. Command & Conquer: Tiberium series.
3. Command & Conquer: Red Alert series

first and second are kind of equal to me, they both got their flaws and their qualities, I love both at the same level, they both have great campaigns and a great story but totally different, I must admit that I prefer the one of Command & Conquer 3 but at the same time I prefer the units in General Zero Hour, depends, sometimes I could say I prefer one and the other time I would say the opposite, both are really great.

That's my favorite list (between them because there are others of course which are even better).
I'd suggest this game to any science fiction and real time strategy games.
If you like the Japanese a lot and/or play with one character only (Japanese campaign), I'd suggest you get Red Alert 3: Uprising which is a expansion (standalone) that is pretty great too.
I'd suggest you try every Command & Conquer except Command & Conquer: Tiberium Alliances which is a mmo and it is really bad, about Command & Conquer 4, you should give it a try for free before buying it.
There is also Command & Conquer: Renegade which is a fps, great game, it was one of my favorite when I was younger.
Anyway, to get back to this game, It is not the best Command & Conquer ever but it is one great strategy game.

The third installment in the Red Alert universe is the best one yet. Combining all the classic elements of its predecessors that made those games great; Red Alert 3 is an RTS done right. Among all the usual fare like Campaign and Skirmishes, there are also lots of battles to be faught online and new experiences to be had in single player with the live action cutscenes. Let's face it guys, the acting is really corny. But who needs good acting when you've got jugs? Lots of jugs. In fact, if you are a fan of jugs you will want to buy this game whether or not you're actually into RTC. 

But seriously, there's a lot of content to be experienced in this, and its expansion which can be bought separately. 

I personally really enjoy the new Empire of the Rising Sun faction, as it adds a modular twist to the usual units we're used to seeing and thus changes up the game significantly. 

Graphics wise it runs very smooth and on nearly any system these days. The art style is one of a more lighter-hearted nature. But then again, that goes hand in hand with the direction of the game and the universe. Red Alert has always been the more cheeky, sci-fi cousin of the Tiberium and Generals universes and stands alone as a unique and interesting one at that. 

THe pacing of the game is fantastic, the audio is pretty decent (especially the music) and the gameplay is sublime. If you're a fan of any of the C&C games in the past, ESPECIALLY Red Alert, you owe it to yourself to check this game out.

An underrated RTS gem that's just plain fun. I can understand why C&C fanboys might dislike it; it doesn't take itself seriously whatsoever. The Allies command Dolpins with sonar pulse weapons, the Soviets have zeppelin-like Kirov Airships, and the Empire has frickin' Warriors with beam katanas. The units, story and cutscenes are all over-the-top ridiculous but it's highly entertaining. The gameplay is as intense as ever, and the cell-shaded graphics are beautiful, especially the crisp blue water. The difficulty scaling is very good; even though I was once Masters in SC2 I went Easy mode for a nice, relaxing playthrough. Medium isn't too bad if you want to play missions a couple times. Overall this game is just excellent in every aspect.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is the 15th game in C&C series. Published in 2008, by EA.

The story stared when Lieutant Cherdenko, General Krukov and Dr. Zelinsky from the Soviet travel through the time to the past to become alliance with Albert Einstein to make the Allies weakened and automatically make the Soviets is the winner in this war. But instead accidentally removed Einstein from the time and from this world. And they come back in the present. From what they have done is leading to have the third faction, the Empire of the Rising Sun, is going to dominate this world. The battle begins between the three great powers. This war called "The war of the three powers".

Pros:
-Three factions have their own specific style.
-Very balance between three factions.(The things like C&C3 will never happen like hordes of Mammoth Tanks, Zone Troopers and Juggernauts are overwheilming you and you are f-u-c-k-e-d) 
-Different base building style.(Dem Japanese scatter their base around the map)
-Co-op campaign that you can play with your friend. Only in this C&C.
-Your beloved units from past games are here.(Kirov Reporting) 
-In skirmish you can choose commander for each facttions. Each commanders have their own playstyle(Bots only).

Cons:
-Short Campaign playtime compared to other games.
-In campaign your bot sometimes useless.
-No 4v4 skirmish
-Unfair tech tree levelling. Soviets only have a single super reactor/tech lab, advanced units availble for whole base in the map. Alied required hightended/max clearance for each MCVs/outposts to unlock advanced units(If your MCV is fully upgraded but if your outpost doesn't upgraded yet, production structures that outpost covered still not unlock advanced units). Empire is the worst, you need to upgrade EACH of the production structures to unlock advanced units.

Conclusion: It's a great game. Worth the money. If you want everything balance, this game is for you.

I'm a pretty big fan of the Command and Conquer franchise, so I was very much looking forward to finally playing this, albeit years after its release.

Unfortunately, while playing this game, all I could think about was how much more fun the campaigns of previous installments were, particularly Red Alert 2.

The first Red Alert featured faceless pixelated troops that you'd throw en masse against your enemies. The second one took a completely different approach, with individual units being rather personalized and potentially extremely powerful (even GIs were a menace at Elite veterancy) and allowing you to wreck enemy bases with just a handful of units in the right spots (I remember being able to dismantle most bases in campaign mode with only 3 Legionnaires). The third installment seems to fit somewhere in between, but loses something to both.

Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a real-time strategy game and obviously the follow-up to Red Alert 2. While I absolutely loved Red Alert 2 I can't say the same for this title.

First, there are some things Red Alert 3 does well. The storyline is as cheesy as it comes and that is what fans expect and love. It is also great that the game has actors like Tim Curry, George Takei and David Hasselhoff, who really seem to enjoy performing the B-movie-like storyline.

However, Red Alert 3 has many problems compared to its predecessor. The units have a cartoonish look to them and look like child's toys. Many of them look so over the top that it is just ridiculous. Also, the weapon's effects and sounds don't convey any impact, further reinforcing that impression.

The gameplay itself comes off as very hectic because units cannot take any damage, no matter the unit type. Even the biggest tanks and ships give off the impression of being made of paper. They get destroyed within seconds leaving no room for actual micromanagement. The problem is that the game wants the player to micromanage since every unit has some sort of special ability. There is not much room to use them however and I would have preferred not having them at all except the toggled abilites. The units' AI is also pretty bad. If the enemy has a slightly longer range they will refrain from retaliating and just get destroyed. Anti-air weaponry is extremely underwhelming in this game. Often building turrets don't seem to make no sense at all. Even if you have a solid turret setup there is just not much use in defending since there are so many units that can destroy your base from huge distances. If the enemy uses aircraft they will still destroy your base because there is no defense that will keep them from destroying at least one target in every run.

Red Alert 3 features a computer controlled partner in every campaign mission. This partner can be replaced by a human player and while I appreciate the idea of making the whole campaign able to be played coop it just doesn't work. The computer partner is highly unreliable in its performance. In some missions it will basically win the mission by itself with you struggling to keep up with the pace and in some missions it will be literally useless. During the last mission of the Rising Sun campaign my AI partner was actually unable to even defend its own base. When I didn't continually sent units there my partner would just be annihilated within a few minutes. All of this while I had my own problems, being hammered by airstrikes, superweapons and ground troops.

The campaign should come with a trigger warning (pun intended) because all missions are heavily built around triggers that you most of the time cannot see coming. However you need to be prepared for them because if you're not you have basically lost. There is no reaction time since the game is fast and units and buildings cannot withstand any damage. It's bad design if you can only win by being able to see into the future. If you have run your head into the wall a few times you will know the triggers and it basically becomes a minigame of avoiding those. One of the worst examples is from the Rising Sun campaign. At one point you will be confronted with a huge enemy fleet and have to hold out until your battleships arrive. When they arrive it is still not enough to destroy the enemie's base but you absolutely need to destroy all their shipyards. Why you ask? Because the AI will start producing an indefinite amount of aircraft carriers and since anti-air turrets are horribly weak you will lose.

Red Alert 3 is not a horrible game but is has so many shortcomings compared to its predecessor that I cannot recommend it at all.

P.S.: If you liked the Tanya from Red Alert 2 you will be severely disappointed.

The Command & Conquer series were a huge part of my childhood, mainly Red Alert 2 and Yuri's Revenge, and while this game definitely has lost alot of its classic elements from back in the day, the amount of improvements it has made is finaminal. 

Pros:
-Three different campaigns you can do at your own pace and difficulty
-Numerous units on sea, land and air (something that alot of RTS games don't have)
-Online Multiplayer
-After over 100 hours, I haven't found a single bug or glitch, besides occasional character movement around corners and water.
-Skrimish mode, where you can practice your strategies on AI's 
-Babes, telling you what to do in the videos as you try to impress them throughout the game. Lmao.

Cons:
-Mediocre Graphics, not nearly as fancy as the videos.
-Pretty dull story mode
-The acting in the videos isn't too great, but what can you expect, right?
-Costs alot when it comes to money (and time haha)... but it's worth it, in my true opinion.

All in all, when comparing the factors I look for in a game, the pros heavily outweigh the cons the way I see it. Again, this is only my opinion, so if you can immerse yourself in another World War 2 story-mode game, then good for you man, I'm glad you enjoy it.

Though I've logged only 4 hours on this game, I am quite familiar with Red Alert 2 and other RTS games. Simply, EA has destroyed what was once a great franchise. The units themselves are woefully balanced with some units being destroyed instantly. The difficulty of the game is quite frustrating considering that the game itself is poorly scripted, as there are multiple bugs. I've had problems with units failing to complete their movement due to poor pathing. Some units will just stop if their path is momentarily blocked. Siege units are insanely powerful while infantry and many other units are simply irrelevant. It seems that the Soviets in particular lack any sort of meaningful anti air units as the Bullfrogs and MiGs have light armor values and can be decimated by units of other regions. Flak troopers may be cheap but without any ability to traverse water, there is essentially no sufficient anti air. The Scorpion unit of RA2 was completely removed, which were some of the best anti air units that the Soviets had at their disposal.

In addition, the campaign missions seem to be poorly designed. Just recently I played a mission in which the Soviet player had to assassinate the Emperor of the Rising Sun with a single Conscript. It seemed as illogical that there were areial units flying that failed to notice the enemy Conscript. As the mission continued, my base was assaulted by a wave of enemy tanks before any sort of player could mount a resistance force. The missions are boring and uninteresting. The acting and writing is subpar. The unit AI seems almost idiotic and inconsistent with some units agressively pursuing enemy units while other times standing their ground and just letting themselves be defeated.

In sum, I was wholeheartedly dissapoointed at this game. EA has (unsurprisingly) ruined another franchise. Just play RE2, which I still do. It may be older but at least it was well made in comparision to RE3, a shit game.

As a fan of Red Alert 2, I was pretty hyped for this game. When the reviews came out, it was clear it wasn't the same experience as before, so I held off purchase. But when it came to sale for the low, low price of ‚Ç¨3, I couldn't resist picking it up. It can't be a bad deal for that price, right?

Wrong. The inclusion of an Allied AI commander clearly supposed to carry the single player campaign in absence of a multiplayer buddy just doesn't work. It's frustrating to have a lot of your fun depend on a dead weight ally. Single player campaign play is frustrating, and only really worth it for the FMV cutscenes. The casting choices are great, including the awesome George Takei as the Japanese Emperor. But, on that subject, the faction of Japan just doesn't feel right in Red Alert, and tries to steal the spotlight from the established factions in a way that just doesn't work. Red Alert's campy plots and cutscenes thrived on its mock Cold War feeling.

From a technical standpoint, it's a fine game. Units are diverse, mechanics are solid enough. Undoubtedly the strength of the game is in multiplayer, which I haven't tried. But it just doesn't feel like it's a proper Red Alert game. Plainly put, I wasn't having fun with this, and rarely have I been so disappointed in a purchase.

Being a long-time fan of the Red Alert series, I was excited to try the latest instalment. I was a little bit sceptical of the new features like transforming units and the ability to build a base on water, because I wondered if some of the magic of the first two games had been lost.

I was wrong. This game has kept my attention enough to beat each faction's campaign at least once, if not twice, and these missions present a challenge even if you have been playing RA2 for a while. The skirmishes, however, kept me coming back and they are what I play these days. There are so many different configurations, playstyles and challenges that you can try and overcome, like winning a match with only infantry units.

I highly recommend this game to fans of the series and newcomers to the RTS genre.

Cheesy cutscenes are part of this game's charm.  Reawakening a nostalgia in me from the original Red Alert games - I throughly enjoyed my time with this game which actually looks very good.  The macromangement is there with each of the unique factions having their own flavours and feels - each seemingly in a state of adequate "balanced-imbalance" that kept it interesting.  As easy as playing through most of the campaign - the fact that they included an option for Coop the campaign mode with your friends was a very nice touch. 

For competitive RTS enthusiasts the deeper level of micro and meta gaming is there for those wanting to polish up their APM and skills and sink their teeth into the multiplayer.  Starting from the collision of units as you nimble side step a falling enemy zepplin with your infantry or position your formation in such a way for their special abilities to get the maximum effectiveness.  The difference between being able to play this game and being a master-class player would be at least a few hundred hours.

Not to say the game doesn't have it's few drawbacks - more times than pure chance units would bug out on the map - whether they got stuck inside of terrain or refuse to function like you are instructing them to - due to pathing errors etc.  The cutscenes themselves have their cheesy charm and the actresses are beautiful but some of the over-the-top acting on cheap sets might turn some people off from it inbetween missions.

I would recommend this title inspite of those issues.

Pros:
+ Great graphics/visuals.
+ Well-known cast.
+ Good balance and mix of units.

Cons:
- Dumbed-down strategy.
- Meaningless storyline.
- Low-poly and cartoony.

[h1]TL:DR? See Conclusion[/h1]

[h1]NOTE:[/h1] I have played this game extensively, but not on Steam.

[h1]INTRODUCTION:[/h1]
Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game serving as the third installment of the popular Command & Conquer series.  It features a rebooted story and a brand new faction called 'The Empire of the Rising Sun'.  However, unlike its predecessors,  Electronic Arts who acquired Westwood Studios, the original developers of the game, produced Red Alert 3.  It is one of the last few remaining franchises who use live action cutscenes which the series is known for.

Players once again take the role of the unknown commander who leads either the Allied Forces, the Soviet Army, or the newly resurrected Imperial Armed Forces to ultimate victory.

Red Alert 3's story starts with the Soviet Union in complete collapse after the events of Red Alert 2.  In an effort to stop the USSR's defeat, surviving Soviet leaders use a time machine to go back in history and erase Albert Einstein in order to prevent him from developing Allied technology.  Upon returning to the Present day however, they discover that without Einstein, nuclear technology was  never developed.  With this turn of events, this meant that the US never bombed Japan and the Empire never surrendered during World War 2.  Now the Empire has risen once more and poses a new threat to both the Soviets and the Allies prompting the hilarious line by actor Peter Stormare as Dr. Gregor Zelinsky: ‚ÄúWe now have...two mortal enemies?‚Äù 

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
+ Colorful visuals and very nice graphics with good use of Physx technology
+ New 'Empire of the Rising Sun' faction is fun to play featuring highly advanced, extremely versatile, very expensive, and unhealthily suicidal units (ex. Tsunami Tank:[i] ‚ÄúHA! Give us a good death‚Äù [/i] Imperial Warrior: [I] ‚ÄúDeath before defeat!‚Äù[/i] Shogun Battleship: [I] ‚ÄúRamming speed!‚Äù[/i] Yari Sub: [I] ‚ÄúWe're taking you with us!‚Äù [/i]
+ Fun campaign for all 3 factions
+ Hilarious, Hammy, Cheesy but overall good voice acting
+ Humorous and entertaining Tutorial
+ All units for all factions now have secondary abilities
+ Co-op campaign
+ Very nice Music and Sounds

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
- The very colorful art-style that could cause headaches for some people
- Some low polygon models, low resolution shadows, and poor textures can be seen here and there
- Short campaign for each faction
- Story is shallow and uses way to many cliche elements from the previous Red Alert 2
- Occasional pathfinding problems
- Balance issues with some of the units
- Some outstanding bugs that was never fixed (for some reason, changing the graphics quality and  resolution at the same time MAY cause a crash)
- Despite EA's vast resources and use of big name actors like Peter Stormare and George Takei, I can't help but feel that they were not able to live up to the standard of Westwood.
- Broken multiplayer on Steam (No idea if it works in Origin)

[h1]CONCLUSION:[/h1]
GREAT RTS GAME.  Although it does not fully capture the magic of Red Alert 2, Red Alert 3 still delivers a great fast paced experience for RTS fans looking for a quick fix.  The campaign is fun with a story that is easy to follow but uses a lot of cliche plot elements.  The Soundtrack is excellent and the over-the-top, hammy, and cheesy voice acting are very entertaining.  Multiplayer is also fun if you're looking for a casual RTS experience since the AI does pose a challenge on higher difficulties.  In addition, new game mechanics such as the secondary abilities and the new faction spices up the action.

Now we come on whether or not I recommend this game.  If you're in this for the single player experience, sure I can RECOMMEND this game easily.  If you're in this for the multiplayer experience, I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game here on Steam because for some reason the Servers are broken so you're better off purchasing this in EA's Origin Platform.

8.34/10

I want to make a note, that I've only played RA3 for about 6 - 7 h when writing this "review".

I can see a fun game in there somewhere, but one major thing really kills the gameplay for me; at least during th solo campaing, and that is the shared economy. I really hate that. Since the AI is always building stuff you can't save up money for things to build, and you are ALWAYS short of resources because of this. It is really frustrating! I was looking forward to having a full co-op campaign when I bought this game, but I was not ready for that design decision.


Otherwise I've been surprised about how well this holds up as a sequel to RA2 and YR. And it is fun that we finally get a main campaign that focuses on the Sovjet side. Sure, previous games have always had the sovjet campaign aswell, but that was not the main story. And having such a great actor-rooster adds to the experience.

The amoun of bewbs (or cleavage) this game shows can be discussed. The twelve-year old inside my 25 year old body is happy, but the game would have been just as good (perhaps better) without it.

So how does the game feel then?

Basically this game is a mixture of the previous C&C titles. You've got the familiar units, all though redesigned, from the RA-series with addition of new units. You've also got the micromanagment system from RA2, which was lacking in the Generals-series; waypoints and hold-fire and stuff like that. Then again, some controls and features from the Generals series have found its way in here. It is really odd to see units and gameplay first feeling like generals, but then also feeling like RA2. I'm not sure I'm all that fond of the mixture yet.


I'm sure my view on this game will change as time goes by. And if I manage to get online I will add that experience to this review later on. 

Will I recommend this game for new players? Well if you have RA2/Yuri's Revenge and you somehow manage to play that online then stick with that game, because it is more fluent than this. At least in my humble opinion.

If you don't have anything else, I can surley see this as a viable option. And for 5 dollars on steam it is worth it.

Ah, good old Red Alert.

Nothing better than a RTS that is easy going with over the top plot and units and technologies. Comparing the three installments of this game the first one was the least over the top. It still had some seriousness from the original C&C, but had the basis for ‚Äòover-the-top-ness‚Äô with the idea of Soviet Union expanding into all of Europe. Oh, and there was time travel as well. The second RA didn‚Äôt disappoint and took a leap forward in ‚Äòover-the-top-ness‚Äô with Soviets assaulting the US and game being generally more colorful and cheerful. Now it is the other way around with Soviets eliminating key figure from the past instead of Allies as in RA 1 and events taking yet another direction with Empire of the Rising Sun coming out as a united threat.

The game is colorful, silly, over the top and most importantly much fun. This time the big new thing is a co-commander who can be a real person over the Internet or AI controlled. This is an interesting concept with sort of built in multiplayer, but I‚Äôm really glad they made the option of AI co-commander, helping me not deal with social interactions. On rare occasions AI glitched and never left its base, so all offensive had to be done by me. At least I didn‚Äôt have to worry about defenses. Overall having a co-commanders is very beneficial as they supply almost constant attacks on the enemy thus softening them up for my big armada, which is quickly reduced to almost nothing, because unit balance is made very well I think. In most cases you can‚Äôt storm in with dozens of Apocalypse tanks and win the level. Almost always you have to think about anti-air units since the enemy AI most often will use air units for defenses and offenses as well.

The best part from RA 2 is back ‚Äì unit experience. There is nothing more satisfying than one or two units maintaining the pressure on the enemy or holding off what is thrown at you only because you previously cared and repaired them each time units were near death and now they have highest possible rank and therefore added defense and firepower. For me that was the best idea Westwood had for RA 2 and it is present in RA 3 as well

Overall I think it made a great transition from 2D to 3D and I loved the game just like the previous ones.

J. Jonah Jameson was trying to blow up Moscow with a giant laser built into Theodore Roosevelt's head on Mount Rushmore, which wasn't good at all, because that would destroy my peace treaty with Doctor Frank N. Furter, whom I desperately needed on my side to help me defeat Lieutenant Sulu.

Red Alert 3 is an RTS game, set in an alternate timeline after the Soviets went back in time and rewrote history (again) by murdering Albert Einstein. It‚Äôs even more ridiculous than it sounds, and serves as a worthy sequel to my all-time favourite RTS, Red Alert 2. It‚Äôs fun, campy, and often hilarious, while still serving up slice after slice of the Command & Conquer we all know and love.

There are three campaigns to be played through: Soviet Union, Allies, and The Empire of the Rising Sun. Each campaign consists of 9 missions, and it took me about 23 hours to beat them all. When you‚Äôre done with that, there‚Äôs custom Skirmishes and the Uprising expansion to play through.

Between missions you'll be treated to good old FMV sequences starring well-known actors, including a couple of surprise cameos. These serve to convey the story, relay your mission objectives, and make you snort Pepsi out of your nose, especially when Tim Curry or J. K. Simmons is speaking.

The soundtrack is a blast, and Frank Klepacki, the musical genius behind the rocktronic compositions for the original C&C through to Renegade, returns once more for three tracks: Hell March 3, Grinder 2, and The Red Menace, which steal the show above the rest of the game's music. Pity he didn't compose the entire soundtrack.

But RA3 suffers from two flaws: Co-op, and hand-holding. These two elements work together to steal away your freedom. Each mission is designed to be played with a partner, but since EA have shut their servers down, you‚Äôre stuck with AI co-commanders. And before each mission, you‚Äôre given a step-by-step battle plan, telling you to go here and do this and move there and capture that.

Gone are the days of freedom to approach a mission in any way you see fit, which would allow for multiple replays and different experiences. Now you‚Äôre stuck with every step laid out for you, and an AI blundering alongside.

I used to find immense enjoyment in taking my time to complete a mission, as I slowly crept up the map, expanding my base, capturing all the enemy‚Äôs buildings, and then crushing him at the end. That‚Äôs no longer possible. Missions are too structured and linear, and my co-commander is always running ahead, blindly sending in troops and mucking up my strategy. 

There were moments when my co-commander completed objectives without me while I was busy elsewhere. Why even bother playing when an AI is gonna do the work whether you want it to or not?

Then there were other missions when my co-commander failed abysmally at his task, and I didn‚Äôt have time to swoop in and pick him up before failing the mission. These were the hardest of missions, and it felt nice to have to actually work to complete them, even if there were only a few.

But at the end of the day, I had so much fun playing this game that I couldn‚Äôt help but forgive it for its shortcomings. Red Alert 3 is glorious and zany in all the right ways. What it lacks in strategy and challenge, it makes up for by simply being awesome, and it‚Äôs a fantastic throwback to past Command and Conquer games.

Now if you'll excuse me, 'I am escaping to one place that hasn't been corrupted by capitalism‚ÄîSPHACE!'


TL;DR: Forced co-op can be a nuisance, and there‚Äôs too much hand-holding, but Red Alert 3 is great fun nonetheless.

I had on windows 8 the problem to change my resolution. everytime if I tried it the game crashed. But you can change the resolution still. U don't need to run the game for this way. 

Enter the folder "roaming" 

You will find it when you open your pc (C;ProgramFiles(x86)/users/yourusername/roaming

there you will find the red alert 3 folder if you enter it you see the folder profiles. there you can enter and change the resolution from 800x600 to whatever you want without tipe in any other stuff.

the easier way to find this folder is to press windows key and r key on the same time, then tpe in the opened field just "roaming" and you will enter this folder.  Hope this will help some peoples which use like me windows 8.

An interesting update to the Red Alert series. The play-style is conpletely different than what you're likely used to from RA2, or even Yuri's Revenge. It's much more fast-paced, and the inclusion of an "ally" while interesting, diminishes the importance of the player. Typically the ally will accomplish most of the objectives without requiring much prompting from you, leaving you to scramble for resources and figure out which units can go where / be used in each situation.

What a game!!! Might be old but it is solid good. You won't be overwhelmed with impossible tasks to manage. The factions are fun and they are all different. The quality of the graphics are good even for today's standards. The campaign is entertaining and long, so you get to play it from each of the faction's perspective (Russia, Allies and Japan). You can put 2 or 3 hour in this game and you won't end up exhausted. 

There is one caveat. This game is single player only, even though it has a menu option for multi-player, but it won't work. I guess the game is too old and EA had to free-up servers. 

If you ever get done with the campaign, there is a pretty good skirmish menu against the computer. In my opinion there is good re-play value in this game for the buck you are paying.

Not a terrible 3rd title in the Red Alert trilogy... 
  I was an OK fan of Red Alert 1. Then I became a HUGE fan of Red Alert 2. In fact I consider Red Alert 2 the RTS title that got me into RTS gaming.
  I had high expectations with Red Alert 3 when it released. Was I impressed initially? Honestly, no. I was a little bit disappointed with the game and really didn't like the Empire faction. I thought it was pretty damn cheesy. I mean this is coming from a game that is loaded with cheese. But really, I preferred my mind whack job faction of Yuri from Red Alert 2. At least they had some Soviet in their style. The Empire faction gives up too much cornyness with their robot units that carry samurai swords and whatnot. I understand it's the theme, but let's be realistic here. You wouldn't be winning a war with swords in Red Alert.
  For me, Red Alert 2 allowing you to choose from real world nations after picking either Allies or Soviets kept a more realistic approach to the madness and you could feel a lil more attachment to the story. Red Alert 3 is all over the place. BUT, not all is bad in the game.
  I still do love the gameplay and minor enhancements they made. The graphics looking stunning even right now with the current gen games out. The Soviets and Allies are still great looking and have some really awesome units. Who doesn't love building a mass of Dreadnoughts to rain down dozens and dozens of missles? When the damage flies, it flies.
  As I got this game on a cheap Steam sale, I figured why the hell not, and I'm happy for it. I stuck mostly with skirmish game matches where I could just have quick fun of building my base and laying waste to my opponent. 
  Where I didn't see much in this game initially upon launch, I found late in it's life thru Steam. At this point I recommend the game, but it will never be held to the standard I had with Red Alert 2.

I would not suggest this game to anyone who was a fan of the original Red Alert/2/Yuri's Revenge or even C&C Generals, EA and whatever is left of Westwood is long gone and dead.  This game does not have an enjoyable campaign, the units are basic and boring, and it is not fun thus defeating the purpose of it being classified as a "game".  The campaign is flat out dull and boring, the witty cutscenes that went hand in hand with good gameplay are no longer there, EA has seen fit to simply have bad acting encompass their bad game design just so they can say "look we remember what RA used to be too!"  

The units are boring and made out of paper, the fun general powers from C&C Generals make a return but with None of the fun or innovation that the previous title put into it.  Factional units are cut and paste from each other with only some different looking models and alternate modes being the variation.  The units in general show the worst signs of AI that I have ever seen in ANY RTS title or game that I have played PERIOD.  They are extremely near-sighted; they always fail to return fire unless you give them a direct order and will just sit there getting blown away by everything.  Speaking of alternate unit modes, this game tries to do something different and fails utterly, the only thing that these abilities do is further complicate the most BASIC C&C formula and further hamper the gameplay and fun factor of the title.  Even when you have them built with attack at will rather then defensive they will consistently neglect to defend themselves even when the enemy unit is right on top of them, it is babysitting of the highest order and a huge failing of the ‚Äúgame‚Äù and its developers.  The ‚Äúfuture‚Äù has shown that any C&C title past Generals or maybe the earlier 3D C&Cs have been a complete failure as fans continue to drop the titles in favor of something less driven by greed and fake innovation.

During the campaign you can either have a coop human player, if you can keep connection with EA‚Äôs trash servers (another quality sign of EA) or you can be aided by the in game AI, which is semi competent enough however the kicker is that for an RTS game you and your coop player share ore resources, which is absolutely ridiculous and a really poorly thought-out mechanic.  On the subject of the campaign again I will clarify further that it is one of the most boring three faction story mode that I have ever played let alone failing to bring me any joy from playing it.  I have to push myself in order to go back to it and attempt to finish it that‚Äôs how I consider the story mode and the game in general, boring and a CHORE, no game should ever make the player feel that way!  I am very glad that I never got this game when it came out for the full price and even then $10 for a 2008 title I still feel ripped off and the price proves that EA will never stop being a money grubbing parasite. To add to this, Steam needs to change the description of this game since as of now the Gamespy servers have been shut down indefinitely so the online Coop and multiplayer are no longer a functioning entity of this title.

The music of C&C has always been memorable this is especially the case with the Red Alert series.  However in RA3 they have yet again gone away from being GOOD and simply moved to the most repetitious garbage that I have had to listen to repeated through the ENTIRE CAMPAIGN.  You will hear a single song for the entirety of each an every single mission within the campaign as well as the multi and skirmish section, not ONCE is the famous Red Alert song played at any point within the game short of the menu, that is yet more proof that there is no longer a Command and Conquer series of RTS games at all.  They have simply screwed up on the entire game, which amazingly enough extends to even the music score which is unbelievable.  

I am saddened that this title got such higher praises then I feel that it should have, as if the fans were so hopeful to the possibilities of the new EA Westwood titles that everyone seems to have given this game a pass regardless to how bad it truly is.  I feel sorry that the younger generations after me will never again know how good C&C titles used to be and that based on this, my last C&C title that I will buy, we will never see the good days again.

One of the few games I truly love. The game have a pretty funny story and not very serious at all. As an Age of Empire 2 lover I also want a change of pace and fight with something like tanks and laser cannon rather than bows and swords. And better yet, fight by commanding an army of robot! The unit types in this game counter each other to the point that a lowly infantry can withstand a blow from the main gun of a tsunami tank (but not its tread of course). The King Oni shoots laser beam from its eyes are vulnerable to infantry (yes, infantry) without its secondary ability. King Oni can finish off buildings and armored vehicles and blow them up to oblivion, but gaze that scary glowing eye of yours at a Conscript, for example, and congrat comgrades, experience how lame you can be.
It pretty much like rock paper scissor. In short : the unit strengths and weaknesses are enhanced, and heavily amplified. Get the right units and you will raze their base to the ground, get the wrong ones, and totaloo, your base will be razed to the ground, oh and your pride as a RTS strategist, too, if you have any.
The pace of battles is very fast for me, the outcome of combat is decided pretty quickly, and you better put your godlike microskillz to use, else, screw micro managing, just right click your way to victory.
The differences of three forces: Allies, USSR, and Japan Empire are very diversified. The Allies has Air superiority, the Japan Empire, of course, master of the sea. Finally the USSR prefers to fight on land (yes, LAND WARFARE) basically if you confront them head on, and they are not hindered by your navy or air force, then you are dead my friend; the Red army will mow you down, they loves using brute force.
There are lots of tatics and tricks that can be used, thanks to the special ability of some units.
Joking aside, to be honest, I bumped onto this game when it was on sale and it was the best bargain I can get with just $5.

Offensive, childish and immature design. Was this game made by a huge conglomerate or by a fucking five year old with a massive red crayon? The acting and scriptwriting was that level. 
Uninspired gameplay, units, mechanics. Long gone is the subtlety and tactics of Tiberian Sun and Red Alert 2. Almost identical design to Tiberium Wars and Starcraft 2 with literally none of the enjoyment or quality. Point, click, point, click. Almost no purpose having hotkeys when the game is this basic. No realism, completely impossible to suspend disbelief. 
As a product of entertainment, this is the biggest fucking load of shit I have wasted ¬£5 on.

It's a fun game and while not quite as fun as Red Alert 2, it's still pretty enjoyable, sadly the online multiplayer/co-op gameplay went offline with gamespy.

The game I'm sure was once great, and the new integration of multiplayer co-op through the campaign added a new and fun way to make your way through the scenarios. However EA had previously hosted the online servers through Gamespy, which has since December 2013 been shut down. EA has not produced an alternate hosting solution for Red Alert 3, and it does not seem like they will as this is not a Madden game or a Battlefield game. Therefore you are stuck playing the single player campaign missions with an AI co-op partner, which sucks eggs. So like other reviewers have stated, the single player alone is not enough to carry this game, and one must engage in the multiplayer aspect to truly appreciate the new mechanics. But since EA isn't hosting the multiplayer anymore the game is no longer worth playing.
