This game is going offline here pretty soon thanks to EA dropping support for the "less than 1%" of their playerbase across over 50 of their titles. Regardless, this is a RTS game that would still remain fantastic to play in singleplayer OR co-op with a friend, as everything does work with Hamachi and if you have a disc version, Gameranger works too. The game has an extensive list of tutorials that for the most part a seasoned C&C player can entirely ignore and figure the new stuff out themselves, but as far as features go, this game is the closest thing to a Westwood C&C styled game that has come out since their demise. No squad system, extreme countering-style units, extreme diversion amongst the factions (the fast-paced allies, the turtle-heavy soviets, and the...asians), diverse base construction (finally bringing walls back) and a ton of lighthearted and extremely amusing missions and dialogue from units and the campaign with rocking music featuring Tim Wynn, James Hannigan, and of course, Frank Klepacki from the westwood titles helping to soundtrack as well. That said, the campaign is absolutely fantastic by ANY standard - FMV cutscenes that add up to somewhere around an hour in length and use top notch actors such as J.K. Simmons and George Takei.

As far as how well this game can bring in new players to the series, it's extensive campaign and the fact that 1 of the 3 campaigns (Soviet one) is almost explicitly designed to ease players into the gameplay makes this a FANTASTIC entry point for newcomers. The tutorial itself consists of 6 amusing tutorials that really don't feel tedious despite totalling about an hour in length to explain the game mechanics, and are entirely skippable for anyone who's familiar with certain aspects of C&C or basic RTS controls to either see newer features or try to figure it out themselves. And for those not particularly happy with the soviet campaign style of easing players in, the allies campaign as well as empire campaign are notably more difficult right off the starting line and clearly designed with veteran players in mind. The campaign endings are lackluster so don't expect anything amazing, but the story throughout each campaign is rather intriguing. And yes, I keep going back to the campaign - that is really where the most work went into this game, clearly. The campaign at all points in time gives you an AI partner of a certain personality, each personality having a different playstyle. If you don't want an AI partner, it's possible to have a friend play with you instead in co-op, replacing the AI partner. The AI isn't particularly bad, however, and you are capable of issuing 4 basic commands (Strike area, strike target, plan (build up and launch) attack, don't attack) to your AI companion in an attempt to order them around like you would with another player.

As far as skirmish goes, it does provide a lot of replayability as once again, you can call in these AI personalities to fight with or against you. Likewise, in multiplayer which will be limited to LAN-based hosting services or just straight up REAL LAN if anyone still uses that, other players can join you and you can still add AI or remove them at will. The limit to 6 players at maximum, however, is upsetting, and the map editor for this game does not work with the steam version as far as I can tell, but there's already plenty of community maps worth downloading and playing.

For a $20 asking price, you are more than getting your money's worth. Compared with the considerably less westwood-like C&C 3 Tiberium Wars game asking $30, you are far better off getting this game and will undoubtably have more fun with it alone or with friends and it is by far the best entry into the C&C series as a whole for new players.

Excellent game, uses a lot of strategy, with varying levels of difficulty from new, to professional. An excellent continuation from the story of C&C: RA2, where the Russians were defeated, but in this one they might just win.  10 stars, I would happily pay $20 for this game, except I already have.

Brilliant game which lets you try almost every tactic you can think of. A long campiagn with both fun, and challanging levels. There are many different mission objectives (not just kill the enemy). A great plot with twists and some unspeakable acts of pure madness and betrail. The cut-scenes also have some very good actors who really suit there role, it makes a nice change from badly scripted and clearly unnatural CGI or just boring text at the bottom. The developers have decided to give this game naval units (unlike the other C&C games). The wide array of ground, naval and air units allow you to fight at many different fronts. You can achieve victory with well co-ordinated attacks, not just with brute force and large armies (which has been a problem with past C&C games). The 3 factions are not equal, each one specialises in one form for example the Rising sun has the best navy. This inequality doesn't make tha game one-sided, it forces commanders of all factions to constantly adopt new and interesting stratagies

Everyone will tell you that this game is a continuation of the wacky shenanigans that happened in RA2, but I really don't remember the game being that wacky and silly. Case in point, in Yuri's Revenge, there was a building that ground up troops for resources all while using slave labor.

Mind you, this was also a game where you fight dinosaurs and hollywood stars were actually commandoes, but I can also say that with the combination of frank klepacki's unapologetically metal soundtrack combined with equal amounts ridiculous and awesome units and set pieces, RA 2 worked on a level that couldn't be replicated.

That being said, RA3 is in no way the game that anyone was looking for. See, what sets RA2 above other RTS games is the idea that a gamebreaker should be countered with a gamebreaker. Just remember the chronotroops and the psychich commandos, its a game with glorious power creep that encourages you to out-do your opponent.

That being said, not only did EA make a pathetic attempt to balance this game, nothing feels as crazy or nearly as fun. Or as balanced.

A focus on naval warfare means that Rising Sun in theory should have an advatage, but with no viable anti-air until at least 2nd tier dock/factory, and to be honest I never used it. Everything feels squishy and underpowered, and nothing is as interesting as it was in RA2, and although Klepacki's soundtrack is fun, its not nearly as engrossing as it was in his other works.

If you're really jonesing for a CnC game, get tiberium wars/wrath of kane.

Command and Conquer does it again with another great installment onto the Red Alert series. Although not as good as its predecessor C&C: RA3 continues to offer no need for builders and no worry of controlling population. 

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Unlike past Red Alerts I only played about one skirmish as I did not find the AI as enjoyable as the predecessors. This Red Alert offers some interesting new teams and resource harvesting concepts which seem different than before. Like in the past Red Alert games the Russians and Allies are pretty much the same basic strategy type, while the third team offers a fresh new tactics. Similar to past Red Alerts to expand bases (when playing as either Allies or Soviets) you can build Mobile Construction Vehicles. But, unlike past Red alerts they have also added the ability for Prospectors (allied ore miners) to deploy into Command Centers which allow you to expand to nearby areas mitigating large costs. The USSR can build ‚ÄúSputnik‚Äù which can also deploy into a command center. Both of these units allow for cheaper base expansion. This is different for the Japanese whose buildings are built by transforming vehicles into buildings and thus are not limited to base parameters.
 
[b]Campaign:[/b]
The campaign took me about 21 hours to complete (that includes Allies, Russians, and Rising Sun missions). Interestingly the campaigns intertwine and in some instances you play the same missions but just as the opposing team, which I sort of liked. In the case of this game the missions are not exactly gripping, but that is the case with all strategy games. The campaign offers a great composition of actors which make you laugh, gasp, and reminisce in the old days when you first sat down and played Red Alert. Some of the missions are very quick and last no time at all while others can last a couple hours. 

[b]Results:[/b]
If you are expecting something just like the second Red Alert then you will be disappointed. There is only one Yuri and his revenge was an epic adventure that could only be told once. If you are interested in playing a strategy game that brings Red Alert on a new adventure then this is a game worth checking out. With an amazing intro song to boot and epic campaign cut scenes that you won't forget. Red Alert 3 really takes Westwood‚Äôs dream into action: hot babes who flirt with you throughout your entire game and keep your spirits bolstered with cheesy lines. 

Pros:
+Great campaign with fun dialogue and amazing cut scenes.
+New Empire of the Rising Sun team which brings all new tactics to the game
+Campaign missions that don't just require you to continually build a base over and over again, but rather test you through a variety of scenarios.
+Epic main menu music that just makes you want to jump right into the Russian campaign. 
+It has been 18 years and Tanya still hasn't aged over 30... a mystery? Or did someone use the chronosphere?

Cons:
-Its not Red Alert 2 (that game already existed, if you want that game you may want to go find the disk from your shelf)
-Some campaign missions can run rather long, while others last about 10 minutes. (Some missions took me up to three hours). 
-Poor movement AI can cause units to not exactly act how you want them too.
If only this was as good as RA2.

C&C: RA3 is one of those very much so rare games that even though all competition from newer RTS-titles, still have managed to remain just as fun to play at the current as back when they were initially released. 

With this IP, EA Los Angeles introduced to us (the players) one of the very best of gaming-experiences ever crafted, let alone one which one could ever have asked for. EALA gave us players lots of additional features and tools both advanced as simple that made and still makes this game from the bigger rest.

The Developers gave us the very best, with features such as the fantasticaly simplictic hosting-system of which still runs as smooth as ever and in which one didn't need to set up a entiere f*****g home-based server in-order to do so.
The RA3 Worldbuilder map-editor which was and once again still remains one of the simplest and most time-saving/conserving map-editors ever to have been introduced to the gaming community.
The Brutal smart-AI's,.. although admittedly not being the hardest nor smartest in all of gaming history, did give us quite a ride with their smart and uncountable use of tactics which they 'occasionally'' deployed with great cunning fighting alonside or versus the players.
The SuperWeapons, even if 'yes a bit anoying'' did by fact bring us that underlying sense of fear of imminent destruction and the feeling that the favors might swing to your opponents side in any number of seconds. It made for a crucial part of the RA3 playing mentality.
They gave us a truly unqiue set of factions whom opperated in very distinct ways from one another and of which employed different tactics for the various of tasks.
Lastly, they gave us the Replay, one of the first in-whole trully so good theater-modes as far as RTS-IPs' are concerned.

Now, too finish off this way too overly extensive review of mine I shall end by proclaiming in-accordance with personal opinion, that Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 most-probably am one of the very best game-IPs' to have been crafted in reccent memory. 

-:"Spoken In The Common Man's Langauge; It Would Be Fair To Considered It My Nr.1 Favorite Game Of All Time."

So it's one of the few good EA titles on Steam, and it's not saddled with some other atrocious DRM. As for the game itself, it's a super colourful, campy fun time. The campaign is three factions long, each with their own ways of playing (the Empire of the Sun units probably require more micro), not to mention the fact that there's a naval component to factor in. Coupled with a good variety of traditional RTS mission styles, and you've got a really lengthy campaign for its genre, before even setting foot in MP (SP only review, no experience with matchmaking, connectivity, etc.)

But let's be honest though, you play this game to see Tim Curry yuck it up as a Soviet Premier, among other standouts like J.K. Simmons, Jonathan Pryce, George Takei, the Nature Boy Ric Flair (Uprising expansion) and a requisite lineup of pinup females. It's an anachronistic, yet heartfelt throwback to C&C's heyday during the 90s FMV trend, which is super appropriate given the time-travelling shennanigans this B-movie cooks up for it's stupidly fun plot.

Out the gate, nothing but enthusiasm. I was a HUGE fan of the original Red Alert and the Aftermath expansion. (Not Counterstrike though.) RE2 was enjoyable, but too comical for my liking. Still, replayed it about 2-3 times. THIS however? This game can go die in a fire. The graphics look like an imitation of Dark Reign 2, and the entire game system apes Blizzard's.

Previously EA used a left-click system, with centralised Barracks and War Factories (where multiples increased the speed of unit production), as well as a long, but simple, unit selection menu. Now even the power meter is gone. EA, you killed the RE series with Generals, now you are only torturing its corpse.

The Good:
Red Alert 3 is a great game. The easy user interface combined with the fast action make me choose this game over Starcraft II on a nearly daily basis. The multiplayer is amazing, and the game is incredibly balanced. Unfortunately, the game does not have a massive online community. You end up running into the same people, time and time again.

The Bad:
As a fan of Red Alert 1 and 2, I found the campaign to be COMPLETELY destroyed by EA. Real actors, combined with cartoony stuff, and Tanya having blonde hair. It made me cringe. If you're looking to play the campaign, and not delve into the incredible tactics within the multiplayer... don't bother. This game is not for you.

Great game. A big step up from Red Alert 2. This game does not disappoint. A great game for anyone who loves to control massive armies, strategize attacks, and conquer your enemies in one fell swoop. The campaign is fun, fluid and will keep you hooked till the very end, especially if you bring a friend along for the ride. 

Visuals are highly saturated and full of color, fitting the games unique style. 

Frank Klepacki returned to compose the music and it does not dissappoint.

If you're looking for a great RTS experience look no further, Red Alert 3 is for you.

TL;DR Review:

Red Alert 3 is a beautiful, terrifically fun game that also does some interesting things with the RTS genre.

Long Review:

The Red Alert series has some defining aspects - alternate histories, time travel, trained animal units, psychic powers - but its most obvious trait was the cheesiness of its cutscenes.  The Red Alert developers realized that trying to do "serious" FMV for these games usually ended up producing something nigh-unwatchable, like Command & Conquer 2.  So they decided to just turn the cheese knob until it broke off, and Red Alert 3 continues this tradition with pride.  It combines time travel and crazy inventions and Tim Curry to make a wonderful, fun mess of a storyline.  And the best part is that the actors are into it - they understand that the scenery here is meant to be eaten.

But look past the cheese (and cheesecake) and you'll find a fun, very playable RTS.  The three sides all play differently, with the Russians being the simple bruisers, the Empire having the coolest (but most difficult to use) units and the Allies having the most useful commander powers.

Plus, the game has co-op.  The "single player" campaign is actually designed to be played by two people at once, each controlling a different commander.  Since co-op multiplayer is the best multiplayer, it was nice to see this finally come to the RTS genre.  And don't worry - if you don't have anyone to play with, there are nine different AI commanders to help you out, each of whom has their own play style and personality.  As the story progresses and you move to the next campaign, AI commanders that used to be your allies could become your enemies and vice-versa - an excellent touch.

The game is also beautiful, with some of the best water I've ever seen. Models are detailed, textures are rich and of good resolution and special effects are excellent.

In short, Red Alert 3 may have disappointed fans who were eagerly awaiting the next "real" Command & Conquer, but if you take it for what it is it's a blast.

The B-Movie acting in the campaigns that you expect from Red Alert makes the fun, dynamic, and interesting campaign levels even better. The acting is funny and the effort that they put into the story for the campaigns make it even better. All 3 factions are well done and balanced giving multiplayer a great feel. It is not "Which faction is the best?" it is "How can I play them to my style.?"

The abilities that are included in your troops make it very interesting; such as the bullfrog transport and the various EMP abillities for Soviet tesla troopers. It makes the game more dynamic and fun, as you never know when your buddy is going to rain down a couple dozen squads of Soviet infantry into your poorly walled in base. In RA3 you never know what is going to happen next.

I at first was playing on "Very Low" graphics for some reason, and I was still blown away at how much fun I was having; but then I changed it to "Ultra-High" and was even more blown away; the lighting effects, shimmering of water, lighting bolts, command abilities, lasers, and bullets, all combine in firefights to make it look absolutely spectacular.

Game is great. I recommend it to everyone.
Gameplay: Gameplay is great, three different nation with different playstiles and superiorities in air, land and sea. Three unique commando's in each side. Graphics are very good and in a perfect sync with the general ambiance of the game. Also the voice acting of the units is well suited and feels like every unit in the game has its own personality.

As for the scenario, I don't want to give spoilers but let me say this: scenario is that when the Soviets started to lose the war against the Allies(US), they use time-machine and go kill Einstein so the nuclear weapons are not made. This eventually leads that Japan doesn't get hit by it too. So the Empire of Rising Sun(JAPAN) is our 3rd nation. 3 different campaign mode for 3 nations. Campaigns are well made, forces you to use different units and tactics everytime and there are bunch of unique things happen in scenario mode which are not present in the skirmish. Also the live-action videos in scenario mode with this cast is awesome (just Gemma Atkinson alone is more than enough). The different play-style of different AI generals makes game more stable to play solo too.
The last good command and conquer ever made :) Remember the greats.

I've always been a fan of the C&C series, but when it comes to the Red Alert subseries, the childishness and immaturity of it is just too much to bear. Even if you don't care about the campaign, you're still going to put up with goofy units and their stupid voices and cartoonic gameplay experience. Red Alert 3 might as well be a game for children, it is so silly. For the hard of hearing or those who disable the obnoxous sounds that come with, you'll find no comfort in the more-of-the-same style of gameplay. There is nothing innovative about this game that makes you go "wow, I'm really glad I bought this game instead of a competing game from a competing series"

Sometimes the soul of a person, or a game, is laid bare in a single moment. In Red Alert 3, there is a Soviet general with six stars per shoulder, dozens and dozens of medals and a coffee mug decorated with Soviet iconography. In one mission briefing he gravely warns that "Our enemies are thrusting deeply into Mother Russia's tender nether regions." It only gets better when the Soviet Hammer Tank exclaims "It's hammer time!" and moves to engage. The best thing about all this is that the actual gameplay follows suit, being both fast-paced and relaxing. Graphical style is very gonzo and bright and fits the subject matter perfectly, as does the gloriously nonsensical soundtrack. Red Alert 3 is silly harmless fun that has not aged a bit in five years.

An awesome RTS with an amazing cast, C&C:RA3 is one of those games that will have you loading it up again and again. With Tim Curry as the Premier of the Soviet Union, and George Takei as the Emperor of Japan, the talent involved in RA3 is top-notch.

The game is more frantic, fast-paced, and epic in scale than anything in recent memory. The solo missions are fantastic battles with multiple bases per player, multiple players per side. The AI, while not perfect, plays in a way that is varied, challenging, and makes you utterly hate your opponent. In addition to the standard RTS elements being spot-on

Right off the top I'm going to say that the story and live action cutscenes are absolutely abysmal. I have no respect for any of the actors and as a result I'm lost in a story with no coherent reason to progress, or even exist. However, the game mechanics, the controls and the actual graphics all work very well together in perfect blend of RTS perfection. Fans of the franchise will be pleased to hear that it plays very much like Red Alert 2; skirmish mode is back, as well as online which are both incredibly addictive. Building a massive army and tipping the enemy over like a pawn is one of the most satisfying feelings in gaming. Apart from the live action garbage, and a few minor bugs I've encountered, this is a perfect gaming experience. 7 / 10

A few game mechanics from RA2 are gone (for the worse), and the campaigns are pretty short. Many of the individual units aren't very useful.

BUT:  This game has coop.  Coop makes a mediocre game pretty fun, and RA3 is no exception.  Playing through the 3 campaigns with a friend is entertaining (each player controls their own faction).  Coop RTS is an excellent idea and I'm dissapointed it isn't more common.  If you have a friend, both of you should buy RA3 and play coop.

One of the few RTS games that managed to pull of naval warfare correctly. Naval warfare is a rather big part of the game, but it doesn't feel tedious and it doesn't feel like you are missing anything on the more sea based maps. Additionally this game nails co-operative play better than any other RTS game I have played. The missions are very well structured for co-operative play. For example on one map your ally is expected to defend an island while you go out and attack the enemy, and on another your base is in the water while your allies base is on land, and you are expected to perform a naval assault while your ally does a land assault. The music in this game is also pretty great, but that is to be expected from a Red Alert title. The unit designs are neat, from armored bears to tranforming mecha. This is a game that doesn't take itself very seriously and probably turned out better for it.

RA3 sets its sights firmly on bringing a smile to your face. The mood of the game is enjoyably goofy and nowhere is this more evident than the completely gratuitous sexy women who practically cavort for your pleasure.  The game mechanics are no less entertaining with loads of odd military units like attack dolphins, armored blimps, and football talking troopers.  Unfortunately the units aren't quite so devastatingly useful as RA2 offered, -it's a rare thing when a single, properly managed unit can land the blows to win a game, and more's the pity.  Furthermore the superpowers are a little more niggly to obtain and less brutally satisfying.

The game plays out much more methodically than RA2 or C&C3 did so that you will have to spend more attention on individual unit tactics rather than massed forces.  This makes the game less friendly to "turtle" game tactics but grants a feeling of earned superiority when you finagle the most out of your limited resources.

Lots of fun, in short.  :)

There are RTS games that try to be serious and realistic, and then there's the C&C Red Alert series, set in an alternate timeline where Einstein goes back in time and eliminates Hitler causing the Soviets to rise to power. The third in the series proves to be even more rediculous as the Soviets go back in time and eliminate Einstein causing the Japanese to rise to power. Now there are three factions each with their own individual play styles and campaigns that can be played solo or co-op. If you want an RTS that is over the top and most of all lots of fun, this is the game for you.
